page.title: Fab Five: The Texas Cheerleader Scandal

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | name = Fab Five:
The Texas Cheerlader Scandal | image = Fab Five Texas Cheerleader Scandal.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Opening title | genre = | creator = | based_on = | writer = Teena Booth | screenplay = | story = | director = [[Tom McLoughlin]] | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Jenna Dewan]] * [[Ashley Benson]] * Aimee Spring Fortier * [[Stephanie Honoré]] * [[Jessica Heap]] * Ashlynn Ross * [[Tatum O'Neal]] }} | narrated = | music = [[Anton Sanko]] | country = United States | language = English | num_episodes = | producer = Robert J. Wilson | editor = Charles Bornstein | cinematography = [[Lloyd Ahern II]] | runtime = 88 minutes | company = Orly Andelson Productions | distributor = [[Fox Television Studios]] | budget = | network = [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime Television]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2008|8|2}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Fab Five: The Texas Cheerleader Scandal''''' is a 2008 American [[teen drama]] [[TV movie|made-for-television]] film produced by [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime Television]]. It stars [[Jenna Dewan]], [[Ashley Benson]], and [[Tatum O'Neal]], and was directed by [[Tom McLoughlin]]. The film premiered on August 2, 2008. It is based on real-life events that occurred at [[McKinney North High School]] in [[McKinney, Texas]], in 2006, five teenage [[cheerleader]]s became notorious for truancies, violations of the school dress code, and general disrespect to the school community. ==Background== In 2005, Michaela Ward was hired to teach geography and coach the cheerleading squad at [[McKinney North High School]]. She discovered that five cheerleaders, nicknamed the "Fab Five", had been disruptive in school and off-campus. They are the five high school mean girls who rules this school with an iron fist. They broke rules, were truant, and causing disturbances during classes. They also caused trouble during off-campus activities, posting photographs of themselves partying, drinking alcohol, and visiting an adult store on [[Myspace]]. Ward was unable to deal with the Fab Five and the school administrators who did not punish them; she resigned in October 2006, despite her close relationships with her students. Ward contacted media to tell them about the Fab Five's unruly behavior and the school's handling of them. Ward told [[Lifetime Television]] about the story; the company produced a film based on Ward's story. ==Plot== Five high school cheerleaders dubbed the "Fab Five"—Brooke Tippit ([[Ashley Benson]]) who is co-captain of the squad, Jeri Blackburn ([[Jessica Heap]]), Lisa Toledo (Aimee Spring Fortier), Ashley ([[Stephanie Honoré]]), and Tabitha Doering (Ashlynn Ross) run amok and who are the mean girls of the school. Teachers, parents, and administrators fail to punish them for their unruly behavior, which includes repeatedly getting their coaches fired after disagreements or driving them to quit. These girls disregard school rules, drink alcohol, bully other students, and post suggestive pictures on the internet. After a new cheerleading coach Emma Carr ([[Jenna Dewan]]) arrives, the girls initially rebel against her but later become cooperative. Brooke becomes furious with Coach Carr when she assigns Meagan Harper, the most respected member of the squad, as co-captain because up until then, she had been the only captain. The Fab Five perform well at a pep rally, but after Ashley is kissed by Jeri’s boyfriend, the other girls eject her from the group and later become the "Fab Four," although Ashley remains part of the squad. Carr tries to discipline the girls, which results in a change in attitude. The girls start bullying other pupils, including Cindy, Meagan's younger sister, and are suspended from the team. The Fab Four get drunk and are caught trying to leave the campus by a guard and the principal. The girls tell the school's superintendent they were tired after a test and wanted to sleep. The security guard then tells Carr about the incident, and she confronts the principal and superintendent, who give excuses for not punishing the girls. Carr insists the principal punishes them, so the principal threatens to dissolve the team. Defiant, Carr punishes the whole squad by continually canceling practices and kicking Jeri off the squad. At next practice session, Carr hands each of the girls an eraser for a "fresh" start, but only Tabitha accepts. As revenge for Jeri's ejection, the girls show the superintendent a picture of Carr hugging another teacher at the school and say the two have been having an affair. At the discipline meeting for Jeri, Carr is repeatedly accused of flirting and not formally punishing the girls. At the next practice session, the "Fab Four" struggle to perform the [[liberty stunt]], but Carr inspires them to learn it. Carr finds Lisa has cheated on a test. After penalizing her, Lisa yells at Carr and storms out. Lisa then tells her father that Carr was bullying her. Carr then accidentally resigns and sends an email to the cheerleaders apologizing for it. She visits the school and is fired by the principal. The girls confront Carr as she prepares to leave the school. She hears about a reporter who is researching "cheerleaders gone wild" and gives an interview about the ongoing events at Jackson High School. The school investigates, and the "Fab Four" enjoy the attention and lie to the reporter about their treatment. Carr discovers the reporter's true agenda, tells him what happened, leaves angrily, and bumps into Brooke. Carr simply asks her if she thinks the [[University of Southern California]] will accept her as a student after all the negative publicity of what has happened. The investigator reports that the allegations against the "Fab Four" and administrators are true and that Carr is innocent. He blames the principal for the problem and Carr losing her job. Lorraine and the assistant principal are suspended from their jobs. Brooke is pulled from the school by her mother, and the rest of the "Fab Four" are no longer allowed to cheer. Brooke and her mother leave followed by cameras, Brooke waves, and Carr is despondent. However, Carr doesn't get her job back from the school. Four months later, Carr watches the girls at a cheer competition and is welcomed with praise and hugs, including Ashley, who she exchanges smiles with. The new cheerleaders compete, and Carr discovers Cindy had written an essay about her, discussing how she stood up to the administration and stopped Brooke and the Fab Three from terrorizing their school, revealing that Carr did change things after all. The girls compete and perform the stunt they struggled with earlier, leaving Carr feeling proud and worthy. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Jenna Dewan]] as Coach Emma Carr * [[Ashley Benson]] as Brooke Tippit * Aimee Spring Fortier as Lisa Toledo * [[Jessica Heap]] as Jeri Blackburn * [[Stephanie Honoré]] as Ashley Sanchez * Ashlynn Ross as Tabitha Doering * [[Tatum O'Neal]] as Principal Lorene Tippit * [[Dameon Clarke]] as Coach Adam Reeve * [[Carissa Capobianco]] as Cindy Harper * Hailey Wist as Meagan Harper * Natalie Rose as Natalie Zamora {{div col end}} ==Reception== The television movie aired on Saturday, August 2, 2008, and scored a 2.63 [[Nielsen ratings|household rating]] (3,041,547 viewers). It scored a 2.63 rating (280,405 viewers) among females aged 12–17 and a 2.17 rating (1,219,726 viewers) among females aged 18–49.{{cite news|url=http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/08-04-2008/0004861259&EDATE= |title=Lifetime Original Movie 'Fab Five: The Texas Cheerleader Scandal' Builds Pyramid to Become Network's Top W18-34 and W12-17 Movie of the Year |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713222923/http://www2.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104 |archivedate=2012-07-13 |df= }} Also seen in [http://www.thefutoncritic.com/ratings/2008/08/04/lifetime-original-movie-fab-five-the-texas-cheerleader-scandal-builds-pyramid-to-become-networks-top-w18-34-and-w12-17-movie-of-the-year-28391/20080804lifetime01/ The Futon Critic] and [https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/08/04/idUS170026+04-Aug-2008+PRN20080804 Reuters]. Linda Stasi of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the movie three stars out of four.{{cite news|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=July 31, 2008|accessdate=October 21, 2012|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/item_A3LG9IW6ErfWmNQyA5vcQN|title=Mean Girls High: True Story of 'Texas Cheerleaders'|author=Linda Stasi}} ''[[Newsweek]]'' said the real-life events that inspired the film were "grimmer" than the television movie; the real-life principal and the vice-principal of the school lost their jobs. Girls from the [[Myspace]] photographs (the "Fab Five") became victims of stalkers and "haunted by their reputations [from high school]". Discipline at [[McKinney North High School]] became stricter than before. ''Newsweek'' said the film was close to the real-life events, the portrayal of Jenna Dewan's character was "brave but naïve", and the story was "an entertaining morality tale" yet "preachy". Steve Thompson of ''[[Yahoo!]] Voices'' praised this movie for addressing important messages to viewers about consequential actions, especially by schools and cheerleaders. Thompson called the portrayal of cheerleaders "purely evil" and vindictive, and that some scenes were inspired by other real "mean girls" events, such as the beating of a 16-year-old girl in [[Lakeland, Florida]], rather than the McKinney incidents.{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/review-fab-five-texas-cheerleader-scandal-on-1759855.html?cat=40 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130210053314/http://voices.yahoo.com/review-fab-five-texas-cheerleader-scandal-on-1759855.html?cat=40 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 10, 2013 |title=Review of ''Fab Five: The Texas Cheerleader Scandal'' on Lifetime |author=Steve Thompson |work=[[Yahoo!]] Voices |date=August 2, 2008 |accessdate=October 21, 2012 }} For more information about beatings of a 16-year-old girl from [[Lakeland, Florida]], read [http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/24009077 the article from MSNBC.com]. ==Aftermath== After the story broke, Michaela Ward faced unemployment and "became ostracized", especially after her lawsuits. In 2008 she filed an unsuccessful lawsuit to get her job back. According to [[KGNS-TV]], Ward coaches cheerleading in [[McKinney, Texas]], and had privately coached a former pupil. In December 2009, former principal Linda Theret was hired by the [[Laredo Independent School District]] as Executive Director of Curriculum.{{cite news |website=[[KGNS-TV]] |date=December 7, 2009 |title=Laredo Independent School District hires Linda Theret |url=http://www.pro8news.com/news/78730842.html |accessdate=October 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022132532/http://www.pro8news.com/news/78730842.html |archivedate=October 22, 2012 |df= }} ==References== {{cite news|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|title=Lifetime has 'Five' spirit, yes they do|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lifetime-has-five-spirit-yes-105375|date=February 22, 2008|accessdate=October 21, 2012}} {{subscription required}} {{cite journal|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2007/01/01/mean-girls.html|author1=Arian Campo-Flores|author2=Gretel C. Kovach|title=Mean Girls|magazine=[[Newsweek]]|date=January 1, 2007|accessdate=October 21, 2012}} {{cite journal|date=August 4, 2008|accessdate=October 21, 2012|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2008/08/04/the-fab-five-revisited.html|magazine=[[Newsweek]]|title=The 'Fab Five' Revisited}} {{cite interview|first=Michaela |last=Ward |title=Michaela Ward: Setting the Story Straight |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/michaela-ward-setting-story-straight |interviewer=Dayna Gross |publisher=[[Lifetime Television]] |accessdate=October 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018071932/http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/michaela-ward-setting-story-straight |archivedate=October 18, 2012 |df= }} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1191113}} * [http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/fab-five-the-texas-cheerleader-scandal Official website] * [https://caselaw.findlaw.com/tx-court-of-appeals/1116217.html ''Ward v. Theret''], July 15, 2009 ([http://statecasefiles.justia.com/documents/texas/eighth-court-of-appeals/08-08-00143-cv.pdf?ts=1323970196 PDF version]) {{Tom McLoughlin|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Lifetime (TV network) films]] [[Category:Films set in Texas]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Teen drama films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Texas culture]] [[Category:Films shot in New Orleans]] [[Category:2008 television films]] [[Category:2000s high school films]] [[Category:Cheerleading films]] [[Category:Films directed by Tom McLoughlin]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/178.17.46.64|178.17.46.64]] ([[User talk:178.17.46.64|talk]]): Worse than Ride to Hell Retribution? ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Short description|Online multiplayer role-playing game released in November 2018}} {{Use American English|date=November 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox video game | title = Fallout 76 | image = Fallout 76 cover.jpg | developer = [[Bethesda Game Studios]]{{efn|Additional work by [[Bethesda Game Studios Austin]]<ref name="Noclip" />}} | publisher = [[Bethesda Softworks]] | series = ''[[Fallout (series)|Fallout]]'' | engine = [[Creation Engine]] | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[Xbox One]]}} | released = November 14, 2018 | genre = [[Action role-playing]] | modes = [[Multiplayer]] | director = [[Todd Howard (video game designer)|Todd Howard]] | producer = | designer = [[Emil Pagliarulo]] | programmer = | artist = Nathan Purkeypile | writer = Emil Pagliarulo | composer = [[Inon Zur]] }}
'''''Fallout 76''''' is an online [[action role-playing game]] developed by [[Bethesda Game Studios]] and published by [[Bethesda Softworks]], part of the ''[[Fallout (series)|Fallout]]'' series. Released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], and [[Xbox One]] on November 14, 2018, it is a [[prequel]] to previous series games.{{efn|The opening chapter of ''[[Fallout 4]]'' takes place twenty-five years prior to ''Fallout 76'', but the remainder of the game takes place two hundred years later.}} ''Fallout 76'' is Bethesda Game Studios's first [[multiplayer]] game; players explore the [[open world]], which has been torn apart by nuclear war, with others.
Bethesda developed the game using a modified version of its [[Creation Engine]], which allowed the accommodation of multiplayer gameplay and a more detailed game world. ''Fallout 76'' was released to generally mixed reviews<!-- Please don't add "mixed-to-negative" as it's imprecisely describe the game's reception, "Mixed" describes both the game's mixed and negative reception, as per [[WP:VG/MIXED]] -->, with many criticizing the game's numerous technical issues, overall design, lack of gameplay purpose, and absence of human [[non-playable character]]s.
==Gameplay== ''Fallout 76'' is [[Bethesda Game Studios]]' first [[online multiplayer]] game.<ref>{{Citation |title=YouTube Live at E3 2018 Monday: Ninja, PlayStation & Ubisoft Press Conferences (Official Livestream) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPWDwBrUNyY |website=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180610233436/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PPWDwBrUNyY# |archive-date=June 10, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref name="Polygon">{{Cite news |url=https://www.polygon.com/e3/2018/6/10/17405448/fallout-76-multiplayer-trailer-bethesda-e3-2018 |title=Bethesda confirms 'Fallout 76 is entirely online' |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611172738/https://www.polygon.com/e3/2018/6/10/17405448/fallout-76-multiplayer-trailer-bethesda-e3-2018# |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>{{efn|In 2006, [[Interplay Entertainment]] and [[Masthead Studios]] started development of ''[[Fallout Online]]'', a [[massively multiplayer online game]] set in the ''Fallout'' world. The game was canceled in 2012 after a legal dispute between Interplay and [[Bethesda Softworks]] that saw Bethesda purchase the rights to the game in an out-of-court settlement.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Great Fallout Legal Battle Ends Without a Fallout MMO |url=http://kotaku.com/5874561/the-great-fallout-legal-battle-ends-without-a-fallout-mmo |work=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=June 17, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111112900/http://kotaku.com/5874561/the-great-fallout-legal-battle-ends-without-a-fallout-mmo# |archive-date=January 11, 2012 |dead-url=no }}</ref>}} Players may play individually or with a party of up to three others.<ref name="The Verge">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/10/17447476/fallout-76-online-game-multiplayer-trailer-bethesda-e3-2018 |title=Fallout 76 is an online-only survival game coming out on November 14, 2018 |website=[[The Verge]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611155155/https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/10/17447476/fallout-76-online-game-multiplayer-trailer-bethesda-e3-2018# |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/e3-2018-more-fallout-76-details-revealed/1100-6459634/ |title=E3 2018: More Fallout 76 Details Revealed |last=Plagge |first=Kallie |date=June 10, 2018 |website=[[GameSpot]]|accessdate=June 11, 2018}}</ref> The servers for the game are [[Dedicated server|dedicated]], with the player automatically allocated to one of them.<ref name="Polygon" /> While the game was expected to launch with public servers only, game director [[Todd Howard (video game designer)|Todd Howard]] revealed plans for private servers to be introduced some time after the game's launch. These private servers allow players to invite friends to play in order to prevent undesirable aspects of [[player versus player]] gameplay such as [[Griefer|griefing]] from affecting an individual player's experience of the game. Howard described the delay as being necessary to allow Bethesda time to assure the stability of public servers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-private-servers |title=Fallout 76 will have private servers |first=Harry |last=Sheppard |date=June 12, 2018 |accessdate=June 12, 2018 |work=[[PCGamesN]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612163019/https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-private-servers# |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> Elements of previous ''Fallout'' games are present and are modified to work with the real-time game. The [[Fallout 3#V.A.T.S.|V.A.T.S.]] system—a mechanic first introduced in ''[[Fallout 3]]'' that allows players to pause the game to target specific locations on an enemy's body to attack—is used in ''Fallout 76'' as a real-time system, though it still allow players to specify targets on an enemy's body.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-vats |title=Fallout 76 has a real-time VATS system |first=Jeremy |last=Peel |date=June 12, 2018 |accessdate=June 12, 2018 |work=[[PCGamesN]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612134308/https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-vats# |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
The game features an [[open world]] four times the size of that of ''[[Fallout 4]]''.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/fallout-76-unveiled-e3-2018/ |title=Bethesda's 'Fallout 76' is four times the size of 'Fallout 4' |date=June 10, 2018 |work=[[Digital Trends]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611173511/https://www.digitaltrends.com/gaming/fallout-76-unveiled-e3-2018/ |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> The game world is called "[[Appalachia]]" and is a representation of [[West Virginia]]. It features recreations of real locations in the region, including the [[West Virginia State Capitol]], [[The Greenbrier]], [[Woodburn Circle]], [[New River Gorge Bridge]], and [[Camden Park (amusement park)|Camden Park]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Horti |first1=Samuel |title=Fallout 76's map is called Appalachia, Bethesda confirms |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/fallout-76s-map-is-called-appalachia-bethesda-confirm/ |website=PC Gamer |accessdate=September 22, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180923052116/https://www.pcgamer.com/fallout-76s-map-is-called-appalachia-bethesda-confirm/ |archive-date=September 23, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://culturedvultures.com/fallout-76-may-take-place-in-2102-the-earliest-in-the-franchise-yet/ |title=Fallout 76 May Take Place In 2102, The Earliest In The Franchise Yet |date=May 30, 2018 |work=Cultured Vultures |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180603060350/https://culturedvultures.com/fallout-76-may-take-place-in-2102-the-earliest-in-the-franchise-yet/ |archive-date=June 3, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.polygon.com/2018/6/10/17447340/fallout-76-locations-west-virginia-real-world |title=Tracking the real-world locations of Fallout 76 hints at a massive game |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611170136/https://www.polygon.com/2018/6/10/17447340/fallout-76-locations-west-virginia-real-world# |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref name="Herald-Dispatch">{{Cite news |url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/features_entertainment/video-game-to-be-based-in-a-post-apocalyptic-mountain/article_09ab293b-41aa-5b78-bed4-d880937ece7a.html |title=Video game to be based in a post-apocalyptic Mountain State |first=Dave |last=Lavender |work=[[The Herald-Dispatch]]|accessdate=June 12, 2018 }}</ref> The game features numerous new mutated monsters, several of which—such as the [[Mothman]] and the [[Flatwoods monster]]—were inspired by West Virginian [[folklore]].<ref name="Herald-Dispatch" /><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/10/17446820/fallout-76-mothman-flying-deathclaw-west-virginia |title=Fans think West Virginia urban legend Mothman is in Fallout 76 |work=[[The Verge]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611170353/https://www.theverge.com/2018/6/10/17446820/fallout-76-mothman-flying-deathclaw-west-virginia# |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/news/e3-2018-bethesda-conference-will-see-fallout-76-unexpected-surprise/ |title=E3 2018 Bethesda conference: Fallout 76 release date, Doom Eternal and The Elder Scrolls VI confirmed |last=Hood |first=Vic |date=June 11, 2018 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |issn=0307-1235 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611012352/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/news/e3-2018-bethesda-conference-will-see-fallout-76-unexpected-surprise/ |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
The game includes revisions to the [[Fallout (video game)#SPECIAL system|SPECIAL progression system]]. Character attributes fall into one of seven categories: strength, perception, endurance, charisma, intelligence, agility and luck. As the player levels up, they are able to spend skill points to boost their attributes on a scale of one to fifteen. Players are able to choose perks, or passive abilities that offer gameplay bonuses. These perks fall into each of the SPECIAL categories and take the form of trading cards. Each card has a value and the player can adopt perks equal to their respective value; for example, if the player has a strength rating of five, then they may equip strength perks worth five points. The player can merge similar cards together to create more powerful—albeit more expensive—perks. The system is designed to encourage the player to recognise the situation they are in and choose perks that aid them rather than passively selecting them and having them for the duration of the game.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
''Fallout 76'' does not feature any human non-player characters (NPCs) as all surviving humans are other players.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://twitter.com/BethesdaStudios/status/1006003558502752256 |title=Bethesda Game Studios on Twitter |website=[[Twitter]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611124134/https://twitter.com/BethesdaStudios/status/1006003558502752256# |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> This required Bethesda to change their approach to storytelling as previous games in the series relied on NPCs to assign quests, engage the player in dialog and advance the overall narrative. ''Fallout 76'' instead uses a combination of NPCs in the form of robots, recordings such as collectible holotapes, terminals throughout the game world, and environmental storytelling where the player uncovers fragments of a narrative by exploring locations that they piece together themselves.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} Each of these elements had previously been used in the series, often to provide backstory for characters and the world of the game whilst remaining separate from the main narrative. According to Howard, this system allows Bethesda to tell a story whilst giving players a greater ability to create their own narratives.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
The game expands on ''Fallout 4''{{'}}s settlements by allowing the player the ability to build bases at many locations of the map.<ref name="PC Gamer">{{Cite news |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/fallout-76-is-a-multiplayer-softcore-survival-game-about-building-settlements/ |title=Fallout 76 is an online game, and you can nuke other players |work=[[PC Gamer]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611173815/https://www.pcgamer.com/fallout-76-is-a-multiplayer-softcore-survival-game-about-building-settlements/ |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> These creations are assigned to the player's profile and are removed from the game world when the player is offline to prevent progress from being lost.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} While other players are able to attack player settlements while they are online, the game preserves player creations in some form to prevent players from having to start over if their creations and progress are destroyed.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
Players are able to use nuclear weapons to temporarily change the areas of game world. After acquiring launch codes, the player can access missile silos and fire a missile at almost any point on the map. This irradiates the area, which the player can explore to find rare weapons, gear and items. However, it also attracts powerful enemies and the player needs to be sufficiently strong to survive.<ref name="PC Gamer" /> The game also includes a photo mode. The player has the ability to pose their character and choose from a variety of facial expressions and filters.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fallout 76 will have a photo mode, complete with poses and fancy filters |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/fallout-76-will-have-a-photo-mode-complete-with-poses-and-fancy-filters/ |website=pcgamer |accessdate=October 23, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180918160725/https://www.pcgamer.com/fallout-76-will-have-a-photo-mode-complete-with-poses-and-fancy-filters/ |archive-date=September 18, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
==Premise== {{further|Fallout (series)#Setting}} ''Fallout 76'' is a narrative prequel to previous ''Fallout'' games. It is set in an [[alternate history]],<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.pcgamer.com/major-events-in-the-fallout-timeline/ | title = Major events in the Fallout timeline | first = Jody | last = Macgregor | date = July 28, 2018 | accessdate = August 14, 2018 | work = [[PC Gamer]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180815055253/https://www.pcgamer.com/major-events-in-the-fallout-timeline/ | archive-date = August 15, 2018 | dead-url = no | df = mdy-all }}</ref> and takes place in 2102, twenty-five years after a nuclear war that devastated the Earth. The player character is a resident of Vault 76, a [[fallout shelter]] that was built in [[West Virginia]] to house America's best and brightest minds. The player character exits the Vault on "Reclamation Day" as part of a plan to re-colonize the Wasteland.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/31/fallout-76-the-history-of-vault-76-and-what-it-means-for-fallout-76 |title=Fallout 76: The History Of Vault 76 And What It Means For Fallout 76 |first=Tom |last=Marks |date=May 31, 2018 |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |work=[[IGN]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180611165612/http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/31/fallout-76-the-history-of-vault-76-and-what-it-means-for-fallout-76# |archive-date=June 11, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
==Development== ''Fallout 76'' uses a modified version of Bethesda's [[Creation Engine]] designed to accommodate multiplayer gameplay.<ref name="Noclip">{{cite web |author1=[[Danny O'Dwyer|Noclip]] |title=The Making of Fallout 76 – Noclip Documentary |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gi8PTAJ2Hjs |website=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=June 17, 2018 |date=June 12, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180617050330/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gi8PTAJ2Hjs# |archive-date=June 17, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> Work on modifying the engine was carried out by [[Bethesda Game Studios Austin]].<ref name="Noclip" /> The modified engine also allowed the development team to incorporate new lighting models, rendering processes and more accurate terrain mapping. These allowed the development team to create a world with sixteen times more detail than was possible with previous iterations of the Creation Engine. The game also includes a dynamic weather system that allows for localized climatic conditions and greater [[draw distance]]s mean that these weather events can be observed by the player from far away.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Bethesda Softworks |title=Bethesda Game Studios E3 2018 Showcase |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hPlpOIfFbWI |website=[[YouTube]] |accessdate=June 17, 2018 |date=June 12, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614214600/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hPlpOIfFbWI# |archive-date=June 14, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> As with many previous games in the series, its musical score was composed by [[Inon Zur]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fogel |first1=Stefanie |title='Fallout,' 'Dragon Age' Series Composer Inon Zur to Score 'Fallout 76' |url=https://variety.com/2018/gaming/news/fallout-76-inon-zur-exclusive-1202900549/ |website=Variety |accessdate=August 20, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820105823/https://variety.com/2018/gaming/news/fallout-76-inon-zur-exclusive-1202900549/ |archive-date=August 20, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
==Release== The game was announced on May 30, 2018; the announcement was preceded by a twenty-four hour live stream on [[Twitch.tv|Twitch]] showing a [[Vault Boy]] bobblehead toy in front of a monitor with a "Please Stand By" [[Test card|test pattern screen]], a signature image of the series. This stream was watched by a total of over two million people, with more than one hundred thousand people watching at any time.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/5/30/17408600/bethesda-fallout-76-twitch-stream |title=Two million people tuned into Bethesda's day-long stream of a toy |work=[[The Verge]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180603154806/https://www.theverge.com/2018/5/30/17408600/bethesda-fallout-76-twitch-stream# |archive-date=June 3, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
Details of the game were announced by Howard during Bethesda's press conference at the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2018|Electronic Entertainment Expo]] on June 10, 2018, including its anticipated release date of November 14, 2018. As it is Bethesda Game Studio's first experience with a fully online game, Howard confirmed that there would be an [[Beta test|open beta phase]], beginning on October 23, 2018 for Xbox One, and October 30, 2018 for PlayStation 4 and PC.<ref name="The Verge" />

===Pre-release=== In response to the announcement that ''Fallout 76'' would feature only multiplayer, a petition was created by fans of the series which called for the game to include a single-player mode. The petition received thousands of signatures within a day.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://comicbook.com/gaming/2018/06/11/fallout-76-petition-single-player/ |title=Fallout 76 Petition Demands a Single-Player Only Mode |work=WWG |accessdate=June 13, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612202713/http://comicbook.com/gaming/2018/06/11/fallout-76-petition-single-player/ |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.inverse.com/article/45859-fallout-76-single-player-petition-has-over-6k-signatures |title='Fallout 76' Single Player Petition: Thousands of Fans Demand Solo Campaign |work=[[Inverse (website)|Inverse]] |accessdate=June 13, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180613084700/https://www.inverse.com/article/45859-fallout-76-single-player-petition-has-over-6k-signatures# |archive-date=June 13, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> Following the game's announcement, there was a burst of interest in tourism in West Virginia. The website "West Virginia Explorer" reported an increase of fifteen times the visitors to the site in the days after the announcement, while management of the [[Camden Park (amusement park)|Camden Park]] amusement park said there was an increase in people looking to purchase park merchandise.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-west-virginia |title=West Virginia tourist sites see massive traffic after Fallout 76 reveal |first=Dustin |last=Bailey |date=June 18, 2018 |accessdate=June 18, 2018 |work=[[PCGamesN]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618230343/https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-west-virginia# |archive-date=June 18, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
The teaser trailer shown at [[E3 2018]] featured a [[cover version]] of [[John Denver]]'s song "[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/30/fallout-76s-setting-may-have-been-teased-by-fallout-3 |title=How Fallout 3 Could Indicate Fallout 76's Setting |last=Dornbush |first=Jonathon |date=May 30, 2018 |website=[[IGN]] -US |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612151558/http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/30/fallout-76s-setting-may-have-been-teased-by-fallout-3# |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/30/fallout-76-announced |title=Fallout 76 Announced, Will Reportedly Be an 'Online Survival RPG' |last=Skrebels |first=Joe |date=May 30, 2018 |website=[[IGN]] -US |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612145818/http://www.ign.com/articles/2018/05/30/fallout-76-announced# |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.polygon.com/2018/5/30/17408674/fallout-76-trailer-pc-ps4-xbox-one |title=Fallout 76 is the next game in the Fallout universe |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |accessdate=June 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612143216/https://www.polygon.com/2018/5/30/17408674/fallout-76-trailer-pc-ps4-xbox-one# |archive-date=June 12, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> Fans of the series expressed interest in the song, prompting Bethesda to announce plans to release the song on digital musical services, with all proceeds from it being donated to [[Habitat for Humanity]], assuring a minimum {{USD|100,000}} donation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-country-roads-itunes |title=Fallout 76's 'Country Roads' cover is going on sale for charity |first=Jeremy |last=Peel |date=June 14, 2018 |accessdate=June 18, 2018 |work=[[PCGamesN]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180619012732/https://www.pcgamesn.com/fallout-76/fallout-76-country-roads-itunes# |archive-date=June 19, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
===Critical response=== According to review aggregator [[Metacritic]], the PC and PlayStation 4 versions received "mixed or average" reviews, while the Xbox One version received "generally unfavorable" reviews.<ref name="Fallout 76-MCPC"/><ref name="Fallout 76-MCXONE"/><ref name="Fallout 76-MCPS4"/> The numerous negative reviews from critics led ''Forbes'' to describe the release of ''Fallout 76'' as a "historically bad launch" and to question if Bethesda would consider the property "worth saving" moving forward.<ref name="Forbes-2">{{Cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2018/11/23/after-a-historically-bad-launch-is-fallout-76-worth-saving/ |title=After A Historically Bad Launch, Is 'Fallout 76' Worth Saving? |last=Tassi| first=Paul|date=November 23, 2018 |work=[[IGN]] |access-date=November 23, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181123201440/https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2018/11/23/after-a-historically-bad-launch-is-fallout-76-worth-saving/ |archive-date=November 23, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
''[[The Guardian]]'' called the game "a pointless walk in the post-apocalypse" featuring "half-baked conflict and witless quests to unearth the dead".<ref name="Guardian">{{Cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/nov/19/fallout-76-review-playstation-xbox-pc |title=Fallout 76 review – a pointless walk in the post-apocalypse |last=Nielsen |first=Holly |date=November 19, 2018 |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=November 19, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181119163219/https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/nov/19/fallout-76-review-playstation-xbox-pc# |archive-date=November 19, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> According to ''[[Forbes]]'', ''Fallout 76'' was a "huge, rare, total miss" by Bethesda.<ref name="Forbes">{{Cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/games/2018/11/20/fallout-76-review-xbox-one-x-look-upon-my-works-and-despair/#3514c2af5e67 |title='Fallout 76' Review (Xbox One X): Look Upon My Works And Despair |last=Tassi |first=Paul |date=November 20, 2018 |work=[[Forbes]] |access-date=November 20, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/games/2018/11/20/fallout-76-review-xbox-one-x-look-upon-my-works-and-despair/#3514c2af5e67 |archive-date=November 20, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> ''[[Eurogamer]]'' described the game as a "bizarre, boring, broken mess", adding that, shortly after its launch, it should be considered as a "failed experiment".<ref name="Eurogamer">{{Cite news |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-11-20-fallout-76-review-a-bizarre-boring-and-broken-mess |title=Fallout 76 review - a bizarre, boring, broken mess |last=Yin-Poole |first=Wesley |date=November 20, 2018 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |access-date=November 20, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-11-20-fallout-76-review-a-bizarre-boring-and-broken-mess |archive-date=November 20, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
''[[Business Insider]]'' described ''Fallout 76'' as "a jumble of disparate video game elements set loose in an online world, held together by a string of pointless fetch quests and experience points".<ref name="Business-Insider">{{Cite news |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/fallout-76-ps4-review-2018-11 |title=The new 'Fallout' game is a boring mess that you shouldn't play — here's why |last=Gilbert |first=Ben |date=November 20, 2018 |work=[[Business Insider]] |access-date=November 20, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.businessinsider.com/fallout-76-ps4-review-2018-11 |archive-date=November 20, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> ''[[Newsweek]]'' said that moments of the enjoyment during their review were "outweighed by the near-constant performance issues and poorly executed game systems", adding that they were disappointed at the game despite being a fan of the series.<ref name="Newsweek">{{Cite news |url=https://www.newsweek.com/fallout-76-review-bad-sucks-trash-disappointment-broken-1225686 |title=THE BROKEN PROMISE OF 'FALLOUT 76' (REVIEW) |last=Mozuch |first=Mo |date=November 20, 2018 |work=[[Newsweek]] |access-date=November 20, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.newsweek.com/fallout-76-review-bad-sucks-trash-disappointment-broken-1225686 |archive-date=November 20, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref>
''[[PCWorld]]'' ended their review early due to their frustration with the game's technical performance, and said that it still would not be a great game to them even if it "functioned properly".<ref name="PCWorld">{{Cite news |url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/3323056/gaming/fallout-76-review.html |title=Fallout 76 review: Almost hell, West Virginia |last=Dingman |first=Hayman |date=November 21, 2018 |work=[[PCWorld]] |access-date=November 21, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/3323056/gaming/fallout-76-review.html |archive-date=November 21, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' wrote that ''Fallout 76'' may be the "most badly made video game" they had ever seen from a major publisher. They further described the game as "a disastrous failure" whose technical shortcomings may one day be fixed, but whose "design failings and obliviousness to its own potential" suggested that it was "irrevocably broken".<ref name="Metro">{{Cite news |url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/11/21/fallout-76-review-a-bad-idea-poorly-executed-8162807/ |title=Fallout 76 review – a bad idea, poorly executed |last= |first= |date=November 21, 2018 |work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |access-date=November 21, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/11/21/fallout-76-review-a-bad-idea-poorly-executed-8162807/ |archive-date=November 21, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> ''[[GameSpot]]'' said that the game "can look and feel like its illustrious predecessors at times, but it's a soulless husk of an experience."<ref name="Gamespot">{{Cite news |url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/fallout-76-review-scorched-earth/1900-6417040/ |title=Fallout 76 Review: Scorched Earth |last=Tran| first=Edmond|date=November 22, 2018 |work=[[Gamespot]] |access-date=November 22, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/fallout-76-review-scorched-earth/1900-6417040/ |archive-date=November 22, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> According to [[IGN]], "The rich wasteland map of ''Fallout 76'' is wasted on a mess of bugs, conflicting ideas, and monotony."<ref name="IGN">{{Cite news |url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2018/11/22/fallout-76-review |title=Fallout 76 Review |last=Tyrrel| first=Brandin|date=November 21, 2018 |work=[[IGN]] |access-date=November 21, 2018 |language=en |archive-url=https://www.ign.com/articles/2018/11/22/fallout-76-review |archive-date=November 22, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> ''[[Giant Bomb]]'' has said they will not publish a full review due to disinterest of the staff to play it enough to reach a final verdict. Editor and co-founder [[Jeff Gerstmann]] stated on their podcast "No one on staff wants to play anymore of this video game."<ref>{{cite podcast |url=https://www.giantbomb.com/shows/559-chocolate-upgrade/2970-17739|title=Giant Bombcast: 559: Chocolate Upgrade|website=Giant Bomb|publisher=Giant Bomb|host=GiantBomb.com|date=November 20, 2018}}</ref>
The game was also criticized for the complete absence of interactive human NPCs. ''GameSpot'' said that "without having any of those people present to tell their stories personally, [''Fallout 76'']'s world is limited to being little more than just an environmental exhibit with things to kill", and that "there are no strong emotional anchors to help you become truly invested...". They also wrote that quests simply exist of "long monologues and one-way directives from a person who no longer exists and you can't interact with ... your actions ultimately won't affect anyone, or the rest of the world for that matter".<ref name="Gamespot"/> PC World similarly took issue, writing "robots aren't really NPCs as much as quest dispensers ... they don't talk with you, they talk at you". Additionally, they disliked the readable terminals and holotapes: "none of it feels important or even particularly interesting" as they were "no substitute for an actual conversation".<ref name="PCWorld"/>
Further controversy surrounding ''Fallout 76'' arose upon the release of the game's Power Armor special edition. Bethesda advertised that the edition would include a canvas [[duffel bag]], but a [[nylon]] one was included instead. Responding to customer complaints, Bethesda revealed that the bag had to be changed due to unavailability of materials. The publisher received criticism for not making the change known beforehand, with ''Eurogamer'' pointing out that the bag's description on Bethesda's website had only changed to read "nylon" after complaints had been submitted. Bethesda later offered affected customers free in-game currency as compensation, equating to $5.00.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kent |first1=Emma |title=Bethesda offers 500 Atoms to customers affected by Fallout 76 bag-gate |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-11-29-bethesda-pledges-500-atoms-to-customers-affected-by-fallout-76-bag-gate |website=Eurogamer |accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Plunkett |first1=Luke |title=$200 Fallout 76 Edition Promised Fancy Bag, Delivers Nylon Trash Instead [Update: Bethesda Responds] |url=https://kotaku.com/200-fallout-76-edition-promised-fancy-bag-delivers-ny-1830724582 |website=Kotaku |accessdate=30 November 2018}}</ref> Additionally, it has been discovered that Bethesda had given a different canvas bag to online influencers, further adding fan outrage.<ref>https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-12-01-turns-out-bethesda-did-make-fallout-76-canvas-bags-and-gave-them-out-to-influencers</ref>
===Sales=== Upon launch, ''Fallout 76'' debuted at third place in the UK's all-format sales charts, behind ''[[Spyro Reignited Trilogy]]'' and ''[[Red Dead Redemption 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Phillips |first1=Tom |title=Spyro sold more physical copies at launch than Fallout 76 |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-11-19-spyro-sold-more-physical-copies-at-launch-than-fallout-76 |website=Eurogamer |publisher=Gamer Network |accessdate=November 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181119141527/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-11-19-spyro-sold-more-physical-copies-at-launch-than-fallout-76# |archive-date=November 19, 2018 |dead-url=no }}</ref> The game saw a price drop in North America less than one week after its initial release, with some pundits listing poor sales as a reason for the cut in price.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tassi |first1=Paul |title=After A Historically Bad Launch, Is 'Fallout 76' Worth Saving? |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/insertcoin/2018/11/23/after-a-historically-bad-launch-is-fallout-76-worth-saving/#28a6f3a8320f |website=Forbes |publisher=Forbes |accessdate=November 23, 2018 |archive-url=|dead-url=no }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Advert|date=December 2014}}
'''Future Cinema''' is a London-based events company specialising in the creation of immersive and social cinema experiences as an alternative to the multiplex.<ref>{{cite news|last=Aspden|first=Peter|title=Way, way beyond the multiplex|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/394d4c04-ce3c-11e0-99ec-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1pwc6qSay|accessdate=23 March 2012|newspaper=The Financial TImes|date=August 26, 2011}}</ref>
== Background == Conceived in 2005, Future Cinema set out to share a cinematic experience by staging large cinema screenings that incorporate aspects of immersive events. Founder of Future Cinema Fabien Riggall described the idea behind Future Cinema as, "creating an immersive experience in which the audience becomes part of the narrative. It's about creating a social cinema experience where the audience can connect with each other online and at the event."<ref>{{cite web |title=Future Cinema to turn Canary Wharf into California |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-08/25/future-cinema |work=Wired.co.uk |accessdate=23 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120318051904/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-08/25/future-cinema |archivedate=18 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
It has been suggested that the popularity of alternative cinema experiences in general is due to the banality of the multiplex cinema experience.<ref>{{cite news|last=Aspden|first=Peter|title=Way, way beyond the multiplex|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/394d4c04-ce3c-11e0-99ec-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1pwc6qSay|accessdate=23 March 2012|newspaper=The Financial TImes|date=August 26, 2011}}</ref>
== Subsidiaries == Future Cinema as an umbrella brand comprises several subsidiary brands that deliver live, immersive cinema experiences worldwide. Future Cinema's online community is continuously growing and to date encompasses 350,000 Facebook and Twitter followers who are highly engaged with all brands.
=== Secret Cinema === In 2007, [[Secret Cinema (events company)|Secret Cinema]] pioneered the form ‘Live Cinema’ by introducing site-specific, immersive cultural experiences. Breaking films – and recently music albums – into their constituent parts and marrying narratives with play-along action, Secret Cinema is a unique participatory social experience. Fuelled by a desire to fill the void left by an over-saturated technological world, it invites audiences to lose themselves in serendipitous, imaginary environments that challenge the way we perceive culture and social interaction. The first event was a screening of Gus Van Sant's classic ''[[Paranoid Park (film)|Paranoid Park]]'' which screened at Southwark Playhouse in London.<ref>{{cite web |title=Behind the scenes of Secret Cinema |url=http://www.timeout.com/film/features/show-feature/11439/Exclusive-Behind_the_scenes_of_Secret_Cinema.html |work=Time Out |accessdate=21 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326044916/http://www.timeout.com/film/features/show-feature/11439/Exclusive-Behind_the_scenes_of_Secret_Cinema.html |archivedate=26 March 2012 |df= }}</ref> Recent screenings include ''[[The Third Man]]'' in 2011, ''[[Prometheus (2012 film)|Prometheus (film)]]'' in 2012 and Terry Gilliam's ''[[Brazil (1985 film)]]'' in 2013. Making use of abandoned or disused buildings, Secret Cinema explores narratives as well as space in its productions.
=== Future Shorts === [[Future Shorts]] is a short film label founded in 2003 to create a platform for new filmmakers to showcase their work. As well as hosting a monthly short film festival, Future Shorts created an online community that screens short films by filmmakers from all over the world. Anyone, anywhere can get involved in hosting their own short film event by signing up on the website.<ref>{{cite web|title=Future Shorts Website|url=http://www.futureshorts.com}}</ref> In 2013, Future Shorts are screened on 6 continents, in 90 countries and over 300 cities worldwide, including Azerbaijan, Bulgaria, Cambodia, Greece, Lebanon, Mexico, Palestine, Scotland, South Korea and Vietnam.
=== The Other Cinema === The Other Cinema is a global network of pop up cinemas that aims to bring back a sense of community and a social experience to cinema-going. For its launch, The Other Cinema screened [[David Lean]]’s ''[[Brief Encounter]]'' on [[Valentines Day]] 2012 which was held at The Troxy in the East End of London. Audiences were encouraged to dress in black-tie and to carry a flower for a lover or a stranger.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Other Cinema Presents 'Brief Encounter'|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/news/the-other-cinema-presents-brief-encounter|work=clashmusic.com|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref> Creator and Founder of Future Cinema Fabien Riggall described the intention of The Other Cinema, "to bring back the idea of local cinema and allow the most important films both old and new to get seen and talked about.”<ref>{{cite web|title=The Other Cinema Screens Brief Encounter|url=http://londonist.com/2012/01/ticket-alert-the-other-cinema-screens-brief-encounter.php|work=londonist.com|accessdate=22 March 2012}}</ref>
=== Secret Screenings === Secret Screenings is a new film club happening bringing back mystery films to the UK for one night only. Focussing on the sense of community, discovery and collective experience to cinema, it gives audiences access to incredible unseen films combined with one of a kind unforgettable experiences. Secret Screenings re-launched in July 2012 with one of the most remarkable unseen films of the year – [[Searching for Sugarman]] followed by an incredible performance by the subject of the film - Rodriguez - and continued its success with the screening on Bart Layton's [[The Imposter (2012 film)|The Imposter]] in August 2012.
=== Secret Restaurant === The latest project from Future Cinema, Secret Restaurant was launched in conjunction with St John, a Michelin Star Restaurant, for Secret Cinema's run of ''[[The Third Man]]''. Originally started as part of Secret Cinema, there are plans to expand Secret Restaurant into other artistic fields.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fine dining discovers its 'Fight Club' side|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/news/fine-dining-discovers-its-fight-club-side-6286743.html|accessdate=21 March 2012|newspaper=The Independent|date=8 January 2012}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{redirect|Golden Raspberry|the fruit|Raspberry}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox award | name = Golden Raspberry Award | current_awards = | image = Golden Raspberry Award.jpg | imagesize = 200x175px | caption = The Golden Raspberry Award statuette. | description = Failure in cinematic achievements | presenter = Golden Raspberry Award Foundation | country = United States | year = March 31, 1981 | website = [http://www.razzies.com/ razzies.com] }} The '''Golden Raspberry Awards''' (also known in short terms as '''Razzies''' and '''Razzie Awards''') is a [[Booby prize|mock award]] in recognition of the [[List of films considered the worst|worst in film]]. Co-founded by UCLA film graduates and film industry veterans [[John J. B. Wilson]] and Mo Murphy, the annual Razzie Awards ceremony in Los Angeles precedes the corresponding [[Academy Awards]] ceremony by one day. The term ''[[wikt:raspberry|raspberry]]'' in the name is used in its irreverent sense, as in "[[blowing a raspberry]]". The awards themselves are in the form of a "golf ball-sized raspberry" atop a [[Super 8 mm film]] reel, all spray painted gold. The [[1st Golden Raspberry Awards|first Golden Raspberry Awards]] ceremony was held on March 31, 1981, at [[John J. B. Wilson]]'s living-room alcove in Los Angeles, to honor the worst in film of the [[1980 in film|1980 film season]]. The [[38th Golden Raspberry Awards|38th ceremony]] was held on March 3, 2018. ==History== [[File:John Wilson at 29th Razzie Awards.jpg|thumb|left|[[John J. B. Wilson]] at the [[29th Golden Raspberry Awards]] in 2009.]] American [[publicist]] [[John J. B. Wilson]] traditionally held [[potluck|potluck parties]] at his house in Los Angeles on the night of the [[Academy Award]]s.{{cite news | last =Lindrea | first =Victoria | title =Blowing raspberries at Tinseltown |work=BBC News |publisher=BBC | date =February 25, 2007 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6392701.stm | accessdate = 2009-05-04 }} In 1981, after the [[53rd Academy Awards]] had completed for the evening, Wilson invited friends to give random award presentations in his living room.{{cite news | last =Larsen | first =Peter | title =The Morning Read – So bad, they're almost good – A love of movies lies behind the Razzies | work =[[The Orange County Register]] | page =1 | date = January 20, 2005 }} Wilson decided to formalize the event, after watching a double feature of ''[[Can't Stop the Music]]'' and ''[[Xanadu (film)|Xanadu]]''.{{cite news | last =Germain | first =David ([[Associated Press]]) | title =25 Years of Razzing Hollywood's Stinkers | work =[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]] | page =7D | publisher =Sun-Sentinel Company | date =February 26, 2005 }} He gave them ballots to vote on worst in film. Wilson stood at a podium made of cardboard in a tacky tuxedo, with a foam ball attached to a broomstick as a fake microphone, and announced ''Can't Stop the Music'' as the first [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture]]. The impromptu ceremony was a success and the following week a press release about his event released by Wilson was picked up by a few local newspapers, including a mention in the ''[[Los Angeles Daily News]]'' with the headline: "Take These Envelopes, Please".{{cite news | last =Marder | first =Jenny | title =Razzin' The Dregs of Hollywood Dreck – Film: Cerritos' John Wilson Marks His Golden Raspberry Awards' 25th Year With A Guide To Cinematic Slumming | work =[[Long Beach Press-Telegram]] | page =A1 | date =February 26, 2005 }} Approximately three dozen people came to the [[1st Golden Raspberry Awards]]. The [[2nd Golden Raspberry Awards]] had double the attendance as the first, and the [[3rd Golden Raspberry Awards|3rd awards ceremony]] in turn, had double this number. By the [[4th Golden Raspberry Awards]] ceremony, [[CNN]] and two major wire services covered the event. Wilson realized that by scheduling the Golden Raspberry Awards before the Academy Awards, the ceremony would get more press coverage: "We finally figured out you couldn't compete with the Oscars on Oscar night, but if you went the night before, when the press from all over the world are here and they are looking for something to do, it could well catch on," he said to [[BBC News]]. The term ''raspberry'' is used in its irreverent sense, as in "[[blowing a raspberry]]".{{cite book | last =Dawson | first =Jim | title =Blame it on the dog: a modern history of the fart | publisher =Ten Speed Press | year =2006 | isbn =978-1-58008-751-3|pages=48–50 }} Wilson commented to the author of ''Blame It on the Dog'': "When I registered the term with the Library of Congress in 1980, they asked me, 'Why ''raspberry''? What's the significance of that?' But since then, ''razz'' has pretty much permeated the culture. We couldn't have done it without Hollywood's help." Wilson is referred to as "Ye Olde Head Razzberry".{{cite book | last = Crouse | first = Richard | title = Reel Winners: Movie Award Trivia | publisher = Dundurn Press Ltd | year = 2005 | pages= 103, 208 | isbn =978-1-55002-574-3 }} {{-}} ==Format== Paying members of the Golden Raspberry Award Foundation vote to determine the recipients. For the [[29th Golden Raspberry Awards]] in 2009, award results were based on votes from approximately 650 journalists, cinema fans and professionals from the film industry.{{cite news | last =Marrs | first =John | title = 'They have no excuse to be as bad as they are' – The Golden Raspberry awards aren't just a refreshing antidote to the Oscars, they can help sell films too. John Marrs talks to the Razzies' founder, John Wilson|work =The Guardian | date =February 25, 2009 | url =https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/feb/24/razzies-interview-oscars | accessdate = 2009-05-06 }}{{cite news| last =Margulies| first =Lee| title =Film Industry Razzes 'Love Guru,' Paris Hilton|work=Los Angeles Times| date =February 21, 2009}} Voters hailed from 45 states in the United States and 19 other countries.{{cite news| last =Telegraph Herald staff| title =Hilton, Myers top Razzies| work =[[Telegraph Herald]]| page =A2| date =February 22, 2009}} [[File:2008 Razzie Awards 07.jpg|thumb|right|John J. B. Wilson at the [[28th Golden Raspberry Awards]] in 2008.]] [[File:Worst Supporting Actress at 29th Razzie Awards.jpg|thumb|right|220px|[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actress|Worst Supporting Actress]] at the [[29th Golden Raspberry Awards]].]] The ceremony, typically held one day before the Academy Awards, is modeled after the latter but "deliberately low-end and tacky". == Collecting in person == {{main|List of people who have accepted Golden Raspberry Awards}} Most winners do not attend the ceremony to collect their awards.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/4301783.stm|title=Berry gets worst actress Razzie|first=Helen |last=Bushby|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=BBC|date=February 27, 2005|accessdate=2009-01-19}} Notable exceptions include [[Tom Green]] (Worst Actor/Worst Director), [[Halle Berry]]{{Citation|last=Razzie Channel|title=Halle Berry accepts her RAZZIE® Award|date=2011-01-13|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U-7s_yeQuDg|accessdate=2016-05-23}} and [[Sandra Bullock]] (Worst Actress), [[John Brancato and Michael Ferris|Michael Ferris]], [[J. David Shapiro|J. D. Shapiro]] (Worst Screenplay), and [[Paul Verhoeven]] (Worst Director). ==Contradicting awards== Three people won both the Razzies and Oscars the same weekend: [[Alan Menken]] in 1993, [[Brian Helgeland]] in 1998, and Sandra Bullock in 2010, although all three for different films.{{cite web|url=http://goldderby.latimes.com/awards_goldderby/2010/01/razzie-awards-razzies-nominations-7594106284-news-story-article.html|title=Razzie Award nominations: Can Sandra Bullock win worst AND best actress?|publisher=|accessdate=6 March 2018}} Two actors had performances in the same movie scoring Oscar and Razzie nominations, [[James Coco]] (''[[Only When I Laugh (film)|Only When I Laugh]]'') and [[Amy Irving]] (''[[Yentl (film)|Yentl]]'').{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/awards/2011/01/quiz-which-role-was-nominated-for-a-razzie-and-oscar.html|title=Quiz: Which role was nominated for a Razzie and an Oscar?|date=26 January 2011|publisher=|accessdate=6 March 2018}} [[Neil Diamond]], winner of the inaugural Worst Actor Razzie for 1980s ''[[The Jazz Singer (1980 film)|The Jazz Singer]]'', was nominated for the [[Golden Globe]] in the same role. The [[Aerosmith]] song "[[I Don't Want to Miss a Thing]]", as part of the original soundtrack to the 1998 film ''[[Armageddon (1998 film)|Armageddon]]'', was nominated for both an [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]] and a [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Original Song]], as was the [[Trisha Yearwood]] song "[[How Do I Live]]" from the 1997 film ''[[Con Air]]'' and the [[Tony Bennett]] song "Life in a Looking Glass" from the 1986 film ''[[That's Life! (film)|That's Life!]]''. In 1981, [[Stanley Kubrick]] was nominated both for a Razzie Award as Worst Director at the [[1st Golden Raspberry Awards]][https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000558/1981 ''Razzie Awards for 1981] at IMDB.com as well as for a [[Saturn Award for Best Director]] at the [[8th Saturn Awards]][https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000004/1981 Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy & Horror Films, USA] on IMDB.com for the same film: ''[[The Shining (film)|''The Shining]]''. In 2017, [[Darren Aronofsky]] was nominated for both the [[Golden Lion]] and the [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Director|Worst Director]] Razzie for ''[[Mother!]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.goldderby.com/article/2018/2018-razzie-awards-mother-jennifer-lawrence-046253719/|title=Hey Razzie Awards, Why! Did! You! Nominate! 'Mother!'?|first=Daniel|last=Montgomery|date=22 January 2018|publisher=|accessdate=6 March 2018}} ''[[Wall Street (1987 film)|Wall Street]]'' (1987) is the only film to date to win both an Oscar and a Razzie. Michael Douglas won the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]],{{cite news |last=Gorney |first=Cynthia |title=Douglas and Cher Win Acting Honors |work=[[Washington Post]] |pages= |publisher= |date=April 12, 1988 |url= |accessdate= }} however [[Daryl Hannah]]'s performance was not as well received and earned her a Razzie for Worst Supporting Actress. == Categories == '''Current Awards''' *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Picture|Worst Picture]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Director|Worst Director]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actor|Worst Actor]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Actress|Worst Actress]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actor|Worst Supporting Actor]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Supporting Actress|Worst Supporting Actress]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or Sequel|Worst Prequel, Remake, Rip-off or Sequel]]: 1994 to 1995, 1997 to 1998, 2000 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screenplay|Worst Screenplay]]: 1980 to present *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screen Combo#Worst Screen Combo 2013–present|Worst Screen Combo]]: 2013 to present *[[The Razzie Redeemer Award]]: 2014 to present '''Retired''' *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Original Song|Worst Original Song]]: 1980 to 1999, 2002 *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst New Star|Worst New Star]]: 1981 to 1998, except 1989 *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Musical Score|Worst Musical Score]]: 1981 to 1985 *Worst Visual Effects: 1986 to 1987 *Worst Screen Couple: [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screen Combo#Worst Screen Couple 1994–2009|1994 to 2009]], [[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screen Combo#Worst Screen Couple 2011–2012|2011 to 2012]] *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screen Combo#Worst Screen Couple/Worst Screen Ensemble 2010|Worst Screen Couple/Worst Screen Ensemble]]: 2010 *[[Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Screen Combo#Worst Screen Ensemble 2011–2012|Worst Screen Ensemble]]: 2011 to 2012 === Special categories === Special categories have also been introduced for specific years. Such special awards include: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Category ! Winner ! Nominees |- |1996 |Worst Written Film Grossing Over $100 Million |''[[Twister (1996 film)|Twister]]''—[[Michael Crichton]] & [[Anne-Marie Martin]] |''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]''—Tab Murphy, [[Irene Mecchi]], [[Bob Tzudiker]] & [[Noni White]]
''[[Independence Day (1996 film)|Independence Day]]''—[[Dean Devlin]] & [[Roland Emmerich]]
''[[Mission: Impossible (film)|Mission: Impossible]]''—[[David Koepp]] and [[Robert Towne]]
