''[[Swept Away (2002 film)|Swept Away]]'' (2002) |} ==Other types of awards== === Worst Career Achievement === This award has been given five times, to [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1981, to [[Linda Blair]] in 1983, to [[Irwin Allen]] in 1985, to "Bruce the Rubber Shark" from ''[[Jaws (franchise)|Jaws]]''[http://razzies.com/asp/content/XcNewsPlus.asp?cmd=view&articleid=14 Razzies.com], visited 2007-04-30. in 1987, and to director [[Uwe Boll]]{{cite web |url=http://www.razzies.com/history/08NomCA.asp |title=Razzies 2008 Nominees for Worst Career Achievement |author=John Wilson |date=January 21, 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-22 |authorlink=John Wilson (Golden Raspberry)}} in 2009 who received this for his achievement as "Germany's answer to [[Ed Wood]]". === Governor's Award === This is a special award given by Razzie Award Governor [[John J. B. Wilson]] to an individual whose achievements are not covered by the Razzies' other categories. It was awarded in 2003 to [[Travis Payne]] for "Distinguished Under-Achievement in Choreography" in the film ''[[From Justin to Kelly]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.razzies.com/asp/24thAwards.htm?cmd=view|title=Razzies.com - Home of the Golden Raspberry Award Foundation|website=razzies.com|access-date=22 January 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313023819/http://www.razzies.com/asp/24thAwards.htm?cmd=view|archive-date=13 March 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} === Barry L. Bumstead Award === This award is given to a critical and financial failure that would've been nominated if it had received an eligible release. It was awarded in 2016 to ''[[United Passions]],''{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/razzie-awards-mock-fifty-shades-870615|title=Razzie Awards Mock 'Fifty Shades of Grey,' Redeem Sylvester Stallone|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-02-24|language=en}}{{Citation|last=Razzie Channel|title=36th Razzie's - Barry L Bumstead Award Goes To…United Passions!|date=2016-04-20|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nl_u_re1-Y0&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-02-24}} to ''[[Misconduct (film)|Misconduct]]'' in 2017,{{cite web|last1=Heller|first1=Corrine|title=Razzies 2017 Winners Announced: Batman v Superman "Loses" Worst Picture But Still "Wins" Big|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/831927/razzies-2017-winners-announced-batman-v-superman-loses-worst-picture-but-still-wins-big|website=E Online|publisher=E!|accessdate=25 February 2017}} and in 2018 to ''[[CHiPs (film)|CHiPs]]''.{{Cite journal|date=2018-03-05|title=38th Golden Raspberry Awards|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=38th_Golden_Raspberry_Awards&oldid=828875936|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}} == Criticism == The Razzies have received criticism, including from news sources such as ''[[Indiewire]]''{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/criticwire/why-the-razzies-are-the-worst-awards-ever-20150105|title=Why the Razzies Are the Worst Awards Ever|author=Sam Adams|date=5 January 2015|website=Criticwire}} and ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'',{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/10669966/Why-I-hate-the-Razzies.html|title=Why I hate the Razzies|date=1 March 2016|website=Telegraph.co.uk}} for several issues, including that members of the Golden Raspberry Foundation are not required to watch the nominated movies, and that seemingly anyone can join the Golden Raspberry Foundation, so long as they pay at least $40, which is different from the invitation-only [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/about/become-new-member|title=HOW TO BECOME A MEMBER|website=Oscars.org - Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences}} Critics take issue with the Razzies picking "easy targets" and mainstream films instead of those perceived as less popular but more deserving productions,{{cite web|url=http://www.craveonline.com/entertainment/942899-easy-targets-razzies-pick-year#LWWkuOBHDvy3xX32.99|title=Which Easy Targets Did The Razzies Pick This Year? - CraveOnline|date=13 January 2016|publisher=|accessdate=31 October 2016}} continuing to appeal to celebrities, seemingly for publicity and attention, over other, worthier films and performances. Sam Adams of ''Indiewire'' has said the Razzies are "like hecklers hurling insults at comedians or a concertgoer yelling out 'Whoo!' during a quiet song, they're not-so-secretly crying out to be noticed. The Razzies, properly enough, avoid pouncing on the little guy; they don't trash no-budget indies no one has seen for having bad lighting or terrible sound". Robbie Collin of ''The Daily Telegraph'' has said "the Razzies' ongoing failure to train its sights on anything but the most obvious targets means it grows more tired and redundant by the year". [[CraveOnline]]'s William Bibbiani stated that the Razzies follow "a cheap shot of pranksterism", and "with only a handful of exceptions, only seen fit to nominate the most infamous movies of the year, and not necessarily the worst." Carolyn Burke of [[Cracked.com]] describes the awards as "a ramshackle operation run by a bunch of lazy [[Internet troll|trolls]] who are guilty of all the same smug self-importance they claim to be lampooning" and further states that "the Razzies are an antiquated 'joke' that has long outlived any goodwill or relevance they once had, and have become nothing more than a mean-spirited cesspool of joyless criticism worse than any of the movies they tear down with artless comedy."{{cite web|url=http://www.cracked.com/article_24629_4-reasons-razzies-suck-even-more-than-oscars.html|title=4 Reasons The Razzies Suck (And Should Be Abolished Forever)|date=22 February 2017|author=Carolyn Burke|accessdate=13 May 2017|website=Cracked.com}} ==See also== {{Portal|Film}} * [[Academy Awards]] * [[Stinkers Bad Movie Awards]] * ''[[The Golden Turkey Awards]]'' * [[List of films considered the worst]] * [[List of people who have accepted Golden Raspberry Awards]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Golden Raspberry Awards}} {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.razzies.com Golden Raspberry Official Website] * [https://www.imdb.com/event/ev0000558/overview/ Razzie Awards] page on the [[Internet Movie Database]] * [https://www.youtube.com/razziechannel Razzie channel on YouTube] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120221214230/http://www.razzies.com/forum/alltime-razzie-champeens-list_topic5372.html All Time Razzie Champions List] * [http://triviatoday.fyi/trivia/which-actress-won-an-oscar-and-a-razzie-in-the-same-year/ Which actress won an Oscar and a Razzie in the same year?] {{Golden Raspberry Award Years}} [[Category:Golden Raspberry Awards| ]] [[Category:American film awards]] [[Category:Lists of worsts]] [[Category:Awards established in 1981]] [[Category:Ironic and humorous awards]]

{{multiple issues| {{notability|1=Music|date=February 2018}} {{prose|date=March 2018}} {{Update|[[Grey Poupon in music#Songs that mention Grey Poupon|Songs that mention Grey Poupon]]|date=December 2017}} }} The mustard brand [[Grey Poupon]] has been referred to in numerous songs.
== Background == [[Name-dropping]] Grey Poupon dates back to the 1980s.<ref name=Huff /> Before 1981, ads of Grey Poupon were only in print magazines such as ''[[Food & Wine]]'' and ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]''. But in 1981, [[Heublein]] decided to reach out to a new audience;<ref name=VOX /> they published a [[Advertisement film|TV commercial]] in which one seemingly wealthy man asks the other, “Pardon me, would you have any Grey Poupon?”<ref name=Huff /> “From then on, Grey Poupon became the condiment of choice for rappers who wanted an easy rhyme that also illustrated the idea of status, luxury, and class,” say [[Vox (website)|Vox]]{{’s}} Estelle Caswell and Sarah Frostenson.<ref name=Huff>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/rappers-grey-poupon-hip-hop-lyrics_us_5800f933e4b0162c043b8009 |title=Here’s Why Rappers Are So Obsessed With Grey Poupon |work=HuffPost |date=October 14, 2016 |access-date=December 5, 2017 |last=Cave |first=James}}</ref>
== Songs that mention Grey Poupon == === 1990s === <!-- When adding a song to list, please include its date of release and a reference --> * "East Coast" by [[Das EFX]] (1992): "He's the Don, have you seen my Grey Poupon? / Bust this, we roll more spliffs than Cheech and Chong"<ref name=VOX>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/videos/2016/10/12/13250360/grey-poupon-in-hip-hop |title=How Grey Poupon became hip-hop’s favorite condiment |work=Vox |date=October 12, 2016 |access-date=December 5, 2017 |last1=Caswell |first1=Estelle |last2=Frostenson |first2=Sarah}}</ref> * "Pimps (Free Stylin at the Fortune 500 Club)" by [[The Coup]] (1994): "Fuck naw, I ain't got no Grey Poupon / Well, anyway, I said, "That's no burglar! That's my butler." / Mr. Rockefeller, let me in on the gossip / I heard you and Mr. Getty are getting into rap music or something"<ref name=VOX /> * "Brooklyn Style...Laid Out" by [[Big Daddy Kane]] (1994): "What type of mission can I say you on? / Because you musta done changed to some Grey Poupon, heh"<ref name=VOX /> * "[[Eat the Rich (Aerosmith song)|Eat the Rich]]" by [[Aerosmith]] (1994): "I believe in rags to riches / Your inheritance won't last / So take your Grey Poupon, my friend / And shove it up your ass"<ref name=VOX /> * "Sandman 118 Freestyle" by [[Big L]] (1995): "Front and get your belly torn, I keep a Pelle on I'm fucking with Grey Poupon and Dom Pérignon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Cashmere Thoughts" by [[Jay Z]] (1996): "I got the Grey Poupon, you been warned / 'Cause all beef return well-done filet mignon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Assassination Day" by [[Ghostface Killah]] (1996): "First of all, before we move on, this shit is like a Yukon, don / Spread it out like Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Fish" by Ghostface Killah (1996): "My triple sevens broke the slot machines out in Queens / Grey Poupon is Revlon rap, smack pawns, swing like batons"<ref name=VOX /> * "Emotions" by [[Twista]] (1997): "You insist to be trippin' while we be gamin' like Don Juan / What up the filet mignon, the Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "We Could Take It Outside" by [[Busta Rhymes]] featuring [[Flipmode Squad]] (1997): "I be burnin' MCs like Betty's grandson / Smokin Grey Poupon, boy / Two lines, I chew rhymes and make n----- fall like they was futons"<ref name=VOX /> * "Boomerang Slang" by [[Elzhi]] (1998): "I try not to do wrong / But I want to be in that limo askin' for the Grey Poupon / for a change / I'm sick of saving change from a coupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "The Right One" by [[John Forté]] featuring [[Pras]] (1998): "Toe - toes, with my brother / Pass the Grey Poupon / Hoe cronies, I don't know what the fuck y'all on"<ref name=VOX /> * "Rap Life" by [[Tash (rapper)|Tash]] featuring [[Raekwon]] (1999): "First of all, before we move on / It's like a Yukon, son / Slide this on like Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Sexy Dancer" by [[Ideal (group)|Ideal]] featuring [[Jazze Pha]] (1999): "Make that ass spread like some Grey Poupon / What level you on and can I get a coochie coupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Hold Your Ground" by [[The Ambassador (rapper)|The Ambassador]] (1999): "So days are grey like Poupon / Full of pain like a toe with two corns with small shoes on"<ref name=VOX />
=== 2000s === * "Throw Them 3's (Boston Niggaz)" by [[Benzino]] (2001): "My nine stars spread bullets like Grey Poupon / I'm tryin to ice on my wrist and on my arm"<ref name=VOX /> * "Filling Space" by [[Scarub]] (2001): "But they still deny you relish / That shit is still pickles / They just gone like Grey Poupon / Acting all stingy with the mayo"<ref name=VOX /> * "Funkin' Around" by [[Outkast]] (2002): "See, we ain't even seen, the mountaintop counter clock / Wise goes the neighborhood hand-me-downs and canned goods / Won't cut the Grey Poupon we got that make you run"<ref name=VOX /> * "Tonight I'm Gonna Let Go (Remix)" by [[Syleena Johnson]] featuring Flipmode Squad (2002): "Get you in the mood, throw them slow grooves on / Spread you on a futon like Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Raedawn" by [[Viktor Vaughn]] (2003): "Soup's on! / And I got a coupon / Chinese restaurant asking for the Grey Poupon / He said, "No! Duck sauce, soy sauce! / And this ain't no Burger King, so you don't get no toy, boss"<ref name=VOX /> * "[[Genius in France]]" by [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] (2003): "Say, would you pass the Grey Poupon? / Merci beaucoup"<ref name=VOX /> * "Firewater" by Baby Blak (2003): "You Burger King, I'm filet mignon / So where the beef? / You mayo (Hah) / I'm Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "That's Wusup" by [[Mac Dre]] (2004): "No shrimp, Dre eat prawns / And do you have any Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "Nevehoe" by [[Anybody Killa]] (2004): "See, I'm being tryin' to speak on / While you sit back and see me as a jar of Grey Poupon"<ref name=VOX /> * "69th Chamber Intercourse" by [[Phonte]] (2005): "The power grocery n-----, flagrant wit asparagus / Stars wit the jewels on / I eat 'em up like Grey Poupon, my lil' cousin needs"<ref name=VOX /> * "[[Harlem: Diary of a Summer|We Just Ballin']]" by [[Jim Jones (rapper)|Jim Jones]] featuring T.K. (2005): "I keep 20 in the pocket (Light Change) / Talk a buck 80 if the Bentley is the topic (That Grey Poupon)"<ref name=VOX /> * "Gwap Nigga" by [[Ray Cash]] (2007): "Need a fuckin' bread truck, y'all can eat the croutons / What you know about a turkey sandwich with Grey Poupon?" * "I Want This Forever" by [[Lil Wayne]] (2007): "What are you on? I'm richer than a bitch without the Grey Poupon"
=== 2010s === * "Food Fight On the Moon!" by [[The Aquabats!]] (2011): "Fo' sho' it's on / Spaghetti-Os and Grey Poupon" * "Hello" by [[Iggy Azalea]] (2011): "I'm gettin' to this bread / Where's the Grey Poupon?" * "In the Stars" by [[Juicy J]] (2013): "Pass that Grey Poupon, rich n-gga talk" * "Facts (Charlie Heat Version)" by [[Kanye West]] (2016): "Yeezy, Yeezy, Yeezy, this is pure luxury / I give 'em Grey Poupon on a DJ Mustard, ah!"<ref name=VOX /> * "Aerosol Can" by [[Major Lazer]] (2014): "No discounts, no coupons / But I got the Rolls Royce for the Grey Poupon" * "Dance Off" by [[Macklemore & Ryan Lewis]] (2016): "You must hurt like Grey Poupon, Swag on tap like Savion" * "[[Humble (song)|Humble]]" by [[Kendrick Lamar]] (2017): "This that Grey Poupon, that Evian, that TED Talk / Watch my soul speak, you let the meds talk / If I kill a nigga, it won't be the alcohol / I'm the realest nigga after all"<ref name=XXL>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xxlmag.com/news/2017/09/hip-hop-lyrics-grey-poupon/ |title=20 HIP-HOP LYRICS SHOWING LOVE TO GREY POUPON |work=XXL Magazine |date=September 12, 2017 |access-date=December 5, 2017 |author=Preezy}}</ref> * "ALASKA" by [[Brockhampton (band)|Brockhampton]] (2017): "We left the corner store on the way to caviar / The coupe is mustard colored, what the f-ck is Grey Poupon?"

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2016}}'''Guignol''' ({{IPA-fr|ɡiɲɔl|lang}}) is the main character in a French [[Puppetry|puppet show]] which has come to bear his name. It represents the workers in the silk industry of France.
Although often thought of as children's entertainment, Guignol's sharp wit and linguistic verve have always been appreciated by adults as well, as shown by the motto of a prominent [[Lyon]] troupe: "Guignol amuses children… and witty adults".
[[Image:Guignol.jpg|thumb|300px|right|A Guignol show being performed in Paris.]] [[File:Guignol de Lyon.JPG|thumb|Flageolet (left), Guignol (right)]] [[Laurent Mourguet]], Guignol's creator, was born into a family of modest silk weavers on March 3, 1769. The certificate of his marriage to Jeanne Esterle in 1788 shows he was unable to read. When hard times fell on the silk trade during the French Revolution, he became a peddler, and in 1797 started to practice [[dentistry]], which in those days was simply the pulling of teeth. The service was free; the money was made from the medicines sold afterward to ease the pain. To attract patients, he started setting up a puppet show in front of his dentist's chair. In the end, his strategy worked very well to his advantage.
His first shows featured [[Pulcinella|Polichinelle]], a character borrowed from the Italian [[commedia dell'arte]] who in England would become [[Punch and Judy|Punch]]. By 1804 the success was such that he gave up dentistry altogether and became a professional puppeteer, creating his own scenarios drawing on the concerns of his working-class audience and improvising references to the news of the day. He developed characters closer to the daily lives of his Lyon audience, first Gnafron, a wine-loving cobbler, and in 1808 Guignol. Other characters, including Guignol's wife Madelon and the [[Gendarmerie|gendarme]] Flageolet soon followed, but these are never much more than foils for the two heroes.
Although nominally a silkweaver like much of his original audience, Guignol's profession changes, as does his marital status; he can be in turn valet, peddler, carpenter, shoemaker, or unemployed; at times he is Madelon's husband, at times her smitten suitor according to requirements of the scenario. What remain constant are his poverty, but more importantly his good humor and his sense of justice. The use in French of "guignol" as an insult meaning "buffoon" is a curious misnomer, as Guignol is clever, courageous and generous; his inevitable victory is always the triumph of good over evil.
Sixteen of Mourguet's children and grandchildren continued his tradition, and many of the companies performing today can trace their artistic heritage back to him although Laurent Morguet´s last descendant - Jean-Guy Morguet - died October 8, 2012, at the age of 82, after working all his life in the Theatre de Guignol at Lyon, France. Jean-Guy, learnt his job helping his grandmother Augustine and then his parents. He became, later, the director of the whole theatre until his death. Laurent Mourguet maintained according to the era, the region, or the performers. Guignol's original caustic satire has often been watered down to simple children's fare, and has even been used to parody grand opera, but his original spirit still survives in his hometown of Lyon, where both traditional and original contemporary performances are an integral part of local culture. In addition to his social satire, Guignol has become an important protector of the local dialect, the ''parler lyonnais''.

revision.comment: publication details for Honey West: Honey for Hire (2014) as sourced
revision.text:
{{Infobox character | name = Honey West | first = ''This Girl for Hire'' (1957) | most_recent = ''Stiff as a Board'' (1972) | gender = Female | order= | term_start= | term_end= | occupation = [[private detective]] | religion = | party = | spouse = | children = | portrayer = [[Anne Francis]] | creator = G.G. Fickling }} '''Honey West''' is a fictional character created by the husband and wife writing team Gloria and Forest Fickling under the [[pseudonym]] "G.G. Fickling", and appearing in eleven [[Mystery fiction|mystery]] novels by the duo.
The character is notable as being one of the first female [[private detectives]] in popular fiction. She first appeared in the 1957 book ''This Girl for Hire'' and would appear in nine novels before being retired in the mid-1960s, with two comeback novels in 1971.<ref>Barnett, Colleen ''Mystery Women: An Encyclopedia of Leading Women Characters in Mystery Fiction, Volume 1: 1860-1979'' Poisoned Pen Press, 2006</ref>
==Creation== The Honey West character was created by Gloria and Forrest E. "Skip" Fickling under the [[pseudonym]] "G.G. Fickling" in the late 1950s.
Forrest Fickling had been a [[United States Army Air Forces]] [[Air Gunner]] during [[World War II]]; he enlisted in the [[U.S. Marine Corps]] Reserve after the war, and as a member of that service was called back to active duty during the [[Korean War]].<ref>http://www.mysteryfile.com/Honey%20West/Honey_West.html</ref> The G.G. represented the initials of his wife, Gloria Gautraud, whom he had married in 1949. The initials were used so the sex of the author would remain vague. Though Gloria said that most of the writing was done by Forrest, he said her ideas helped make the female character more plausible and gave her a good dress sense. Gloria had been an assistant fashion editor at [[Look (American magazine)|''Look'' magazine]] and a fashion writer for ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]''. Forrest told the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', "I first thought of [[Marilyn Monroe]], and then I thought of [fictional detective] [[Mike Hammer]] and decided to put the two together... We thought the most used name for someone you really like is Honey. And she lives in the West, so there was her name."<ref>Obituary, Los Angeles Times http://articles.latimes.com/1998/apr/11/local/me-38189</ref>
==Prose==
===Novels=== *''This Girl for Hire'' (1957) *''Girl on the Loose'' (1958) *''A Gun for Honey'' (1958) *''Honey in the Flesh'' (1959) *''Girl on the Prowl'' (1959) *''Kiss for a Killer'' (1960) *''Dig a Dead Doll'' (1960) *''Blood and Honey'' (1961) *''Bombshell'' (1964) *''Honey on her Tail'' (1971) *''Stiff as a Broad'' (1972)
===Short story=== *"The Red Hairing" in ''Mike Shayne Mystery Magazine'' (June 1965)
===Authorized Works by Other Writers===
===Novels=== *''A Girl and Her Cat'' by [[Win Scott Eckert]] and Matthew Baugh (2014)
===Short stories=== *"Seer Sucker" by [[Will Murray]] in ''Honey West Commemorative Edition'' (2011)
*''Honey West: Honey for Hire'' by [[Joe Gentile]], Fernando Ferreiro, [[Ed Gorman (writer)|Ed Gorman]], [[Mel Odom (author)|Mel Odom]], Will Murray, [[Trina Robbins]], [[C. J. Henderson]], Mike Black, ed. [[Nancy Holder]] (2014)<ref>https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Honey_West.html?id=pybsnQEACAAJ&redir_esc=y</ref> **"Bruce" **"Faith" **"Naked Truth" **"Most Dangerous Honeys" **"Cat's Paw in Heat" **"Number One with a Bullet" **"The Education of Honey West" **"Thunder Kiss"
==Other media==
===Television series=== {{main|Honey West (TV series)}} The character was also the basis for a short-lived [[American Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] TV series in the 1965-66 television season starring [[Anne Francis]] and [[John Ericson]]. There were 30 episodes. The series was executive produced by [[Aaron Spelling]].
===Comics=== [[Gold Key Comics]] released a one-shot Honey West comic book in June 1966. In August 2010, [[Moonstone Books]] began a ''Honey West'' comic book series, written by [[Trina Robbins]] with art by [[Cynthia Martin]].<ref>http://moonstonebooks.com/shop/category.aspx?catid=31</ref> Other writers include [[Elaine Lee]] and [[Ronn Sutton]]. It lasted 19 issues. After which, there were two limited installments, the single issue ''Honey West and Kolchak'' (2013), and two issues for ''Honey West and The Cat'' (2013).
===Audio=== In 2011, the [[AudioComics Company]] announced plans to adapt Elaine Lee and Ronn Sutton's three-part miniseries ''Murder on Mars'' as a full-cast audio drama, in conjunction with Moonstone Books. Starring audio book narrator [[Carrington MacDuffie]] as Honey, the adaptation was released on compact disc and [[music download|digital download]] in April 2012.
===Proposed film=== At various times a proposed film with [[Reese Witherspoon]] as Honey West was mentioned, but never made.<ref>http://www.cinemaretro.com/index.php?/archives/183-HONEY-WEST-HEADED-TO-THE-BIG-SCREEN.html</ref>
==See also== *[[List of female action heroes]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *Frederickson, John C. ''Honey West'' BearManor Media (June 1, 2009) *{{cite web|url=http://www.comicsbulletin.com/reviews/129991767964301.htm|title=Honey West #3 Review - Line of Fire Reviews - Comics Bulletin|author=Jason Brice|publisher=Comicsbulletin.com|accessdate=19 December 2014}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|title=Honey West|id=0058814}} *[http://www.museum.tv/archives/etv/H/htmlH/honeywest/honeywest.htm Museum of Broadcast Communications] *[http://www.thrillingdetective.com/honey.html Honey West] at Thrilling Detective.com *[http://www.originalhoneywest.com Official Honey West Movie Website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:West, Honey}} [[Category:Fictional detectives]] [[Category:Novel series]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1957]] [[Category:Characters in American novels of the 20th century]] [[Category:Television characters]]
[[fr:Honey West]]

{{Infobox film | name = Insidious: Chapter 3 | image = Insidious – Chapter 3 (film poster).png | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Leigh Whannell]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Jason Blum]] * [[Oren Peli]] * [[James Wan]] }} | writer = Leigh Whannell | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Dermot Mulroney]] * [[Stefanie Scott]] * [[Angus Sampson]] * Leigh Whannell * [[Lin Shaye]] }} | music = [[Joseph Bishara]] | cinematography = Brian Pearson | editing = Timothy Alverson | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Blumhouse Productions]]<ref name=thr/> * [[Entertainment One]]<ref name=thr/> * [[Stage 6 Films]]<ref name=thr/> }} | distributor = [[Focus Features]]<ref name="deadline1"/> | released = {{Film date|2015|06|05}} | runtime = 98 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 97:30--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/insidious-chapter-3-film | title=''INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 3'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=May 1, 2015 | accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> | country = {{Plainlist| * United States<ref name=bfi>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/5589dd4bd9e8e|title=Insidious Chapter 3 (2015)|work=[[British Film Institute]]|accessdate=May 27, 2017}}</ref> * Canada<ref name=bfi/> * United Kingdom<ref name=bfi/> }} | language = English | budget = $11 million<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.filmla.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/2015_film_study_v5_WEB.pdf|last=FilmL.A.|date=June 15, 2016|work=|accessdate=May 8, 2018|via=}}</ref> | gross = $113 million<ref name=BOM /> }} '''''Insidious: Chapter 3''''' is a 2015 [[supernatural horror film]] written and directed by [[Leigh Whannell]] in his [[List of directorial debuts|directorial debut]]. It is a [[prequel]] to the first two films and the third installment in the [[Insidious (film series)|''Insidious'' franchise]]. The film stars [[Dermot Mulroney]] and [[Stefanie Scott]], with [[Angus Sampson]], Whannell, and [[Lin Shaye]] reprising their roles from the previous films. The film was released on June 5, 2015, received mixed reviews and grossed $113 million against a budget of $11 million.
==Plot== <!-- Please see WP:FILMPLOT for more information. The word count for a plot summary is between 400 and 700 words. --> Several years before [[Insidious (film)|the Lambert haunting]], teenager Quinn Brenner meets with retired [[demonology|demonologist]] Elise Rainier. Elise reluctantly agrees to try and contact the spirit of Quinn's mother, Lillith, who died one year prior. However, Elise urges Quinn not to try and contact her mother again after sensing a malevolent force. After auditioning for a school for the performing arts, Quinn sees a mysterious figure waving to her from the distance on the street. Distracted, she is hit by a car, having both of her legs broken in the process.
Now stuck in her home with her father Sean and brother Alex, Quinn begins to experience increasingly disturbing [[paranormal|paranormal phenomena]], including seeing visions of a dark spirit wearing an oxygen mask known as the "Man Who Can't Breathe"—the same figure that caused her accident. One of Quinn's neighbors, an elderly woman with [[dementia]] who had previously said several confusing and cryptic things to her about the "Man Who Can't Breathe", passes away.
Sean meets with Elise, whom like him is also grieving after the death of her husband Jack, and tries to convince her to help his daughter. Elise declines, stating that her previous visits to the dark spiritual world of the "Further" made her realize that an evil spirit is hunting her. However, she is convinced by her friend and former colleague Carl to continue using her spiritual ability, after he reminds her about her successful [[Insidious: Chapter 2|case involving Josh Lambert]] in 1986, and stating that she is stronger than any spirits or demons because she is living and they are not.
Due to Elise's refusal, Alex suggests Sean call on alleged demonologists Specs and Tucker, who have built a following on the [[internet]]. During their investigation, Quinn becomes briefly possessed by the "Man Who Can't Breathe," breaks through her leg braces, and attempts to attack Sean, Specs, and Tucker. Sean realizes Specs and Tucker are [[confidence trick|frauds,]] and prepares to kick the duo out until Elise arrives. Deducing that the dark spirit's goal is to lure potential victims to "the Further" so it can eat their life force, Elise decides to enter the spiritual world, and enlists Specs and Tucker to help.
Elise enters the Further and has a brief fight with the evil spirit that haunts her (a mysterious [[Insidious: Chapter 2|"Bride in Black"]]), before she discovers Jack's spirit. Jack begins to encourage Elise to commit [[suicide]] so that they might be reunited. Elise realizes that Jack is actually the "Man Who Can't Breathe" in disguise and slashes his face before escaping back to the physical world. Elise realizes that Quinn has to defeat him on her own. Though Quinn is at first at a disadvantage, Elise receives a message from Quinn's deceased neighbor: Lillith had left Quinn a letter to read before she graduated High School, but Quinn never found it. Lillith's spirit suddenly appears in the Further and helps Quinn defeat the "Man Who Can't Breathe." Elise gives parting words to the family, including words of encouragement from Lillith's spirit. She leaves with Specs and Tucker, and the three agree to form a partnership.
Later, Elise arrives home and notices her dog barking at something. Suddenly, [[Insidious (film)|a demon with a red face]] appears behind her.
==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Lin Shaye]] as Elise Rainier * [[Dermot Mulroney]] as Sean Brenner * [[Stefanie Scott]] as Quinn Brenner * [[Angus Sampson]] as Tucker * [[Leigh Whannell]] as Specs * [[Hayley Kiyoko]] as Maggie * Tate Berney as Alex Brenner * Michael Reid MacKay as "The Man Who Can't Breathe" * [[Tom Gallop]] as Dr. Henderson * Steve Coulter as Carl * Phyllis Applegate as Grace * Ashton Moio as Hector * [[Ele Keats]] as Lillith Brenner * Tom Fitzpatrick as Bride in Black / Parker Crane * Adrian Sparks as Jack Rainier * Phil Abrams as Mel * Ruben Garfias as Ernesto * [[James Wan]] as The Acting School Audition Judge * Amaris Davidson as Nurse * Garrett Ryan as Young Josh Lambert * [[Joseph Bishara]] as Lipstick-Face Demon {{div col end}}
==Production== [[File:Insidious premiere.jpg|thumb|Premiere at the [[TCL Chinese Theatre]] in [[Hollywood]] (June 4, 2015)]] On September 15, 2013, a third installment in the ''Insidious'' series was announced, with [[Leigh Whannell]] signed on to return as writer, and [[Jason Blum]] and [[Oren Peli]] set to produce.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=''INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER THREE'' Moving Forward; Leigh Whannell Returning to Write the Script|url=http://collider.com/insidious-3-sequel-leigh-whannell|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=September 16, 2013|date=September 16, 2013}}</ref> When asked about returning for another sequel, actor [[Patrick Wilson (American actor)|Patrick Wilson]] went on to say that he "[doesn't] know where else it could go", and that "[Josh Lambert has] been through the wringer, and I think the movie sets it up well at the end [...] And that's great, that's how it should end."<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Nigel M.|title=Patrick Wilson On Why There Won't Be an ''Insidious 3'' and His Love for ''Conjuring'' Director James Wan|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/patrick-wilson-on-why-there-wont-be-an-insidious-3-and-his-love-for-director-james-wan?page=2#articleHeaderPanel|work=[[Indiewire]]|accessdate=September 16, 2013|date=September 12, 2013}}</ref> On November 13, 2013, it was announced [[Focus Features]] and [[Stage 6 Films]] would release the film on April 3, 2015. The date was later moved to May 29, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=''INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 3'' Will Haunt Theaters on April 3, 2015|url=http://collider.com/insidious-chapter-3-release-date-april-3-2015|work=Collider.com|accessdate=November 18, 2013|date=November 18, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=120187|title=''Insidious: Chapter 3'' Moves to May 2015|last=Mitovich|first=Matt Webb|work=Comingsoon.net|date=July 2, 2014|accessdate=July 2, 2014}}</ref>
On March 11, 2014, Screen Rant reported that the third film would not focus on the Lamberts, but on a new family and story, and would not connect to the last scene in the second film. It was also reported that both Whannell and [[Angus Sampson]] would return as ghost hunters Specs and Tucker, along with [[Lin Shaye]] as Elise.<ref>{{cite web|last=Outlaw|first=Kofi|title=''Insidious 3'' Will Introduce New Story and Characters; Ghost Hunters Will Return|url=http://screenrant.com/insidious-3-story-characters-specs-tucker|work=Screen Rant|accessdate=March 11, 2014|date=March 11, 2014}}</ref> On May 7, 2014, Wan tweeted that Whannell would direct the third film, which marks his directorial debut.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/creepypuppet/status/464105691834093568?p=v|title=Twitter / creepypuppet: I'm truly honored & excited|publisher=Twitter.com|date=May 7, 2014|accessdate=July 23, 2014}}</ref> In June 2014, [[Stefanie Scott]] and [[Dermot Mulroney]] were cast in the film.<ref>{{cite news|title=Horror Sequel ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' Scares Up ''Jem'', ''A.N.T. Farm'' Star Stefanie Scott|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/06/stefanie-scott-insidious-chapter-3-jem-and-the-holograms|accessdate=June 12, 2014|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=June 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodreporter.com/v/MoviesNews/DermotMulroneyStarIn3|title=Dermot Mulroney to Star in ''Insidious: Chapter 3''|last=Kit|first=Borys|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 25, 2014|accessdate=June 25, 2014}}</ref> On September 22, 2014, during the Cinema Diverse Film Festival in [[Palm Springs]], actress [[Ele Keats]] said she had recently wrapped an undisclosed supporting role in the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QIbddipAFL0|title=Interview with Ele Keats|publisher=youtube.com|date=September 22, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on July 9, 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studiosystemnews.com/40476|title=On The Set For 7/14/14: Dermot Mulroney Starrer ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' Starts, Levan Akin's ''The Circle'' Wraps|publisher=StudioSystemNews.com|accessdate=July 23, 2014}}</ref> in [[Los Angeles]] under the title "Into The Further", on a scheduled 29-day shoot.<ref name="slashfilm1">{{cite web|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/insidious-3-set-visit|title=‘Insidious Chapter 3:’ A Set Visit As Scary as the Franchise Itself|publisher=slashfilm.com|accessdate=March 23, 2015}}</ref> Several scenes were shot in the [[San Fernando Valley]] at the ''Delfino Studios'' in [[Sylmar]], where the Brenner apartment's interiors were built.<ref name="slashfilm1"/>
A first look image was released on July 22, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Anderton|first1=Ethan|title=First Look: ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' Which Predates the First Two Films|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2014/first-look-insidious-chapter-3-which-predates-the-first-two-films|accessdate=July 23, 2014|publisher=FirstShowing.net|date=July 22, 2014}}</ref> Filming wrapped on August 18, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/oren_peli/status/501969033751580672|title=Insidious Wrap Party|publisher=Instagram.com|accessdate=January 13, 2015}}</ref>
===Music=== The [[film score|musical score]] for ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' is composed by [[Joseph Bishara]], who composed the music for the previous installments.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joseph Bishara to Return for ''Insidious: Chapter 3''|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2014/11/10/joseph-bishara-to-return-for-insidious-chapter-3|website=Film Music Reporter|accessdate=November 11, 2014|date=November 10, 2014}}</ref> A soundtrack album for the film was released digitally on June 5, 2015 by Void Recordings.<ref>{{cite web|title=‘Insidious: Chapter 3′ Soundtrack Details|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2015/05/15/insidious-chapter-3-soundtrack-details/|website=Film Music Reporter|accessdate=May 18, 2015|date=May 15, 2015}}</ref>
==Marketing and promotion== A first [[Teaser campaign|teaser]] poster was released online on September 18, 2014, featuring a grey wall with a vent and the red text "The man who can't breathe, the man who lives in the vents, I heard him saying your name last night, I heard him in your room while you were gone, he's in there right now, standing in your room."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enstarz.com/articles/46597/20140919/insidious-3-news-new-teaser-poster-for-movie-released-video.htm|title='Insidious 3' News: Horrifying Teaser Poster For Movie Released|publisher=enstarz.com|date=September 18, 2014|accessdate=March 3, 2015}}</ref> The first teaser trailer for the film was released by [[Focus Features]] on October 23, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/first-teaser-trailer-lands-for-insidious-chapter-3-watch-now/|title=First teaser trailer lands for Insidious: Chapter 3: watch now|publisher=gamesradar.com|date=October 23, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}}</ref> The same day director [[Leigh Whannell]] invited fans to join him for a live Q&A session on the movie's official [[Facebook]] page.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/InsidiousMovie/posts/735457813174741?permPage=1|title=Insidious Official Facebook Page|publisher=facebook.com|date=October 23, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}}</ref> A few days later, on October 28, 2014 the same Facebook page reached 4 million fans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/InsidiousMovie/photos/a.158035400916988.42161.148418438545351/737589076294948/|title=4 million have entered into The Further|publisher=facebook.com|date=October 28, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}}</ref> On December 17, 2014, fans were invited to connect with ''Insidious'' on [[Kik Messenger]] for exclusive content.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/InsidiousMovie/photos/a.158035400916988.42161.148418438545351/762183223835533/|title=Insidious Official Facebook Page|publisher=facebook.com|date=December 17, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2015}}</ref>
On March 16, 2015, [[Focus Features]] debuted a teaser for the full official trailer that was eventually released the following day, on March 17, 2015, during a series of launch events in selected cities, including [[Miami]] (where lead star [[Stefanie Scott]] held a Q&A session), [[Chicago]] (with supporting actress [[Hayley Kiyoko]] in attendance), and [[New York City]] (where ''[[Fangoria]]'' magazine hosted a Q&A session with [[Lin Shaye]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fangoria.com/new/ny-join-lin-shaye-at-insidious-chapter-3-trailer-launch-event-tomorrow/|title=NY! Join Lin Shaye at "INSIDIOUS: CHAPTER 3" trailer launch event tomorrow|publisher=fangoria.com|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref> A new poster featuring Stefanie Scott was also released the same day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/93528/insidious-chapter-3-official-poster-premiere|title='Insidious 3' Official Poster Premiere|publisher=dreadcentral.com|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref> On July 3, 2014, [[Focus Features]] moved the already announced US theatrical release date from April 3 to May 29, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/54568/insidious-chapter-3-releases-further-down-the-line-in-2015|title=Insidious Chapter 3 Releases Further Down the Line in 2015|publisher=dreadcentral.com|date=July 3, 2014|accessdate=March 8, 2015}}</ref> On December 10, 2014, the distribution company announced that the theatrical release date had been moved back again from May 29 to June 5, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailydead.com/release-date-change-insidious-chapter-3-2|title=Release Date Change for Insidious: Chapter 3|publisher=dailydead.com|date=December 11, 2014|accessdate=March 8, 2015}}</ref>
On May 20, 2015, Focus Features relaunched their [[Gramercy Pictures]] label for action, horror, and science fiction movies. ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' was the first release from the revived Gramercy.<ref name="deadline1">{{cite news|last1=Petski|first1=Denise|title=Focus Features Revives Gramercy Pictures Label For Genre Films|url=http://deadline.com/2015/05/focus-features-revives-gramercy-pictures-label-genre-films-1201430500/|accessdate=May 20, 2015|website=Deadline Hollywood|date=May 20, 2015}}</ref>
==Release== === Box office === ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' grossed $52.2 million in North America and $60.6 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $112.8 million, against a budget of $10 million.<ref name="BOM">{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=insidiouschapter3.htm |title=Insidious: Chapter 3 (2015) |website=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=July 13, 2015}}</ref>
In North America, the film made $1.6 million from its early Thursday night showings, from 2,150 theaters,<ref name="TT">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/insidious-chapter-3-entourage-spy-box-office-1201438262/|title=‘Insidious: Chapter 3′ Scares Up Bucks In Thursday Night Previews – Box Office|author=Anthony D'Alessandro|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=June 5, 2015|accessdate=June 5, 2015}}</ref> and $10.4 million on its opening day, from 3,003 theaters.<ref name="THROP">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-spy-laughs-past-800188|title=Box Office: 'Spy' Laughs Past Rival Comedy 'Entourage,' Horror Film 'Insidious 3'|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=June 6, 2015|accessdate=June 6, 2015}}</ref> It finished at third place in its opening weekend, earning $23 million behind fellow opener ''[[Spy (2015 film)|Spy]]'' and holdover ''[[San Andreas (film)|San Andreas]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-spy-wins-crowded-800654|title=Box Office: 'Spy' Wins Crowded Race With $30M; 'Entourage' Stalls|author=Pamela McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=([[Prometheus Global Media]])|date=June 7, 2015|accessdate=June 7, 2015}}</ref>
Outside North America, ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' grossed $14.3 million in its opening weekend, from 42 countries on 2,989 screens, also finishing in third place behind ''San Andreas'' and ''Spy''.<ref name="2ndweek">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/san-andreas-mad-max-spy-insidious-3-entourage-avengers-ultron-pitch-perfect-international-box-office-1201438931/|title=‘San Andreas’ Has Seismic $97.7M Frame; ‘Spy’ Crosses $50M – Intl B.O. Final|author=Nancy Tartaglione and Anita Busch|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=June 8, 2015|accessdate=June 9, 2015}}</ref> It had the biggest opening for a horror film in the Philippines ($1.5 million) and in Vietnam ($620,000), the second-biggest in Malaysia ($1.6 million), and had similarly successful openings in Russia and the CIS ($2.7 million).<ref name="2ndweek"/> Mexico opened with $1.8 million and India with $620,000.<ref name="3rdweek">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/international-box-office-terminator-genisys-ted-2-jurassic-world-minions-inside-out-1201460765/|title=‘Terminator: Genisys’ In $8.3M Bow; Dinos Mighty With $82.5M More; ‘Minions’ Well Outpacing ‘DM2′ – Intl Box Office|author=Nancy Tartaglione|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=([[Penske Media Corporation]])|date=June 28, 2015|accessdate=June 29, 2015}}</ref>
=== Critical reception === The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] lists a 59% approval rating based on 121 reviews and a [[Weighted arithmetic mean|rating average]] of 5.5/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "''Insidious: Chapter 3'' isn't as terrifying as the original, although it boasts surprising thematic depth and is enlivened by another fine performance from Lin Shaye."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/insidious_chapter_3_2015/ |title=Insidious: Chapter 3 (2015) |publisher=[[Fandango Media]]|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=April 11, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]] the film has a score of 52 out of 100 based on 26 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/insidious-chapter-3|title=Insidious: Chapter 3 Reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=June 6, 2015}}</ref> In [[CinemaScore]] polls, cinema audiences gave the film an average score of "B+" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="THROP"/>
Daniel Krupa of [[IGN]] awarded it a score of 7.1 out of 10, saying "''Insidious: Chapter 3'' is the most focussed, dark, and creepy installment of the series to date."<ref>{{cite web|first=Daniel |last=Krupa |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/06/04/insidious-chapter-3-review |title=Insidious: Chapter 3 Review |publisher=IGN |date=2015-06-04 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Scott Foundas of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a negative review, saying "Chief among things that go bump in the night in ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' is the movie itself—a thuddingly dull prequel to James Wan's very enjoyable (and highly profitable) demonic-possession horror franchise."<ref>{{cite web|first=Scott |last=Foundas |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/reviews/insidious-chapter-3-film-review-1201511456/ |title=‘Insidious: Chapter 3′ Review: Third Time No Charm For Wan-less Franchise |work=Variety |date=2015-06-03 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Justin Lowe of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "''Insidious: Chapter 3'' offers a relatable young protagonist and several key supporting players from the prior films in a nimble setup to the series."<ref name=thr>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/insidious-chapter-3/review/799171 |title='Insidious: Chapter 3': Film Review |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date= 2015-06-03|accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Kyle Anderson of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a C+, saying "''Insidious Chapter 3'' is the worst kind of sequel: Not terrible, but also cartoonishly unnecessary."<ref>{{cite web|last=Anderson |first=Kyle |url=http://www.ew.com/article/2015/06/04/insidious-chapter-3-ew-review |title='Insidious: Chapter 3': EW review |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=2015-06-04 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Michael Ordoña of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' rated it zero out of four stars, saying "''Insidious: Chapter 3'' is simply not scary. Not a bit, not a whit. Except that the audience will be terrified of the next stabbing of their eardrums, at generally predictable intervals."<ref>{{cite web|first=Michael |last=Ordoña |url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/Insidious-3-More-of-the-same-That-s-not-6305329.php |title=‘Insidious 3’: More of the same. That’s not good. |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=2015-03-11 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Michael O'Sullivan of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the film one-and-a-half stars out of four, saying "The ''Insidious'' franchise, after three attempts to exorcise its real demons, still can't seem to shake what really haunts it: the ghost of B-movies past."<ref>{{cite web|last=O'Sullivan |first=Michael |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/insidious-chapter-3-review-haunted-by-the-problems-of-the-first-two-films/2015/06/04/36d7a672-0ac9-11e5-9e39-0db921c47b93_story.html |title=‘Insidious: Chapter 3’ review: Haunted by the problems of the first two films |work=The Washington Post |date=2012-12-14 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Peter Howell of the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' gave the film two-and-a-half stars out of four, saying "This prequel to the shriek hell, directed and scripted by series writer/actor Leigh Whannell, manages to avoid the Curse of the Triple Cash Grab."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/movies/2015/06/04/insidious-or-just-inevitable-chapter-3-is-still-involving-review.html |title=Insidious or just inevitable? Chapter 3 is still involving: review |work=The Toronto Star |date=2015-03-16 |accessdate=2015-06-07|last=Howell|first=Peter}}</ref>
Kerry Lengel of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "''Insidious: Chapter 3'' is almost more a spoof of a classic like ''The Exorcist'' than it is an homage. It's not scary horror, it's silly horror, and the audience is in on the joke."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/story/entertainment/movies/2015/06/04/movie-review-insidious-chapter-stars/28496149/ |title=Review: 'Insidious: Chapter 3' is paint-by-numbers scary |work=The Arizona Republic |date=2014-04-25 |accessdate=2015-06-07|last=Lengel|first=Kerry}}</ref> Stephen Whitty of the ''[[The Star-Ledger|Newark Star-Ledger]]'' gave the film two-and-a-half stars, saying "You need more than a few sudden noises and scary shocks to make a good horror movie. But ''Insidious: Chapter Three'' is at least an OK horror movie."<ref>{{cite web|first=Stephen |last=Whitty |url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/06/insidious_chapter_3_review_no_ghoul_like_an_old_gh.html |title='Insidious: Chapter 3' review: No ghoul like an old ghoul |work=Newark Star-Ledger |date=2015-06-05 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> [[James Berardinelli]] of ''[[ReelViews]]'' gave the film two-and-a-half out of four stars, saying "They say the third time's the charm. Not with the ''Insidious'' series, it isn't. Admittedly, installment #3 is an improvement over #2, but it fails to reach the highs of the chilling-but-uneven original."<ref>{{cite web|first=James |last=Berardinelli |url=http://www.reelviews.net/reelviews/insidious-chapter-3 |title=Insidious: Chapter 3 |work=Reelviews |date=2015-06-05 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Tim Robey of ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'' gave the film four out of five stars, saying "It manages the all-important jump scares with the finesse of a skilled stage illusionist, but it’s the surprisingly sincere emotional core that makes it the pick of the series."<ref>{{cite web|first=Tim |last=Robey |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/insidious-chapter-3/review/ |title=Insidious: Chapter 3 review |work=The Telegraph |date=2015-06-04 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Katie Rife of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the film a B-, saying "The motif of grief runs throughout ''Insidious: Chapter 3'', which is surprisingly thematically rich for the third installment of a horror franchise. This emotional undercurrent informs the fright scenes, which otherwise lean rather heavily on jump scares."<ref>{{cite web|last=Rife |first=Katie |url=http://www.avclub.com/review/veteran-character-actress-almost-gets-her-due-insi-220356 |title=Review: A veteran character actress almost gets her due in Insidious: Chapter 3 |work=The A.V. Club |date=2015-06-04 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref> Bilge Ebiri of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine gave the film a negative review, saying "This is so often the problem with this genre—scary setups, followed by dopey resolutions—that you sort of want to give the movie a pass. But given its distinguished forebears, ''Insidious: Chapter 3'' doesn’t quite live up to expectations."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/06/movie-review-insidious-chapter-3.html |title=Movie Review: Insidious: Chapter 3 |work=Vulture |date=2015-06-05 |accessdate=2015-06-07}}</ref>
==Sequel== In an interview Leigh Whannell was asked "If there is a fourth ''Insidious'' film, would that be a sequel to ''Chapter 3'', another prequel to the original or will it continue in this timeline or go to a whole new timeline?" Whannell stated: "I don't know. I haven't really thought about it yet. But for the purposes of this interview, I'll say that I'd like to explore the time between this film and the first film. That whole area there where Elise has rediscovered her gift, I think you could have a lot of adventures before she arrives. So I think there is a lot of room there. We've kind of established Lin [Shaye] in this particular film as kind of this superhero, so that would be kind of interesting to explore in the other films."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wegotthiscovered.com/movies/leigh-whannell-discusses-ideas-insidious-4/|title=Insidious: Chapter 4 Will Take Place Closer To First Film|author=Isaac Feldberg|work=We Got This Covered}}</ref>
''[[Insidious: The Last Key]]'' was announced in May 2016 for a release date of October 20, 2017. Whannell will return to write, Blum, Peli and Wan producing as well as Shaye reprising her role as Elise Rainer and [[Adam Robitel]] directing.<ref>http://bloody-disgusting.com/movie/3391342/insidious-4-announces-writer-director-release-date/</ref> The film was released on January 5, 2018.<ref>https://variety.com/2017/film/news/insidious-chapter-4-release-date-january-2018-1202391316/</ref>

{{Infobox music genre | name = Latin rock | color = white | bgcolor = crimson | stylistic_origins = {{hlist|[[Rock music|Rock]]|[[Music of Latin America|Latin American music]]|[[List of Caribbean music genres|Caribbean music]]|[[rock and roll]]|[[rhythm and blues]]|[[Soul music|soul]]|[[funk]]}} | cultural_origins = Late 1950s, United States | derivatives = [[Latin alternative]] }} '''Latin rock''' is a term to describe a music subgenre consisting in melting traditional sounds and elements of Latin American and Caribbean folk with [[rock music]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Latin Rock |url=http://www.allmusic.com/subgenre/latin-rock-ma0000011908 |work=Allmusic.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Latin Rock definition |url=http://www.imusicdictionary.com/definition.php?term=Latin%20rock |work=Imusicdictionary}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Heatley |first1=Michael |title=Rock & Pop. La historia completa: Un recorrido exhaustivo a través de cinco décadas de rock y pop. |date=2007 |publisher=Robinbook |isbn=978-84-96222-85-4|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Finn |first1=Larry |title=Beyond the Backbeat: From Rock and Funk to Jazz and Latin |date=2000 |publisher=Berklee Press Publication}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Leng |first1=Simon |title=Santana |date=2002 |publisher=Cátedra (colección Pop-Rock) |isbn=978-84-376-1947-7}}</ref> However, it is widely used in the English-language media to refer any kind of rock music featuring Spanish or Portuguese vocals. This fact lead into a controversy about the scope of the terminology.
Latin rock should not be confused with "Rock music from Latin America"<ref>{{cite book |last1=Varios autores |title=Diccionario del Rock Latino |date=2000 |publisher=Iberautor Promociones Culturales-Zona de trabajos |isbn=978-84-8048-408-4|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Varios autores (Coordinado por Diego A. Manrique) |title=Historia de la música Rock |date=1987 |publisher=El País|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Avant-Mier |first1=Roberto |title=Rock the Nation: Latin/o Identities and the Latin Rock Diaspora |date=2010 |publisher=Continuum Publishing Corporation}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Grijalba |first1=Silvia |title=Santana - El nuevo iluminado |date=2000 |publisher=La Máscara |isbn=978-84-7974-426-7|language=Spanish}}</ref> or [[Rock en español]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=De Limongi |first1=Toni |title=Los fabulosos cadillacs. los calaveras del rock latino |date=1999 |publisher=La Máscara |isbn=978-84-7974-361-1|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=McCarthy |first1=Jim |title=Voices of Latin Rock: The People and Events That Created This Sound |date=2005 |publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Finn |first1=Larry |title=Beyond the Backbeat: From Rock and Funk to Jazz and Latin |date=2000 |publisher=Berklee Press Publication}}</ref> It's also closely related to the '''[[Latin alternative]]''' scene (which combines Latin elements with [[alternative rock]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[electronic music]], [[Indie pop|indie]] or [[hip hop]] among others)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Jiménez |first=Willi |title=Alterlatino |journal=Zona de trabajos (revista) |date=April 2012|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Scaramuzzino |first=Rubén |title=Algo así como la Biblia de la Cultura Latina |journal=Zona de trabajos |date=2008 |issue=53|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Jon |last=Pareles |title=Latin Alternative Music’s Movers and Shakers Meet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/11/arts/music/11lamc.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=10 July 2009 |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Latin Alternative Music Conference |url=http://www.latinalternative.com/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=PRX Series - The Latin Alternative Radio |url=https://www.prx.org/series/32690-the-latin-alternative}}</ref> a term often used to refer the same phenomenon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/music/10-rock-en-espa-ol-albums-to-listen-to-before-you-die-6605944|title=10 Rock en Español Albums to Listen to Before You Die|accessdate=20 November 2012|work=ocweekly.com|author=Gustavo Arellano}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Origins (1950s–1960s) === [[File:Sir Douglas Quintet 1965.jpg|thumb|<small>[[Sir Douglas Quintet]] were an American rock band that experimented with Latin folk elements during the 1960s.</small>]] Rock and Roll music of the 1950s originated from a variety of sources including African-American rhythm and blues, blues, gospel, country and western, bluegrass, western swing, and Tin Pan Alley pop music. Also, there was some influence of the traditional Latin music on it. Caribbean rhythms like [[Calypso music|calypso]] were remarkable on [[surf music]]; and there were some rock and roll songs based on [[cha-cha-cha (music)|cha-cha-chá]] or [[mambo (music)|mambo]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pallan |first1=Michelle H. |title=Loca Motion: The Travels of Chicana/Latina Popular Culture |date=2005 |publisher=NYU Press}}</ref>
Latin Rock (term not yet created) was born in the [[United States]]<ref>{{cite book |last1=David Reyes |first1=Tom Waldman |title=Land of a Thousand Dances: Chicano rock 'n' roll from Southern California |date=1998 |publisher=University of New Mexico Press |isbn=0-8263-1929-7}}</ref> at late 1950s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Loza |first1=Joseph Steven |title=Barrio Rhythm: Mexican American music in Los Angeles |date=1993 |publisher=University of Illinois Press |isbn=0-252-06288-4}}</ref> In 1958 and adaptation of a Mexican folk song called “[[La Bamba (song)|La bamba]]” by the [[chicano rock]] artist [[Ritchie Valens]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mendheim |first1=Beverly |title=Ritchie Valens: The First Latino Rocker |date=1987 |publisher=Bilingual Review Press |isbn=978-0-916950-79-8}}</ref> That same year, instrumental rock band [[The Champs]] released "[[Tequila (song)|Tequila]]", that incorporates clear Latin sounds (composed by chicano [[Danny Flores]]).
During the 1960s, there were more examples of rock artists like [[Thee Midniters]], [[Question Mark & the Mysterians]],<ref>{{cite web |last1=Guerrero |first1=Mark |title=Question Mark & the Mysterians: The First Punk Rock Band |url=http://www.markguerrero.com/36.php |date=2008}}</ref> [[Sam the Sham|Sam the Sham and the Pharaohs]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Sam the Sham & the Pharaos |url=http://www.classicbands.com/samsham.html |work=Classic Bands}}</ref> or [[Sir Douglas Quintet]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Huey |first1=Steve |title=Sir Douglas Quintet - A Biography |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/the-sir-douglas-quintet-mn0000018708/biography |work=Allmusic.com |date=2015}}</ref> that included Latin rhythms on their compositions. Also the rise of the [[chicano rock]] in [[California]] joined; although not all of them could be considered as early Latin rock artists since many of them lacked the Latin folk influences.<ref>{{cite book |last1=David Reyes |first1=Tom Waldman |title=Land of a Thousand Dances: Chicano rock 'n' roll from Southern California |date=1998 |publisher=University of New Mexico Press |isbn=0-8263-1929-7}}</ref>
On the other hand, at some Latin American countries, Latin rock started to develop on [[Peru]], [[Colombia]] or [[Argentina]], but specially [[Brazil]]<ref>{{cite book |last1=Dunn |first1=Christopher |title=Brutality Garden: Tropicália and the Emergence of a Brazilian Counterculture. |date=2001 |publisher=Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press |isbn=0-8078-4976-6}}</ref> where '''[[Tropicália]]''' appeared at mid-1960s<ref>{{cite web |title=Tropicalia |url=http://www.allmusic.com/style/tropicalia-ma0000002805 |work=Allmusic.com}}</ref> with the first releases of [[Os Mutantes]], [[Gal Costa]] and [[Caetano Veloso]] from 1967 to 1970,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Mei |first1=Giancarlo |title=Canto Latino: Origine, Evoluzione e Protagonisti della Musica Popolare del Brasile |date=2004 |publisher=Stampa Alternativa-Nuovi Equilibri|language=Italian}}</ref> a music movement that melt rock music with [[bossa nova]], [[psychedelia]] and other Latin elements<ref>{{cite book |last1=Riccardo Pesanha |first1=Chris McGowan |title=The Brazilian Sound: Samba, Bossa Nova and the Popular Music of Brazi |date=1998 |publisher=Philadelphia: Temple University Press |isbn=1-56639-545-3}}</ref> which has been regarded as the main root of the genre.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Júnior |first1=Gonçalo |title=La (in)digestión del Tropicalismo. |url=http://revistapesquisa.fapesp.br/es/2007/10/01/la-indigestion-del-tropicalismo/ |work=Pesquisa-FAPESP |date=October 2007}}</ref>
=== "Latin Rock" term born (1970s) ===
[[File:Santana (1971).png|left|thumb|American band '''[[Santana (band)|Santana]]''' in 1971]] In 1969, after the release of the debut album by [[Santana (band)|Santana]], Latin rock appeared in the US and other parts of the world.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Woog |first1=Adam |title=Carlos Santana: Legendary Guitarist (The Twentieth Century's Most Influential Hispanics) |date=2006 |publisher=Lucent Books |isbn=978-1-59018-972-6}}</ref> They treated to describe the band's music style as a fusion of Latin American and Caribbean rhythms, [[soul music|soul]], [[jazz]], [[funk]], [[blues]], [[psychedelia]] and [[rhythm and blues]] based on [[rock music]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pasceri |first1=Carlo |title=Santana: Love, Devotion & Surrender (Storie di Musica Vol.1) |date=2015 |publisher=Libro digital-Kindle}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Leng |first1=Simon |title=Santana |publisher=Cátedra (colección Pop-Rock) |isbn=978-84-376-1947-7|language=Spanish}}</ref>
Following [[Santana (band)|Santana]], other American bands appeared like [[Malo (band)|Malo]], [[Ocho (band)|Ocho]], [[Mandrill (band)|Mandrill]], [[El Chicano]], [[Eddie Palmieri's Harlem River Drive]], [[War (band)|War]], [[Sapo (band)|Sapo]] and [[Azteca (band)|Azteca]] at early 1970s popularizing the genre in the USA and the rest of the world since 1970-71.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gillet |first1=Charlie |title=Historia del Rock. El sonido de la ciudad |date=2008 |publisher=Ma Non Troppo Ediciones |isbn=978-84-96924-39-0}}</ref>
Latin American counterpart Latin rock bands appeared as it could be seen in [[Peru]] with bands like [[Telegraph Avenue]], [[Traffic Sound]], [[The Mad's]], [[El Polen]] and specially [[Black Sugar]] melting rock with jazz music, Peruvian folk, [[progressive rock]] and Latin elements; in [[Colombia]] highlighted [[Siglo Cero]], [[Génesis (Colombia)|Génesis]] and [[La Columna de Fuego]]; in [[Argentina]] [[Arco Iris (band)|Arco Iris]]; and in [[Chile]], [[Los Jaivas]].
The genre arrived also in [[Europe]], with the Spaniards [[Barrabás]],<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ordovás |first1=Jesús |title=Historia de la música Pop española |date=1987 |publisher=Alianza editorial |isbn=978-84-206-0224-0|language=Spanish}}</ref> Dutch [[Massada (band)|Massada]] and African-British [[Osibisa]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Aniagolu |first1=Charles |title=Osibisa - Living In The State Of Happy Vibes And Criss Cross Rhythms |date=2004 |publisher=Trafford Publishing |isbn=1-4120-2106-5}}</ref>
Meanwhile, [[Reggae]] music achieved a great success around the world. This rhythm originated in [[Jamaica]] arose during the 1960s, evolving from [[ska]], [[rocksteady]] and bluebeat.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Bradley |first1=Lloyd |title=This Is Reggae Music: The Story of Jamaica's Music |date=2001 |publisher=Grove Press |isbn=978-0-8021-3828-6}}</ref> Since its origins along with rock music and rhythm and blues with Jamaican folk rhythms, the [[Caribbean]] and Continental Latin America elements influenced the scene.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Davis |first1=Stephen |title=Reggae Bloodlines: In Search Of The Music And Culture Of Jamaica |date=1992 |publisher=Da Capo Press |isbn=978-0-306-80496-0}}</ref> Nevertheless, [[Reggae]] or [[Ska]] have never considered as part of the Latin Rock.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Barrow |first1=Steve |title=The Rough Guide to Reggae |date=2001 |publisher=Rough Guides |isbn=978-1-85828-558-0}}</ref> On the other hand, [[Disco Music]] also influenced Latin rock during the 1970s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Alan Jones |first1=Jussi Kantonen |title=Saturday Night Forever: The Story of Disco |date=1999 |publisher=A Capella Books |isbn=1-55652-411-0}}</ref>
=== Latin rock evolution (1980–Present)=== [[File:Macaco aterciopelados.JPG|thumb|Colombian band '''[[Aterciopelados]]''' with the Spaniard '''[[Macaco (band)|Macaco]]'''.]] After [[punk rock|punk]] eclosion at late 1970s, the genre also was influenced by many other music styles. Some British punk and [[new wave]] acts like [[The Clash]] included elements that could be considered as "latin" in "[[Sandinista!]]" (1980).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Gendre |first1=Marcos |title=The Clash: La única banda que importa |date=2015 |publisher=Quarentena |isbn=978-84-16229-11-6|language=Spanish}}</ref> Other bands such as [[Bow Wow Wow]], [[Gang Of Four]], [[The Slits]] or [[The Specials|Special AKA]] did so.
[[File:Cafe Tacuba Pontevedra.jpg|left|thumb|Mexican band '''[[Café Tacuba]]''']] In Spain, [[Los Coyotes]], [[Los Mestizos]] and [[Radio Futura]], that had been emerged as new wave and post-punk acts, finally got influenced by Latin music at mid 1980s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Ordovás |first1=Jesús |title=Historia de la música Pop española |date=1987 |publisher=Alianza editorial |isbn=978-84-206-0224-0|language=Spanish}}</ref> Spain would go on producing some Latin acts like [[Macaco (band)|Macaco]], [[Amparanoia]] or [[Jarabe de Palo]].
In France, bands like [[Les Negresses Vertes]] played a fusion of rock with [[World music]] including Latin elements. But [[Manu Chao]] was the major success of the Latin rock in France with the band [[Mano Negra (band)|Mano Negra]] (also as a solo artist) with a style that would be known later as '''[[Latin alternative]]'''. A mix of rock, with Latin elements, [[Arabic music]], [[punk rock|punk]], [[rap]], [[flamenco]], [[ska]] and [[reggae]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Robecchi |first1=Alessandro |title=Manu Chao. Música y Libertad |date=2002 |publisher=Random House |isbn=978-84-397-0856-8|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In the US during this period bands like [[David Byrne]] (ex-leader of [[Talking Heads]]), [[Peter Gabriel]], [[Paul Simon]], [[Willy Deville]], [[Los Lobos]], [[El Vez]], [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], and [[Rage Against The Machine]] appeared, developing some of these "mixing" sounds (specially in Latin folk sounds)
The genre consolidated during the 1990s in Latin America.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Scaramuzzino |first1=Rubén |title=Algo así como la Biblia de la Cultura Latina |journal=Zona de trabajos |date=2008 |issue=53|language=Spanish}}</ref> Many bands appeared such as [[Rio Roma]] (Mexico), [[Maná (band)|Maná]] (Mexico), [[Caifanes]] (Mexico), [[Café Tacuba]] (Mexico), [[Aterciopelados]] (Colombia), [[Paralamas do Sucesso]] (Brazil), [[Bersuit Vergarabat]] (Argentina), [[Karamelo Santo]] (Argentina), [[Maldita Vecindad]] (Mexico), [[Carmina Burana]] (Argentina), [[Los Fabulosos Cadillacs]] (Argentina), [[Soda Stereo]] (Argentina), [[Los Tres]] (Chile), [[Octavia (band)|Octavia]] (Bolivia), [[Karnak (band)|Karnak]] (Brazil), [[Chancho en Piedra]] (Chile), [[Julieta Venegas]] (Mexico) and [[Los Rabanes]] (Panama), that incorporated Latin folk rhythms on their compositions (especially [[Caifanes]] and [[Los Fabulosos Cadillacs]]).
== Controversy about the term ==
[[File:LFCMedellín3.jpg|thumb|Argentine band '''[[Los Fabulosos Cadillacs]]''']] At late 1990s, the rising population of "Latinos" in the US<ref>{{cite book |last1=Suárez-Orozco |first1=Marcelo |title=Latinos: Remaking America |date=2008 |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-25827-3}}</ref>(term popularized since the 1960s due to the wrong and confusing use of "[[Spaniards|Spanish]]" term and the unpopular term "[[Hispanic]]")<ref>{{cite book |last1=González |first1=Juan |title=Harvest of Empire: A History of Latinos in America |date=2011 |publisher=Penguin Books |isbn=978-0-14-311928-9}}</ref> lead music industry to create the [[Latin Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences]] as a sub-department of [[The Recording Academy|National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]. Also in 2000 the [[Latin Grammy Awards]] were created. Thus, a great part of the English media started to refer any kind of music featuring Spanish vocals as "Latin music".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Avant-Mier |first1=Roberto |title=Rock the Nation: Latin/o Identities and the Latin Rock Diaspora |date=2010 |publisher=Continuum Publishing Corporation}}</ref>
This term achieved a great success in some Latin American countries, where some of their regional press started to use the new terminology.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Avant-Mier |first1=Roberto |title=Rock the Nation: Latin/o Identities and the Latin Rock Diaspora |date=2010 |publisher=Continuum Publishing Corporation}}</ref> This phenomenon spread the use of the "latin rock" term with a completely different meaning of the original one.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Varios autores |title=Diccionario del Rock Latino |date=2000 |publisher=Iberautor Promociones Culturales-Zona de trabajos |isbn=978-84-8048-408-4|language=Spanish}}</ref> This lead into a controversy and confusion in the population.
== See also == * [[Latin alternative]] * [[Latin music (genre)]] * [[Latin jazz]] * [[Tropicália]] * [[Chicano rock]] * [[Rock en español]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== Bibliography ==
* {{cite book |url=https://books.google.com.ar/books?id=v-ioAwAAQBAJ&pg=PR10&dq=%22Rock+latino%22&hl=es-419 |title=Rock the Nation: Latin/o Identities and the Latin Rock Diaspora |first=Roberto |last=Avant-Mier |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |year=2010 |location=United States |isbn=978-1-4411-6448-3}}

{{Infobox television | show_name = Marrying the Game | image = Marrying the Game.jpg | genre = [[Reality television|Reality]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Game (rapper)|Jayceon Taylor]] * Tiffney Cambridge }} | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 3 | num_episodes = 22 | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Ben Samek * Christian Sarabia * Cris Abrego * Jill Holmes * Kristen Kelly * Rabih Gholam }} | runtime = 22 to 24 minutes | company = [[51 Minds Entertainment]] | channel = [[VH1]] | picture_format = [[480i]] ([[Standard-definition television|SDTV]])
[[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | first_aired = {{Start date|2012|11|19}} | last_aired = {{End date|2014|7|2}} | website = http://www.vh1.com/shows/marrying_the_game/series.jhtml }} '''''Marrying the Game''''' is an American [[reality television]] series that aired on [[VH1]] and premiered on November 19, 2012 and ended July 2, 2014.{{cite press release|last=Kondolojy|first=Amanda|title=VH1 Bets on Love With the Premiere of 'Marrying The Game' on November 19 at 9:30 PM|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2012/10/11/vh1-bets-on-love-with-the-premiere-of-marrying-the-game-on-november-19-at-930-pm/152577/|work=TV by the Numbers|date=October 11, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Strong|first=Nolan|title=Game’s Reality Show "Marrying The Game’ Set To Debut November 19 On VH1|url=http://allhiphop.com/2012/10/11/games-reality-show-marrying-the-game-set-to-debut-november-19-on-vh1/|work=All Hip Hop|date=October 11, 2012}}{{cite web|last=Victorian|first=Brande|title=Ev and Ocho 2.0? VH1′s Debuting "Marrying The Game" Next Month|url=http://madamenoire.com/223585/ev-and-ocho-2-0-vh1s-debuting-marrying-the-game-next-month/|work=Madame Noire|date=October 11, 2012}} ==Premise== ''Marrying the Game'' chronicles the life of Jayceon Taylor, mostly known as [[Game (rapper)|The Game]], and his fiancé Tiffney Cambridge.{{cite web|last=White|first=Caitlin|title=Game to Star in VH1 Reality Show ‘Marrying the Game’|url=http://theboombox.com/the-game-to-star-in-vh1-show/|work=The Boombox|date=October 11, 2012}} The couple dated for eight years, have two children together and were preparing to walk down the aisle. The second season follows the couple after Tiffney called off the wedding, moved out of the family home with their kids and as they work to fix their relationship.{{cite web|title=AUGUST GETS EVEN HOTTER WITH THE RETURN OF VH1′S SCORCHING FAN FAVORITES|url=http://www.vh1press.com/august-gets-even-hotter-with-the-return-of-vh1s-scorching-fan-favorites/|publisher=VH1 Press Room|location=New York, New York|date=July 17, 2013}} ==Cast== ===Main=== * [[Game (rapper)|Jayceon Taylor / The Game]],{{cite web|title=''Marrying The Game'' - Cast Bios|url=http://www.vh1.com/shows/marrying_the_game/cast.jhtml|work=VH1|accessdate=September 6, 2013}} Rapper, record producer, entrepreneur, and actor * Tiffney Cambridge, Elementary school teacher for 14 years and on/off fiancé to Jayceon ===Supporting=== * King "Justice" Taylor, Jayceon's and Tiffney's son * Cali Dream Taylor, Jayceon's and Tiffney's daughter * Harlem Caron Taylor, Jayceon's son from previous relationship * Dontay Kidd, Jayceon's manager and best friend * Maya Mellon, Tiffney's sister ==Episodes== ===Series overview=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="padding:0 8px;" colspan="2" rowspan="2"| Season ! scope="col" style="padding:0 8px;" rowspan="2"| Episodes ! scope="col" style="padding:0 80px;" colspan="2"| Originally aired |- ! scope="col" | [[Season premiere]] ! scope="col" | [[Season finale]] |- | scope="row" style="background:#D4ED91;"| | '''[[#Season 1 (2012)|1]]''' | 6 | {{Start date|2012|11|19}} | {{End date|2012|12|17}} |- | scope="row" style="background:#76EEC6;"| | '''[[#Season 2 (2013)|2]]''' | 8 | {{Start date|2013|8|5}} | {{End date|2013|9|16}} |- | scope="row" style="background:#FF6666;"| | '''[[#Season 3 (2014)|3]]''' | 8 | {{Start date|2014|5|7}} | {{End date|2014|7|2}} |} ===Season 1 (2012)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:99%;" |- ! scope="col" style="background-color: #D4ED91; color: #000000;" width=7% | No. in
