revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Oliver & Bonacini Restaurants | logo = | caption = | type = | traded_as = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1993 | founder = Peter Oliver
[[Michael Bonacini]] | defunct = | location_city = 2323 [[Yonge Street]]
[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | location_country = [[Canada]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Peter Oliver
Michael Bonacini | industry = Hospitality and Entertainment | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = Jump, Canoe, Auberge du Pommier, Biff's Bistro, O&B Canteen, Luma, Bannock | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 1,200+ (2013) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.oliverbonacini.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} [[File:OliverBonaciniCaféGrill.jpg|thumb|Oliver & Bonacini Café Grill in downtown Toronto]] '''Oliver & Bonacini Restaurants''' also known as '''O&B''' is a Canadian [[hospitality industry|hospitality]] and entertainment company. Based in [[Toronto]], it was founded in 1993 as a partnership between Peter Oliver and Michael Bonacini when they opened their first collaboration — a restaurant named Jump. In the years since, the company has expanded and it currently owns multiple venues and properties in and around Toronto. According to a 2013 ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' piece, the company employs a staff of 1,200 people.{{cite news|last=Galt|first=Virginia|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/small-business/sb-growth/day-to-day/restaurants-need-to-innovate-or-be-eaten/article8736986/|title=Restaurants need to innovate or be eaten|agency=''[[The Globe and Mail]]''|date=18 February 2013|accessdate=9 November 2015}} ==Restaurants== ===Jump=== In operation for more than two decades, Jump is O&B's flagship restaurant. During that time it became a well known business lunch and dinner spot in Toronto's [[Financial District, Toronto|Financial District]].{{cite news|last=Eastwood|first=Joel|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2013/11/12/jump_bay_street_fixture_celebrates_20_years.html|title=Jump: Bay Street fixture celebrates 20 years|agency=''[[Toronto Star]]''|date=12 November 2013|accessdate=9 November 2015}} When it opened at the corner of Bay & Wellington West in late 1993 during the early 1990s recession in Canada, Jump was a major investment by the 44-year-old [[South Africa]]n-born former stockbroker and real estate entrepreneur Peter Oliver who had been an active restaurateur in Toronto since 1978 and 33-year-old Michael Bonacini who had made his name as chef at Centro, a popular Franco Prevedello-owned Italian cuisine fine dining spot at [[Yonge and Eglinton]].[http://www.chefdb.com/pl/47/Centro-Toronto Centro Toronto (1987-2013)] Furthermore, at the time, Oliver owned successful midtown and uptown Toronto restaurants Oliver's Old Fashioned Bakery and Oliver's Bistro (also in the [[Yonge and Eglinton]] area), Bofinger Brasserie (near Yonge & St. Clair), and Auberge du Pommier (in [[North York]] near Yonge and York Mills); though he opened Jump as a partnership with Bonacini in 1993, Oliver kept the sole ownership of those four restaurants. Their collaboration occurred almost by chance - Oliver had been setting up the Jump project for years before his chef-to-be fell through and he turned to Bonacini who was the executive chef at Centro, across the street from Oliver's Old Fashioned Bakery.{{cite news|last=Mintz|first=Coreyl|url=https://www.thestar.com/life/food_wine/2011/04/08/their_gamble_grew_into_an_empire.html|title=Their gamble grew into an empire|agency=''[[Toronto Star]]''|date=8 April 2011|accessdate=10 November 2015}} Located adjacent to the old glass-covered walkway in [[Commerce Court East]], Jump aimed to bring a New York-style restaurant/bar with an offbeat menu and vibe. Launched with a blowout party with 600 guests and a rock band, the restaurant quickly established itself as the favourite of the business lunch crowd. In February 2013, ahead of its twentieth anniversary, the restaurant closed down for a month in order to undergo a C$1 million upgrade including the installation of state-of-the-art audio visual equipment to better meet the needs of clients who book space for private business meetings as well as renovation to the dining room, bar, and kitchen.[http://www.bizbash.com/1-jump-oliver-bonacini-restaurant-jump-celebrated-20th-anniversary/gallery/131972#.VkFl4l74BqA Jump] ===Canoe=== In 1995, following the quick failure of Chapeau (O&B's first project since Jump took off), the company accepted an offer from the [[Toronto-Dominion Centre|TD Bank Tower]] landlord about opening a restaurant on the building's 54th floor where a struggling vine bar had been operating up to that point. A new restaurant called Canoe opened on 21 September 1995[http://oliverbonacini.com/OurCompany/Blog/O-B-Blog/September-2015/Canoe-Twenty---20th-Anniversary.aspx O&B blog] and quickly turned into another big winner for O&B, by the late 2000s generating between C$6 and 7 million in revenue annually. In May 2015, nearly 20 years after the restaurant opened its doors, ''The Globe & Mail'''s Chris Nuttall-Smith awarded Canoe four stars, calling the restaurant "fresher, more ambitious, better-polished and more committed today to its cool Canadian mission than ever."[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/food-and-wine/restaurant-reviews/canoe-canadiana-restaurant-is-still-cresting-the-waves/article24563077/] ===Auberge du Pommier=== [[File:Auberge du Pommier.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Auberge du Pommier in Toronto's [[York Mills]] neighbourhood.]] Opened in 1987 in [[North York]]'s affluent [[York Mills]] neighbourhood, under Peter Oliver's sole ownership, the fine dining [[French cuisine]] spot Auberge du Pommier operated under his command until 1997 when Oliver's partner in the rising O&B company Michael Bonacini entered into its ownership structure as a co-owner. The restaurant thus after ten years got placed under the O&B banner. Located in a mid 19th century cottage that was originally built in nearby [[Hoggs Hollow]] before getting relocated to its present location, the restaurant offers refined and modern interpretations of classic French dishes. Its executive chef is Marc St. Jacques who took over the post in 2011 having previously worked under celebrity chef [[Michael Mina]] at his restaurant Michael Mina at [[Bellagio (resort)|Bellagio]] in [[Las Vegas]].{{cite news|last=Nuttall-Smith|first=Chris|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/food-and-wine/restaurant-reviews/auberge-du-pommier-seduction-made-safe/article4686787/|title=Auberge du Pommier: Seduction made safe|agency=''[[The Globe and Mail]]''|date=26 October 2012|accessdate=16 November 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.oliverbonacini.com Official Web Site] {{DEFAULTSORT:Oliver and Bonacini Restaurants}} [[Category:Companies based in Toronto]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of Canada]]

revision.text:
'''Operation G-Sting''', also called Strippergate, and referencing a [[G-String]] part of a costume used by strippers and showgirls. It was an [[FBI]] investigation into [[bribe]]s and unreported [[campaign contribution]]s taken by [[Clark County Commission]]ers in [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]], [[Nevada]] (home of Las Vegas) and [[San Diego city council|city council]] members in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], [[California]]. These bribes were from the same [[lobbyist]], representing two sets of strip clubs, and was the result of strip club owners [[Rick Rizzolo]] and Mike Galardi trying to remove local "no touch" laws affecting the girls in their clubs.
A separate [[arms dealing]] investigation was started after the ''Operation G-Sting'' investigation, and ended around the same time.
== History == On February 20, 2003, FBI, [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]] and [[IRS]] agents removed material and documents from the [[Crazy Horse Too]] as part of a lengthy criminal investigation. As part of that investigation actors [[George Clooney]], [[Robert De Niro]], and [[Joe Pesci]] were interviewed. The case ended in 2006 when 17 defendants pleaded guilty to various offenses. As a part of the plea bargain Rick Rizzolo was ordered to sell the Crazy Horse Too within one year.
== Political corruption convictions == The investigation resulted in the convictions of 17 defendants including:<ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/jane-ann-morrison/politicians-come-and-go-after-serving-corruption-sentences]</ref> #[[Clark County Commissioner (Nevada)|Clark county Commissioner]] [[Lynette Boggs McDonald]] (R) pled no contest to filing a false statement and campaign funding irregularities. (2009)<ref name="reviewjournal">{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/jane-ann-morrison/politicians-come-and-go-after-serving-corruption-sentences|publisher=reviewjournal.com|title=Politicians come and go after serving corruption sentences | Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref><ref>http://www.reviewjournal.com, April 16, 2012 Lynette Boggs moves on after political, legal ups and downs by Jane Ann Morrison [http://www.reviewjournal.com/jane-ann-morrison/lynette-boggs-moves-after-political-legal-ups-and-downs]</ref><ref>[http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-04-Sun-2006/news/7756814.html CLARK COUNTY COMMISSION: Corruption cases cloud races] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181310/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jun-04-Sun-2006/news/7756814.html |date=2007-09-30 }}</ref> #[[Clark County Commission (Nevada)|Clark County Commissioner]] [[Mary Kincaid-Chauncey]] (D) was sentenced to 30 months in federal prison, fined $7,600 and ordered to forfeit $19,000 in assets(2006)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/nv/home/pressrelease/august2006/herrera082106.htm |accessdate=13 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821150924/http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/nv/home/pressrelease/august2006/herrera082106.htm |archivedate=21 August 2009 }}</ref> #[[Clark County Commission (Nevada)|Clark County Commissioner]] [[Dario Herrera]] (D) was sentenced to 50 months in federal prison, fined $15,000 and ordered to forfeit $60,000 in assets(2006) #[[Clark County Commission (Nevada)|Clark County Commissioner]] [[Erin Kenny]] (D) was sentenced to 2.5 years in prison(2006) #[[Clark County Commission (Nevada)|Clark County Commissioner]] Lance Matthew Malone (R) pleaded guilty to violating federal racketeering laws for bribing commissioners(2006)<ref>Ex-commissioner Lance Malone released from federal prison By Rich Coleman | Wednesday, Feb. 23, 2011 | [http://lasvegassun.com/news/2011/feb/23/ex-commissioner-lance-malone-released-federal-pris/]</ref>
In San Diego, California, three city council members were accused of corruption: [[Ralph Inzunza]], [[Michael Zucchet]] and [[Charles L. Lewis (California politician)|Charles L. Lewis]] though Lewis died of unrelated health issues prior to trial. Inzunza and Zucchet were both convicted, though Zucchet was later cleared of all charges due to lack of evidence. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sddt.com/News/article.cfm?SourceCode=20101014tza|title=Justice undone: Michael Zucchet and Ralph Inzunza|last=Coffey|first=Daniel|date=October 14, 2010|work=San Diego Daily Transcript|accessdate=2 September 2012}}</ref>
== Main Players == *[[Jack Galardi]] – Businessman and father of Michael *[[Michael Galardi]] – Strip club owner of Jaguars and Cheetah's strip clubs. Galardi admitted that he had paid various public officials between $200,000 and $400,000.<ref>{{cite news |first=Corey |last= Levitan |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= TOP 10 SCANDALS: GRITTY CITY |url= http://www.lvrj.com/living/16160347.html |work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] |publisher= |date= 2008-03-02 |accessdate=2008-03-03 }}</ref> *Lance Malone – Lobbyist, former county commissioner (Clark County, Nevada). *Tony Montegna – Undercover informant, key witness *Rick Rizzolo – Strip club owner *Charles Tappe – Street arms dealer *John D'Intino – Strip club manager and friend of Jack Galardi
==See also== * [[Cheetah's]] - Galardi’s club * [[Crazy Horse Too]] - Rick Rizzolo's club
== Notes == {{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{reflist}}
== References == * [[Brent Jordan|Jordan, Brent]], ''Stripped: Twenty Years of Secrets from Inside the Strip Club'', 2004, {{ISBN|0-9703441-2-0}} *{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Cheetah's owner to contest LV fine |url= http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jan-24-Sat-2004/news/23067753.html |work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] |publisher= |date= 2004-01-24 |accessdate= }} *{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= FBI raids Vegas strip clubs, San Diego city offices |url= http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/West/05/15/stripclub.probe.ap/ |work=[[CNN]] |publisher= |date=2003-05-15 |accessdate= }} *{{cite news|first=|last=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Patriot Act aided Feds in probe|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/sun/2003/nov/04/515818511.html|work=[[Las Vegas Sun]]|publisher=|date=2003-11-04|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427004955/http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/sun/2003/nov/04/515818511.html|archivedate=2006-04-27|df=}}
{{US federal public corruption law}}

In [[literature]], '''pace''', or '''pacing''' is the speed at which a [[narrative|story]] is told—not necessarily the speed at which the story takes place.<ref>{{harvtxt|Bishop|1988|p=46}}</ref><ref>{{harvtxt|Schellhardt|2008|p=66}}</ref><ref>{{harvtxt|Turco|1999|pp=67–68}}</ref> The number of words needed to write about a certain event does not depend upon how much time the event takes to happen; it depends upon how important that moment is to the story.<ref>{{harvtxt|Bauer|1992|p=89}}</ref> The pace is determined by the length of the [[Scene (drama)|scenes]], how fast the [[Action (narrative)|action]] moves, and how quickly the reader is provided with information. It is also sometimes dictated by the [[genre]] of the story: [[Comedy (drama)|comedies]] move faster than [[drama]]s; [[Adventure fiction|action adventures]] move faster than [[Thriller (genre)|suspense]].<ref>{{harvtxt|Schellhardt|2008|p=66}}</ref> A dragging pace is characteristic of many novels turned down by publishers, and of some that find their way into print but not into the hearts and recommendations of readers. Most rejected manuscripts move too slowly, encouraging readers to put them down.<ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=193}}</ref>
== Methods == Storytellers have a number of writing tools at their disposal—for example, [[narration]], action, [[description]], and [[Dialogue in writing|dialogue]]. When considering how to pace a story, description and narration will move it along slowly, steadily, and easily, while action and dialogue will speed it up.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=11}}</ref> Of all the tools at a writer's disposal, dialogue is the one that most quickly puts the characters and the reader into the present moment, even more so than action.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=122}}</ref>
Pace can be increased through: * flipping forward past a scene that is in the story but never appears in the book<ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=195}}</ref> * skipping steps in a logical sequence of events<ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=195}}</ref> * short scenes<ref>{{harvtxt|Bishop|1988|p=209}}</ref> * frequent paragraphing<ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=194}}</ref> * short sentences<ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=194}}</ref> * dialogue<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=11}}</ref><ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=194}}</ref> * action<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=11}}</ref> * active voice and aggressive verbs<ref>{{harvtxt|Hacker|1991|pp=151–152}}</ref> * flab-cutting (removal of superfluous words and phrases, and unnecessary adjectives and adverbs)<ref>{{harvtxt|Stein|1995|p=197}}</ref> Pace can be decreased through: * description and narration<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=11}}</ref> * introspection<ref>{{harvtxt|Bishop|1988|p=241}}</ref>
== Weaving == While ''dialogue'' is the element that brings a story and the characters to life on the page, ''action'' creates the movement, and ''narrative'' gives the story its depth and substance. Writing a story means weaving all the elements of fiction together. When this is done right, weaving dialogue, action, and narrative can create a beautiful tapestry.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=67}}</ref> Pacing is probably the most common fiction element to pay attention to when considering when to and when not to weave dialogue, narrative, and action. When creating a fast-paced conflict scene between two or more people, a writer might do well to consider only dialogue, at least for parts of it. Perhaps the characters have just entered into an argument and the writer wants to speed up the scene.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=78}}</ref> Then there are times when a scene should move slowly, so it is not always best to use dialogue.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=12}}</ref> However, reading slow-moving dialogue is preferable to reading lengthy passages of philosophical narrative.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=119}}</ref> There are scenes in all stories that work best using only narrative or only dialogue or only action.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=68}}</ref> There are no definite rules about when to and when not to weave. To weave well is to find the story's rhythm.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=79}}</ref>
== Variation == ===Within a story=== A good [[Plot (narrative)|plot]] is an exercise in proper balance. By staying aware of the scenes' levels of intensity and writing accordingly, a writer can make novels fresh and memorable to their readers.<ref>{{harvtxt|Bell|2004|pp=127-128}}</ref> Beginning writers often give every moment in their stories the same weight.<ref>{{harvtxt|Bauer|1992|p=90}}</ref> However, in writing fiction, they are in charge of the way time moves. They can pass quickly over what is unimportant, or even skip it entirely. Then they can stretch out the events their readers care about.<ref>{{harvtxt|Bauer|1992|p=89}}</ref> There is a time for telling and a time for showing.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=72}}</ref> Most stories are paced not too fast, but too slowly.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=120}}</ref> On the other hand, there is nothing less exciting than non-stop excitement, so writers must avoid the monotony of constant action and texture the pace.<ref>{{harvtxt|Saville|2013|p=154}}</ref> Writing should be done with a consciousness of pacing and tension. In the [[rising action]] of the story, reader interest can be maintained by upping the action ante with each succeeding scene. The initial obstacle the hero overcomes should be smaller than the one that follows.<ref>{{harvtxt|Lamb|2008|p=130}}</ref>
===Between different stories=== Different kinds of stories call for different kinds of characters, tension, pacing, themes, and dialogue. A fast-paced action adventure needs fast-paced dialogue in every scene to keep the story moving forward quickly. Likewise, a literary story needs the dialogue to match the pace of the other elements in the story—it needs to move more slowly.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=32}}</ref> Genre stories generally move quickly, employing more dialogue and action and less slow-paced narrative, because they are generally plot-driven rather than character-driven, like literary and mainstream stories. The emphasis is on the action that keeps the plot moving rather than the narrative that keeps the character growing. It pays to know the characters because who they are determines how slowly or quickly they talk.<ref>{{harvtxt|Kempton|2004|p=119}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Show, don't tell]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Pinewood Derby (''South Park'')}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox television episode | title =Pinewood Derby | series =South Park | image =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:South park pinewood derby.jpg|250px]] --> | caption = [[Randy and Sharon Marsh|Randy]] putting final touches on [[Stan Marsh|Stan]]'s Pinewood Derby car. | season =13 | episode =6 | airdate =April 15, 2009 | production =1306 | writer = Trey Parker | director = [[Trey Parker]] | guests = | season_article = South Park (season 13) | episode_list = List of South Park episodes <!-- The WikiProject South Park previously reached a consensus NOT to use season infoboxes because it makes the infobox unnecessarily long. Please do not readd it. --> | prev =[[Fishsticks (South Park)|Fishsticks]] | next =[[Fatbeard]] }} "'''Pinewood Derby'''" is the sixth episode of the [[South Park (season 13)|thirteenth season]] of the American animated television series ''[[South Park]]''. The 187th overall episode of the series, it originally aired on [[Comedy Central]] in the United States on April 15, 2009 and in the United Kingdom on April 17, 2009. In the episode, [[Randy and Sharon Marsh|Randy]] helps [[Stan Marsh|Stan]] cheat in a [[pinewood derby]] race, which inadvertently leads to the discovery of alien life. When an alien gangster visits South Park and the residents come into possession of his stolen "space cash", they decide to keep it for themselves and hide it from alien police officers who are looking for it.
The episode was written and directed by series co-founder [[Trey Parker]], and was rated [[Television content rating systems|TV-MA L]] in the United States for strong to extreme language. "Pinewood Derby" was seen by 2.78 million households in its original broadcast, according to [[Nielsen ratings]], making it the second most-watched episode on [[Comedy Central]] the week it aired. The episode received mixed reviews upon its initial broadcast.
"Pinewood Derby" has been noted for spoofing a number of world leaders, such as [[Gordon Brown]], [[Silvio Berlusconi]], [[Vladimir Putin]], [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]], [[Raila Odinga]], [[Taro Aso]], [[Han Seung-soo]], [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], [[Matti Vanhanen]], [[Angela Merkel]], [[Wen Jiabao]] and [[John Howard]]. The episode was originally scheduled to air on [[MTV Latin America]] in February 2010 but was pulled at the last minute, allegedly due to its perceived negative portrayal of [[Mexico|Mexican]] President [[Felipe Calderón]].
==Plot== Randy Marsh, determined to make sure his son Stan wins the annual statewide [[pinewood derby]], slips an object into the back of the car to give it an advantage. Stan learns from a news report that the object is a [[superconducting magnet]], stolen from the [[Large Hadron Collider]] by Randy disguised as [[Princess Leia]]. During the finals, Randy coaxes Stan to lie to the judges and say he used only the parts in the approved pinewood derby kit. Stan wins first place when his car reaches [[warp speed]], shooting off the track and into space, where it is later found by an alien species. Soon after, a spaceship lands in South Park, but its pilot is a bank robber named "Baby Fark McGee-zax" who demands that Stan and Randy build him a new warp drive while holding the entire planet at gunpoint. Everyone believes Stan and his father can create the drive using only the approved pinewood derby kit.
Stan tries to persuade Randy to tell the truth about the stolen magnet, but Randy refuses in order to avoid embarrassment. As the pair works on the warp drive, an Intergalactic Police ship approaches Earth; McGeezax cloaks his ship and drags Stan out of sight as a hostage, leaving the townspeople to divert the officers' questions. The officers say that McGeezax stole a large sum of space cash, but no one admits to seeing him, and the officers leave. Randy then provides a diversion for McGeezax while Stan, at Randy's insistence, stabs him to death with a [[shiv (weapon)|shank]]. McGeezax's ship is found to contain the stolen space cash, but instead of returning it, Randy persuades everyone to divide it among themselves. Randy, in contact with all world leaders, buys other countries' silence by giving them a share. Four days later, the officers return to South Park. They now know that McGeezax landed here and Randy tells them of his death, but everyone denies finding any space cash.
Randy tries to keep other countries from spending the space cash since that might alert the Intergalactic Police; however, this fails when Mexico spends its money on 32 hospitals and 7 water parks, and China spends it on 48 soccer stadiums. Learning that [[Finland]] is about to divulge to the cops, Randy persuades the rest of the world to wipe Finland out in a [[nuclear missile]] attack. The Intergalactic Police pay a third visit to ask about the strike, but the South Park residents fake disbelief. By this time, Stan has had enough of the deception, so he tells the truth about cheating in the pinewood derby and returns his trophy; however, no one else on the planet comes clean about the space cash. McGeezax emerges from the officers' ship, having only faked his death. He reveals that he is really Kevern Zaksor, ambassador to new world testing, and that the entire chain of events was a test to see if Earth was worthy of joining the intergalactic community but humans proven to be too selfish, greedy, chaotic and deceitful. As punishment for failing, the Earth and the Moon are isolated from the rest of the Universe (although it appears to have disappeared [[South Park (season 15)|later on]]). The episode ends with Randy saying, "Well that sucks."
==Production== "Pinewood Derby" was written and directed by series co-creator Trey Parker. The episode first aired on April 15, 2009, in the United States, and was rated TV-MA L in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Pinewood Derby – Episode Guide |publisher=South Park Studios |url=http://www.southparkstudios.com/guide/1306/ |accessdate=April 25, 2009}}</ref> The theme of the episode was a warning about the dangers of greed, lying, and cheating.<ref name="AVClub">{{Cite news |last=Modell |first=Josh |title=South Park: Season 13: Episode 6: "Pinewood Derby" |work=The A.V. Club |date=April 15, 2009 |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/pinewood-derby,26712/ |accessdate=April 16, 2009}}</ref><ref name="EWTucker">{{Cite news |last=Tucker |first=Ken |title="South Park" and "Reno 911!" teach us lessons |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=April 15, 2009 |url=http://watching-tv.ew.com/2009/04/south-park-reno.html |accessdate=April 16, 2009}}</ref>
==Cultural references==
Among the world leaders who communicate with Randy in the episode are French president [[Nicolas Sarkozy]], Chancellor of Germany [[Angela Merkel]], Brazilian president [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]],<ref>{{Cite news|title=Lula faz "participação especial" em episódio de "South Park" |trans-title=Lula makes a "special appearance" in an episode of "South Park" |work=O Globo |date=April 16, 2009 |url=http://oglobo.globo.com/cultura/mat/2009/04/16/lula-faz-participacao-especial-em-episodio-de-south-park-755299326.asp |accessdate=April 16, 2009 |language=Portuguese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418151424/http://oglobo.globo.com/cultura/mat/2009/04/16/lula-faz-participacao-especial-em-episodio-de-south-park-755299326.asp |archivedate=April 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Prime Minister of Italy [[Silvio Berlusconi]], Chinese president [[Hu Jintao]],<ref>{{Cite news |title=Lula aparece no desenho animado americano South Park |trans-title=Lula appears in the American cartoon South Park |work=JC Online |date=April 17, 2009 |url=http://jc.uol.com.br/canal/cotidiano/nacional/noticia/2009/04/17/lula-aparece-no-desenho-animado-americano-south-park-184750.php |language=Portuguese |accessdate=April 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421001348/http://jc.uol.com.br/canal/cotidiano/nacional/noticia/2009/04/17/lula-aparece-no-desenho-animado-americano-south-park-184750.php |archivedate=April 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Japanese prime minister [[Taro Aso]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Presidente Lula faz 'ponta' em episódio do 'South Park' |trans-title=President Lula makes 'cameo' in episode of South Park |work=O Estado de S. Paulo |date=April 16, 2009 |url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/arteelazer,presidente-lula-faz-ponta-em-episodio-do-south-park,355911,0.htm |accessdate=April 21, 2009 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090419105704/http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/arteelazer%2Cpresidente-lula-faz-ponta-em-episodio-do-south-park%2C355911%2C0.htm |archivedate=April 19, 2009 |df= }}</ref> Mexican president [[Felipe Calderón]],<ref name="ElUniv0209">{{Cite news |title=MTV no emite episodio de South Park y Calderón|trans-title=MTV will not broadcast episode of South Park and Calderón|date=February 9, 2010 |work=El Universal |url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/657349.html |accessdate=February 9, 2010}}</ref> and Finnish prime minister [[Matti Vanhanen]]. The episode received some degree of criticism overseas for depicting the wrong leaders for its countries.<ref>{{Cite news |title=South Park takes aim at Howard |work=ninemsn |date=April 20, 2009 |url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/803749/south-park-takes-aim-at-howard |accessdate=April 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421231603/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/entertainment/803749/south-park-takes-aim-at-howard |archivedate=April 21, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="Macquarie">{{Cite news |title=John Howard stars on South Park, Rudd snubbed |work=Macquarie National News |date=April 21, 2009 |url=http://www.livenews.com.au/entertainment/tv/john-howard-stars-on-south-park-rudd-snubbed/2009/4/21/203600 |accessdate=April 21, 2009 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The episode featured [[John Howard]] as Prime Minister of Australia, even though he had been replaced by [[Kevin Rudd]] almost eighteen months earlier; according to the ''[[Macquarie National News]]'', the episode "has copped some flack on video sharing websites" over the error. The episode also features [[Vladimir Putin]] as President of Russia, even though he stepped down in May 2008.<ref name="Macquarie" /> The episode also featured [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[Gordon Brown]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hughes |first=Steve |title=Gord Robs Alien Shop for South Park Lark |work=The Daily Star |date=April 20, 2009 | url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/view/77450/Gord-robs-alien-ship-for-South-Park-lark |accessdate=April 19, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Battering for Alistair Darling’s Budget|work=The Times|date=April 25, 2009|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/economics/budget/article6164776.ece|accessdate=August 5, 2009 | location=London | first1=Francis | last1=Elliott | first2=Gráinne | last2=Gilmore | first3=Gary | last3=Duncan}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Gordon Brown features in latest episode of South Park|work=Daily Mirror|date=April 20, 2009|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2009/04/20/gordon-brown-features-in-latest-episode-of-south-park-115875-21291764/|accessdate=August 5, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Oh my Gord ...|work=The Sun|date=April 20, 2009|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/article2384488.ece|accessdate=August 5, 2009}}</ref>
==Reception== In its original American broadcast, "Pinewood Derby" was watched by 2.78 million overall households, according to the Nielsen ratings, making it the second most-watched Comedy Central production of the week, behind the [[Ron White]] stand-up special "Behavioral Problems", which was seen by 3.36 million households.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Cable favorites outside the top 20: From ''Fake Fiance'' to ''The Cougar'' |last=Seidman |first=Robert |date=April 22, 2009 |work=TV by the Numbers |url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/04/22/cable-favorites-outside-the-top-20-from-fake-fiance-to-the-cougar/17237#more-17237 |accessdate=April 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u1ho7WLn?url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/04/22/cable-favorites-outside-the-top-20-from-fake-fiance-to-the-cougar/17237 |archivedate=November 6, 2010 |df= }}</ref>
The episode received mixed reviews. Josh Modell of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' said the episode was "boring" and "unfunny", and was particularly disappointing following the episode "[[Fishsticks (South Park)|Fishsticks]]" the previous week. Modell said, "''South Park'' episodes don't get much lazier or uninspired than this one. It was like half an idea stretched out forever and ever, and with very little payoff."<ref name="AVClub"/> Carlos Delgado of ''If Magazine'' said the episode plot was too silly and lacked laughs: "All in all, I was left feeling a little cheated. "Pinewood Derby" wasn’t funny, it was just weird."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Delgado |first=Carlos |title=TV Review: South Park – Season 13 – "Pinewood Derby" |work=If Magazine |date=April 16, 2009}}</ref> Ken Tucker of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' said the episode was told with "the warp-speed storytelling style that is making this season one of ''South Park''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s best".<ref name="EWTucker" /> Travis Fickett of [[IGN]] said he was happy to see an episode centered on Randy Marsh, who he said is an excellent character; Fickett said of "Pinewood Derby", "This isn't a great episode but its fast-paced lunacy in the ''South Park'' tradition and most of the genre tropes it riffs on are dead on."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Fickett |first=Travis |title=South Park: "Pinewood Derby" Review |date=April 16, 2009 |work=IGN |url=http://tv.ign.com/articles/973/973474p1.html |accessdate=April 16, 2009}}</ref>
==Mexican flag controversy== "Pinewood Derby" drew considerable media attention in Mexico when it originally aired due to its depiction of Mexican president Felipe Calderón.<ref name="bbc news">{{cite news |last=Miglierini |first=Julian |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8507514.stm |title=MTV under fire as it pulls South Park episode in Mexico |accessdate=February 10, 2010 |work=BBC News |date=February 10, 2010}}</ref> The episode was scheduled to air in Spanish on [[MTV Latin America]] on February 8, 2010, and was advertised extensively for one week prior to the broadcast date. However, a few hours before the scheduled time, the network decided not to air the episode and replaced it with the episode "[[The Ring (South Park)|The Ring]]", allegedly due to its depiction of Calderón irritating the international community and frivolously spending the space cash on water parks.<ref name="ElUniv0209" /><ref name="bbc news" /> This depiction was said to differ from the image Mexico's [[Secretaría de Gobernación|Ministry of the Interior]] sought to present of Calderón, whom they dubbed the "Employment president".<ref name="ElUniv0209" /> MTV said the ''South Park'' creators did not get a special permit needed to broadcast an image of Mexico's flag, and MTV executives said they did not want to risk angering fans by altering the image. The explanation was met with skepticism by Mexican ''South Park'' fans, some of whom accused MTV of unfair censorship.<ref name="bbc news" /> MTV later announced it would broadcast the episode on April 4 after the network was granted permission from the Minister of the Interior to air it.<ref>{{Cite news |title=MTV will air 'South Park' with Mexican president |work=Associated Press |date=February 26, 2010}}</ref> When asked to comment on the episode getting pulled, Stone said, "That's so far away from us. We read that on the news, too, along with everyone else."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Itzkoff |first=Dave |title='South Park' at 200: Trey Parker and Matt Stone Apologize to No One |date=March 10, 2010 |work=The New York Times |url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/03/10/south-park-at-200-trey-parker-and-matt-stone-apologize-to-no-one/ |accessdate=April 16, 2010}}</ref>
==Home release== "Pinewood Derby", along with the thirteen other episodes from ''South Park''{{'s}} thirteenth season, were released on a three-disc DVD set and two-disc [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] set in the United States on March 16, 2010. The sets included brief audio commentaries by Parker and Stone for each episode,<ref>{{cite web|last=Foster |first=Dave |url=http://www.dvdtimes.co.uk/content.php?contentid=71969 |title=South Park Season 13 (R1/US BD) in March |publisher=DVD Times |date=December 14, 2009 |accessdate=February 24, 2010}}</ref> a collection of deleted scenes, and a special mini-feature ''Inside Xbox: A Behind-the-Scenes Tour of South Park Studios'', which discussed the process behind animating the show with ''Inside Xbox'' host [[Larry Hryb|Major Nelson]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=South Park: The Complete Thirteenth Season Blu-ray Review |publisher=Blu-ray.com |date=March 5, 2010 |last=Liebman |first=Martin |url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/South-Park-The-Complete-Thirteenth-Season-Blu-ray-Review/8807/ |accessdate=March 25, 2010}}</ref>

page.title: Roller derby in the United States

revision.text:
{{Sport overview | country = | sport = Roller derby | image = | imagesize = | caption = | union = | nickname = | registered = | clubs = | first = | match = | league = | national1 = | club1 = | club2 = | national2 = | national3 = | national4 = | countryflag = }} [[File:Roller Derby 1950.jpg|right|thumb|Two women's league roller derby skaters leap over two who have fallen in a 1950 bout in New York City.]] The growing popularity of [[roller skating]] in the United States led to the formation of organized multi-day endurance races for cash prizes, as early as the mid-1880s.{{Cite news|title=Remarkable roller-skating feat.|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=April 13, 1884|page=10}}{{Cite news|title=A six-day roller skate race.|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=March 2, 1885|page=10}}{{Cite news|title=On rollers for six days: beginning the race at the Madison-Square Garden. Thirty-six entries, including Frank Hart and several champions—cheering the start.|newspaper=New York Times|date=March 2, 1885|page=10}} Speed and endurance races continued to be held on both flat and banked tracks in the century's first three decades{{Cite news|title=Roller marathon thrills and jars: 100 boys meet with adventures and tumbles in West Side Boulevard race. Dodge cars and autos. But records are smashed by contestants in red tights, overalls, etc.|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=November 27, 1908|page=5}} and spectators enjoyed the spills and falls of the skaters.{{Cite news|title=Roller skating on banked track: old-time sport is revived with speed contests at the Garden|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 17, 1922|page=11}}{{Cite news|title=24-hour roller race: Ollie Moore will be teamed with Willie Blackburn at Garden|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 17, 1914|page=S2}} The term "[[roller derby]]" was used to refer to such races by 1922.{{Cite news|title=Roller derby on tomorrow|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=April 24, 1922|page=20}} == Associations == There are a multitude of roller derby associations in the United States. * [[Men's Roller Derby Association]] (MRDA){{cite web|url=http://www.mensderbycoalition.com |title=Men's Roller Derby Association: Home |publisher=Mensderbycoalition.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} - 25 member leagues{{cite web |url=http://www.mensderbycoalition.com/leagues/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121228182118/http://www.mensderbycoalition.com/leagues/ |archivedate=December 28, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} * Modern Athletic Derby Endeavor (MADE){{cite web|url=http://www.skatemade.org |title=Modern Athletic Derby Endeavor (MADE) |publisher=Skatemade.org |accessdate=Feb 10, 2014}} - 8 member leagues * Junior Roller Derby Association (JRDA){{cite web|url=http://juniorrollerderby.org |title=Junior Roller Derby Association |publisher=Juniorrollerderby.org |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} - 118 [[junior roller derby]] member leagues as of Dec 2017 * Roller Derby Coalition of Leagues (RDCL) - 8 banked track member leagues * [[USA Roller Sports]] (USARS)http://www.teamusa.org/USA-Roller-Sports.aspx - 10 member leagueshttp://www2.teamusa.org/USA-Roller-Sports/Resources/Member-Lists.aspx * [[Women's Flat Track Derby Association]] (WFTDA)http://www.wftda.com - 402 member leagues and 57 [[WFTDA Apprentice Program|apprentice]] leagues as of December 2017 http://wftda.com/leagues * World Organization of Roller Derby (WORD) ==Leagues== Due to historical accident,{{whom|date=May 2018}} the term "league" in modern roller derby means something more akin to a football club than to a traditional [[sports league]] thus, there are a very large number of leagues sometimes even including two or more based in a single city. {| class="wikitable sortable collapsible collapsed" |+ '''Western USA ''' ! {{other uses|Skylink (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox company | name = Towercom, TradeTec | logo = Skylink logo.svg | type = [[Private company|Private]] | company_slogan = | foundation = {{start date|2007}} | location = [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]]
[[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]] | key_people = Jaromír Glisník | industry = [[Telecommunication]] | products = [[Television]], [[direct broadcast satellite]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = | parent = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.skylink.cz www.skylink.cz]
[http://www.skylink.sk www.skylink.sk] | footnotes = }} '''Skylink''' is a [[Direct-broadcast satellite|satellite service]] that offers Czech and Slovak [[TV station|TV]] and [[radio station]]s to residents of [[Slovakia]] and the [[Czech Republic]]. The package includes channels received without subscription and pay-TV channels. A number of [[HDTV]] channels were introduced into the package in 2009, and Skylink claimed to have 500,000 subscribers from Slovakia and the Czech Republic,{{cite web | last = Dziadul | first = Chris | url = http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/?p=15548 | title = Sky Link prepares more HD | work = Broadband TV News | date = 17 March 2009}} but by the end of the 2009, Skylink had 900,000 subscribers.{{cite press release | url = http://www.skylink.cz/web/structure/6.html?do%5BloadData%5D=1&itemKey=cz_66 | title = Skylink překročil 900 000 karet | publisher = Skylink | date = 13 January 2010 | language = Czech}} Furthermore by April 2010, Skylink has reached 1,000,000 subscribers. {{good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = Tales of Symphonia | image = Tales of Symphonia case cover.jpg | caption = North American box art | developer = [[Namco Tales Studio]], Other Ocean Interactive (Windows port) | publisher = [[Namco]] | director = Yoshito Higuchi
Kiyoshi Nagai
[[Eiji Kikuchi]] | producer = Makoto Yoshizumi | designer = Takashi Hasegawa | artist = [[Kōsuke Fujishima]] | writer = Takumi Miyajima | composer = [[Motoi Sakuraba]]
Shinji Tamura
Takeshi Arai | released ={{collapsible list|title=August 29, 2003| '''''Tales of Symphonia'''''
'''Nintendo GameCube'''
{{vgrelease|JP|August 29, 2003|NA|July 13, 2004|EU|November 19, 2004}} '''PlayStation 2'''
{{vgrelease|JP|September 22, 2004}} '''Microsoft Windows'''
{{vgrelease|WW|February 2, 2016}} '''''Tales of Symphonia Chronicles'''''
'''PlayStation 3'''
{{vgrelease|JP|October 10, 2013|NA|February 25, 2014|PAL|February 28, 2014}} }} |series = ''[[Tales (video game series)|Tales]]'' | genre = [[Role-playing video game|Role-playing]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[Nintendo GameCube]], [[PlayStation 2]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Microsoft Windows]] }} {{Nihongo|'''''Tales of Symphonia'''''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia|lead=yes}} is a [[Japanese role-playing game]] released for the [[Nintendo GameCube]] on August 29, 2003 in Japan. It was published by [[Namco]] and is the fifth [[core product]] of the [[Tales (video game series)|''Tales'' series]]. The game was localized and released in North America on July 13, 2004 and in Europe on November 19, 2004.{{cite web|title=''Tales of Symphonia'' Release Dates |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |url=http://www.gamespot.com/tales-of-symphonia/related/release/platform/gamecube/ |accessdate=May 2, 2012| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120816122206/http://www.gamespot.com/tales-of-symphonia/related/release/platform/gamecube/| archivedate=August 16, 2012}} In Japan, the game was ported for the [[PlayStation 2]] with additional content and was released on September 22, 2004.{{cite web|title=Symphonia to include Tales of Rebirth preview |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/symphonia-to-include-tales-of-rebirth-preview/1100-6101680/ |accessdate=February 8, 2015}} The game takes place in a fictional world called Sylvarant and follows [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Lloyd Irving|Lloyd Irving]]. Lloyd accompanies his childhood friend, [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Colette Brunel|Colette Brunel]], who is destined to go on a journey to save their world. As their journey progresses, they learn that saving Sylvarant endangers Tethe'alla, a world parallel to their own. The game's central theme is {{Nihongo3|"RPG that resonates with you"|君と響きあうRPG|Kimi to Hibiki au RPG}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/cs/list/talesofsymphonia_ps2/ |title=''Tales of Symphonia'' Official PS2 Website |publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 1, 2012}} The game's reception was generally positive with critics praising the gameplay but criticizing the plot. It received a [[Japan Game Awards]] in 2003 and had received re-releases under the [[Player's Choice]] and [[The Best (PlayStation range)|PlayStation 2 the Best]] labels. In the United States, over 100 thousand copies were sold during the first two weeks and has sold over a million copies worldwide.{{cite web |last=Preziotte |first=Mathew |title=July 2004 Sales Figures for America |publisher=Nintelligent Network |date=August 16, 2004 |url=http://www.nintelligent.net/news2063.php |accessdate=May 1, 2012 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050222213823/http://www.nintelligent.net/news2063.php |archivedate =February 22, 2005}}{{cite web| title=''Tales'' series exceeds 10 million copies|publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |date=December 11, 2007| format=pdf| language=Japanese |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/corporate/press/pdf/53-026.pdf| accessdate=May 1, 2012}} Since its release, ''Tales of Symphonia'' spawned a substantial media franchise in Japan. The game has been adapted into seven [[manga]] collections, two novel series, seven [[Radio drama|drama CDs]], and an [[OVA]] anime series. A sequel entitled ''[[Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the New World]]'' was released for the [[Wii]] in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/tales-of-symphonia-dawn-of-the-new-world/related/release/platform/wii/ |title=''Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the New World'' release date |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=May 17, 2012| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601144327/http://www.gamespot.com/tales-of-symphonia-dawn-of-the-new-world/related/release/platform/wii/| archivedate=June 1, 2013}} ''Tales of Symphonia'' and its sequel was collected as a [[PlayStation 3]] [[High-definition remasters for PlayStation consoles|high definition release]] in ''Tales of Symphonia Chronicles'' in 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2013-06-01/tales-of-symphonia-chronicles-confirmed-for-overseas-release-in-2014 |title=Tales of Symphonia Chronicles Confirmed for Overseas Release in 2014 |date=June 1, 2013 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=June 1, 2013}} A [[Steam (software)|Steam]] version was released on February 2, 2016.{{cite web| url=http://blog.talesofgame.com/en/japan-expo-zestiria-collectors-edition-revealed-pre-order-bonus-symphonia-for-pc-and-more/| title=''Zestiria'' Collector's Edition revealed and preorder Symphonia for PC| date=July 2, 2015| publisher=Tales Of| accessdate=July 2, 2015| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150703060149/http://blog.talesofgame.com/en/japan-expo-zestiria-collectors-edition-revealed-pre-order-bonus-symphonia-for-pc-and-more/| archivedate=July 3, 2015| df=}} {{TOC limit|limit=3}} ==Gameplay== Like previous installments in the [[Tales (video game series)|''Tales'' series]], ''Tales of Symphonia'' consists primarily of three major areas: an [[overworld]] field map, town and dungeon maps, and a battle screen.{{Cite book| year=2003 | title=''Tales of Symphonia'' North American instruction manual | pages=10–11 | publisher=[[Namco]]}} The overworld map is a 3D model, featuring a scaled-down version of the game's fictional world which the player travels through to reach the game's locations. As with preceding games in the series, the world map can be traversed by foot, on the party's quadrupedal pet [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Noishe|Noishe]], and on flying vehicles known as Rheairds. On field maps, characters are directed across realistically scaled environments. The battle screen is a 3D representation of an area, in which the player commands the characters in battles against CPU-controlled enemies.{{Cite book| year=2003 | title=''Tales of Symphonia'' North American instruction manual | pages=27–34 | publisher=[[Namco]]}} On the overworld and field maps, [[Tales (video game series)#Skits|various skits]] between the characters can be viewed. They involve animated character portraits, subtitles, and, in the Japanese version, full voice acting. Skits concern anything from character development to side details. Overworld map skits affect Lloyd's relationships with other party members. The player will be able to make certain decisions that imperceptibly affect how the other characters think of Lloyd. Some of these choices have minor ramifications for the game's storyline. ;Battle system [[File:Tales Of Symphonia - Launch Trailer.webm|left|thumb|Launch trailer with examples of battle gameplay. Critics praised the real-time battle system for being fast and accessible to players.]] During battle sequences, the game uses the Multi-Line Linear Motion Battle System.{{cite web |url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2003/08/29/tales-of-symphonia-hands-on |title=Tales of Symphonia Hands-On |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=August 29, 2003 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} Four characters from the [[Party (role-playing games)|party]] are chosen to battle; those not controlled by a player are guided by [[artificial intelligence]] with instructions set by the player beforehand. Damage dealt to the opponent fills a "Unison Gauge". When this is full, a "Unison Attack" can be triggered, allowing the party to use techniques simultaneously on a single enemy. When certain techniques are combined, a special attack results in additional damage. After battle, a currency called Grade is awarded or subtracted based on specific criteria that are fulfilled in battle. It is used to purchase bonuses during [[New Game Plus]]. Players are also prompted to cook food after battles if they have the materials. Cooking recipes determine the benefits received such as [[Health (gaming)|health]] recovery. The degree of the benefit is determined by which character is chosen to cook.{{Cite book| year=2003 | title=''Tales of Symphonia'' North American instruction manual | pages=24| publisher=[[Namco]]}} ''Tales of Symphonia''{{'}}s [[statistic (role-playing games)#Skills|skill system]] is built around the use of "EX Gems", which come in four ranks.{{Cite book| year=2003 | title=''Tales of Symphonia'' North American instruction manual | pages=22–23 | publisher=[[Namco]]}} Each character can equip up to four EX Gems and set abilities to those gems. The abilities determine if the characters will learn Strike or Technical techniques and spells. Combinations of EX Gem abilities can also grant additional abilities called "EX-Skills". The development of a character's [[Statistic (role-playing games)#Attributes|attributes]] is determined by their equipped "Title".{{Cite book| year=2003 | title=''Tales of Symphonia'' North American instruction manual | pages=18–19 | publisher=[[Namco]]}} Titles are earned through story progression, side quests, or completion of miscellaneous criteria. ==Plot== {{Main|List of Tales of Symphonia characters}} [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Lloyd Irving|Lloyd Irving]] and his friend, [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Genis Sage|Genis Sage]] accompany the chosen, [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Colette Brunel|Colette Brunel]] and her guardians, [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Raine Sage|Raine Sage]] and [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Kratos Aurion|Kratos Aurion]] on her journey of world regeneration. The purpose of the journey is to replenish Sylvarant with mana, a necessary energy to their survival.'''Raine:''' Today is the Day of Prophecy. It is a very important day, which the Chosen of Mana will receive an oracle from the Goddess Martel. Now, Chosen One...Colette. Tell us about the journey of world regeneration. /'''Colette:''' It is a journey to seal the Desians. Upon passing the trials of the Goddess Martel, the Summon Spirit that protect the world awaken, and mana is restored. The path of the journey consists of five temples which must be unsealed by Colette. On their journey, they meet [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Sheena Fujibayashi|Sheena Fujibayashi]] who comes from Tethe'alla, a world parallel to Sylvarant. She tells them about how the two worlds vie for each other's mana through the journey of regeneration.'''Sheena:''' My world is called Tethe’alla. [...] The two worlds lie directly adjacent to each other. They just can’t see one another. Our scholars say they exist on shifted dimensions. Anyway, the two worlds can’t see or touch each other, but they do in fact exist next to and affect each other. [...] They vie for the supply of mana. When one world weakens, the mana from that world flows to the other. As a result, one world is always flourishing, and the other waning. Sort of like an hourglass. [...] Sylvarant’s mana is flowing to Tethe'alla. Therefore, Sylvarant is in decline. Without mana, crops won’t grow and magic becomes unusable. If there is no mana, the Summon Spirits that protect the world alongside the Goddess Martel can’t survive in Sylvarant either. As a result, the world slips even further down the path of destruction. /'''Raine:''' Then the Chosen’s world regeneration is actually the process of reversing the mana flow?/'''Sheena:''' Exactly. When the Chosen breaks the seal, the mana flow reverses, and the Summon Spirit that governs the seal awakens. Hoping to find answers from the angel Remiel, the party meets him at the final seal and are betrayed by Remiel and Kratos; both are revealed to be part of [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Cruxis and Desians|Cruxis]], an evil organization led by [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Mithos Yggdrasill|Mithos Yggdrasill]]. The party leaves for Tethe'alla to search for a way to save both worlds and are joined by [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Zelos Wilder|Zelos Wilder]], [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Presea Combatir|Presea Combatir]], and [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Regal Bryant|Regal Bryant]]. The party learns that awakening the Summon Spirits in both worlds will sever the mana tie between them.'''Undine:''' Mana flows from the world in which the Summon Spirits sleep to the world in which the Summon Spirits are awake. This is the first time the Summon Spirits have been awakened in both worlds at the same time. Because of this, the mana connecting the two worlds has been eliminated. Believing that to be the answer, they successfully sever all mana ties between the two worlds.'''Lloyd:''' Does that mean that Sylvarant and Tethe’alla have stopped competing for each other’s mana?/'''Volt:''' .../'''Raine:'''I do not know. The only thing certain is that the flow of mana between the worlds has been severed./'''Undine:''' Yes. Eventually the worlds shall separate.../'''Genis:''' You mean the two worlds will split apart?/'''Zelos:''' That’s perfect! Then they’ll stop competing for each other’s mana! Their actions instead destabilize the Great Seed, the supplier of mana to both worlds, causing it to grow and engulf Sylvarant at an exponential rate.'''Kratos:''' Having lost the stability afforded by the protection of the Summon Spirits, the Great Seed has gone out of control. /'''Yuan:''' No! The purpose of the Summon Spirits was to isolate the Great Seed from the outside world and prevent it from growing! /'''Kratos:''' That was only half of it. The two worlds were forced out of phase by Yggdrasill. They should have drifted apart from each other and have been consumed by the void. But this was prevented from happening because the Great Seed was placed in the center between the two worlds. [...] The Great Seed is constantly being pulled upon from both worlds as they try to separate from one another. It’s a miracle that this delicate balance held up for even this long. /'''Yuan:''' Wait! So the mana links served as a cage to contain the Great Seed in the space between the two worlds? Is that what you’re saying? /'''Kratos:''' Exactly. And because you provided the unstable Great Seed with mana, germinated in a twisted form and has gone out of control. It’s even engulfed Martel. /'''Lloyd:''' Who cares why this happened! I wanna know what’s gonna happen if we can’t stop this thing!/'''Yuan:''' If what Kratos says is true, then Sylvarant will be consumed and destroyed by the Great Seed. And if Sylvarant is destroyed, Tethe’alla will be destroyed as well, as it is linked by the Holy Ground of Kharlan and the Otherworldly Gate. After the party re-stabilizes the seed, they learn from [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Yuan Ka-Fai|Yuan Ka-Fai]] about the origins of Sylvarant and Tethe'alla and how they used to be one world but was split by Mithos with the Eternal Sword; the party realizes they can save the world if they wield the Eternal Sword, merge the worlds, and germinate the Great Seed. They decide to confront and defeat Mithos before seeking the Eternal Sword. Kratos is revealed to have been gathering materials to have Lloyd use the Eternal Sword. He succeeds but Mithos survives his apparent death and possesses a member from the party before fleeing to the comet Derris-Kharlan. Mithos attempts to take the Great Seed with him but is foiled and killed by Lloyd. Using the Eternal Sword, Lloyd merges Sylvarant and Tethe'alla together and germinates the Great Seed into a Giant Kharlan Tree to supply the world with mana.'''Origin:''' The world was originally separated into two in order to prevent its destruction. If it returns to its true form, the world lacks the mana to support itself. The land is dying. /'''Lloyd:''' I don’t need to know why it’s dying! What do we need to do to stop it?/'''Origin:''' Support the two worlds by linking them with the Giant Tree. That is the only way to stop the destruction of the land. [...] '''Lloyd:''' This is my final wish. Eternal Sword [...] Rise Giant Kharlan Tree! ==Development and release== The game was first announced on May 8, 2002 by Namco to be one of the many titles it would be releasing on the [[Nintendo GameCube]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2002/05/08/namco-brings-gcn-support |title=Namco Brings GCN Support |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=May 8, 2002 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} Namco stated it would be a part of the ''[[Tales of Phantasia]]'' series and expected comics, animation, drama CDs and novels to be spun off from the game. Its name was revealed to be ''Tales of Symphonia'' in February 2003.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060614050438/http://cube.ign.com/articles/386/386796p2.html |archivedate=June 14, 2006 |url=http://cube.ign.com/articles/386/386796p2.html |title=GameCube in 2003: Part 2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=February 20, 2003 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} An April 2003 edition of ''[[Famitsu]]'' revealed the game has been in development for two years, its developers are the same from ''[[Tales of Eternia]]'', the game will have the most main characters in the ''Tales'' series, and will be the first 3D game in the series.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/04/09/weekly-japanese-magazine-report |title=Weekly Japanese Magazine Report |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=April 9, 2003 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} During [[Electronic Entertainment Expo]] 2003, a North American localization was confirmed.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/05/09/e3-2003-tales-of-symphonia-us-bound |title=E3 2003: Tales of Symphonia US Bound |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=May 9, 2003 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} A conference by Namco on June 9, 2003 revealed the game will be on two disks and its [[theme song]] will be "Starry Heavens" by [[Day After Tomorrow (band)|Day After Tomorrow]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/06/09/new-tales-of-symphonia-details |title=New Tales of Symphonia Details |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=June 9, 2003 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} To celebrate its release in Japan, the game was bundled with a symphonic green Nintendo GameCube.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2003/07/11/tales-of-symphonia-gcn-bundle |title=Tales of Symphonia GCN Bundle |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=July 11, 2003 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} For the North American version, the localization producer replaced Starry Heavens with an orchestral anthem and focused on hiring professional voice actors to dub the game in order to appeal to the Western audience.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/04/30/pre-e3-2004-tales-of-symphonia-interview?page=2 |title=Pre-E3 2004: Tales of Symphonia Interview Page 2 |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=April 30, 2004 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/06/18/tales-of-symphonia-faq?page=4 |title=Tales of Symphonia FAQ Page 4 |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=June 11, 2004 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} The game was released in Japan on August 29, 2003 and was localized in North America and Europe on July 13, 2004 and November 19, 2004 respectively. The game was re-released in North America under the [[Player's Choice]] label on July 19, 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.play-asia.com/paOS-13-71-71-49-en-70-33c.html |title=Tales of Symphonia (Player's Choice) |publisher=[[Play-Asia]] |accessdate=May 20, 2012}} During the second week of April 2004, ''[[Weekly Shōnen Jump]]'' announced a [[PlayStation 2]] [[Porting|port]] of ''Tales of Symphonia''.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/04/08/new-tales-games-for-ps2 |title=New Tales Games for PS2 |last=Hitmitsu |first=Suppai |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=April 4, 2004 |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} It received new in-game additions and its theme song is {{Nihongo3|lit. "And Thus, I Can Do It"|そして僕にできるコト|"Soshite Boku ni Dekiru Koto"}} by Day After Tomorrow.{{cite web |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/cs/list/talesofsymphonia_ps2/song/ |title=''Tales of Symphonia'' PS2 Theme Song |publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |accessdate=May 13, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/cs/list/talesofsymphonia_ps2/event/ |title=''Tales of Symphonia'' PS2 Additions |publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |accessdate=May 13, 2012}} It was released exclusively in Japan on September 22, 2004 and re-released under the [[The Best (PlayStation range)|PlayStation 2 the Best]] label on July 7, 2005.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/sony-adding-new-budget-reissues/1100-6126871/ |title=Sony adding new budget reissues |first=Hirohiko |last=Niizumi |date=June 2, 2005 |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=May 20, 2012}} ===Scenario=== Takumi Miyajima, the game's writer, explained ''Tales of Symphonia'' was planned to create a "unique symphonia", dependent on the player's choices and the affection system.{{cite journal| magazine=Viva Tales of| volume=2013| number=November| date=| publisher=| language=Japanese}} Miyajima wrote many scenarios, with the most significant events centered on [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Zelos Wilder|Zelos Wilder]]. Originally, Zelos' death was supposed to be [[Canon (fiction)|canon]]. His survival would have been dependent on the affection system: He would die early on if he was ranked the lowest in the affection system, would die at the end if he ranked in the middle, and would only survive if he ranked the top. However, the development staff suggested to have [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Kratos Aurion|Kratos Aurion]] return to the party and the team discussed how it would work. The change in scenario had Miyajima rework Zelos' death into a non-canon path of the story. While generally a self-contained story, ''Symphonia'' apparently takes place within either the same or a similar timeline to the first ''Tales'' game, ''[[Tales of Phantasia]]''.{{cite book|script-title=ja:「テイルズオブシンフォニア イラスト集」 藤島康介のキャラクター仕事|trans-title=Kosuke Fujishima Character Works: Tales of Symphonia Illustrations|publisher=[[Ichijinsha|Studio DNA]]|page=60|isbn=978-4758010191|language=Japanese|date=26 January 2004}} ===Sequel and Chronicles release=== The sequel {{nihongo|''Tales of Symphonia: Knight of Ratatosk''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア ラタトスクの騎士|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Ratatosuku no Kishi}}, localized in English as ''[[Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the New World]]'', was announced on July 20, 2007 for the [[Wii]].{{cite web |url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2007/07/20/tales-set-for-wii-ds |title=Tales Set for Wii, DS |first=Anoop |last=Gantayat |date=July 20, 2007 |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=June 2, 2013}} It was released in Japan and North America in 2008 and in Europe a year after. ''Tales of Symphonia Chronicles'' was announced on June 1, 2013 for the [[PlayStation 3]]. It contains ''Tales of Symphonia'' and ''Tales of Symphonia: Dawn of the New World'' with remastered graphics and additional content. It was released in Japan on October 10, 2013, and it was released in North America and Europe on February 2014 as both a retail version and download release, with the option to purchase ''Tales of Symphonia'' as a standalone release. ==Adaptations== ===Comics=== ''Tales of Symphonia'' spawned seven [[manga]] adaptations after its release: six [[anthology]] collections and a traditional manga series. The first anthology collection, {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Comic Anthology''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア コミックアンソロジー|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Komikku Ansorojī |group=kanji}}, consists of five volumes which were released between November 25, 2003 and February 25, 2006 by [[Ichijinsha]].{{cite web |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67fvkJB5U?url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/goods/title.php?title=21&category=1 |archivedate=May 15, 2012 |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/goods/title.php?title=21&category=1 |title=''Tales of Symphonia'' book releases |publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67fxlRJcw?url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/goods/title.php?pg=2&title=21&category=1 |archivedate=May 15, 2012 |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/goods/title.php?pg=2&title=21&category=1 |title=''Tales of Symphonia'' book releases page 2 |publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} The second anthology collection, {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Yonkoma Kings''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア コミックア 4コマ Kings|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Yonkoma Kings|group=kanji}}, is a [[yonkoma|four-panel comic]]. It consists of five volumes released between November 25, 2003 and December 25, 2006 by Ichijinsha. A third anthology collection entitled {{Nihongo foot|''BC Anthology Collection Tales of Symphonia''|BCアンソロジーコレクション テイルズ オブ シンフォニア|BC Ansorojī Korekushon Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia|group=kanji}} had two volumes published by [[Mag Garden]] on February 2005 and 2007. The fourth anthology collection is {{Nihongo foot|''BC Anthology Collection Tales of Symphonia Yonkoma Short Comic Collection''|BCアンソロジーコレクション テイルズ オブ シンフォニア ４コマ・ショートコミックセレクション|BC Ansorojī Korekushon Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Yonkoma: Shōto Komikku Serekushon|group=kanji}} and consisted of a single volume which was released by Mag Garden on October 10, 2007. The fifth anthology collection is {{Nihongo foot|''Super Comic Theater: Tales of Symphonia''|スーパーコミック劇場 テイルズ オブ シンフォニア|Sūpā Komikku Gekijou Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia |group=kanji}}. It consisted of two volumes which were released by [[Square Enix]] on May 27, 2005 and September 16, 2005. The sixth anthology collection is {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Comic Anthology: The Best''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア コミックアンソロジー The Best|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Komikku Ansorojī The Best |group=kanji}} is a single volume released on June 5, 2010 by Ichijinsha.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104220539/http://data.ichijinsha.co.jp/book/booksearch/booksearch_detail.php?i=75800556 |archivedate=November 4, 2013 |url=http://data.ichijinsha.co.jp/book/booksearch/booksearch_detail.php?i=75800556 |title=Tales of Symphonia Comic Anthology: The Best |publisher=[[Ichijinsha]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=March 15, 2013 |deadurl=no}} The manga series by [[Hitoshi Ichimura]] was titled ''Tales of Symphonia'' and was an adaptation of the game's storyline. The first four chapters were serialized between the April and July 2005 editions of ''[[Monthly Comic Blade]]''.{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050304020717/http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |archivedate=March 4, 2005 |url=http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |title=Monthly Comic Blade April 2005 issue |publisher=[[Mag Garden]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050406100549/http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |archivedate=April 6, 2005 |url=http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |title=Monthly Comic Blade May 2005 issue |publisher=[[Mag Garden]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050507052650/http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |archivedate=May 7, 2005 |url=http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |title=Monthly Comic Blade June 2005 issue |publisher=[[Mag Garden]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 15, 2012}}{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050609031324/http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |archivedate=June 9, 2005 |url=http://www.mag-garden.co.jp/comic-blade/index.htm |title=Monthly Comic Blade July 2005 issue |publisher=[[Mag Garden]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 15, 2012}} Future chapters were released in ''[[tankōbon]]'' volumes by Mag Garden thereafter. Six volumes were released: the first was released on August 10, 2005 and the last two were released on July 10, 2007. ===Books=== ''Tales of Symphonia'' has spun off two novel series adaptions, four strategy guides, a character book, an official scenario book, and an art book. The first novel series is titled ''Tales of Symphonia'' and is written by Kiyoshi Yuki. It consisted of three novels released between November 21 and December 20, 2003 by [[Shueisha]]. The second novel series is titled {{Nihongo|''Tales of Symphonia: Radiance of Time''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア 久遠 の輝き|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Toki no Kagayaki}} and is written by Sera Yajima. It consists of four volumes released between December 20, 2003 and June 19, 2004 by [[Enterbrain]]. An after story by the same author was released on September 18, 2004. Two strategy guides under the [[V Jump Books]] brand were published by Shueisha: the Gamecube guide was released on August 29, 2003 and the PS2 on September 22, 2004. Namco Bandai Games released two official strategy guides on October 1, 2003 and October 27, 2004 for the Gamecube and PS2 respectively. {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Illustration: Kosuke Fujishima's Character Work''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア イラストレーションズ 藤島康介のキャラクター仕事|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Irasutorēshonzu Fujishima Kōsuke no Kyarakutā Shigoto|group=kanji}} is a book by the game's designer, Kōsuke Fujishima, and was released on January 26, 2004 by [[Ichijinsha]]. It provides details on the characters' back story and how their design came to be. {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Official Scenario Book''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア 公式シナリオブック|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Koushiki Shinario Bukku|group=kanji}} was released on June 26, 2008 by Namco Bandai. The book details the history of the world and characters. {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia The Animation Visual Complete Picture Book''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア The Animation ビジュアルコンプリートブック|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia The Animation Bijua Rukon Purīto Bukku|group=kanji}} is an art book for the anime released on March 28, 2013 by [[ASCII Media Works]]. ===Audio CDs=== Seven [[Radio drama|drama CDs]] based on the game's plot were produced by [[Frontier Works]].{{cite web |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67hMklhZb?url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/goods/title.php?title=21&category=2 |archivedate=May 16, 2012 |url=http://www.bandainamcogames.co.jp/goods/title.php?title=21&category=2 |title=''Tales of Symphonia'' CD releases |publisher=[[Namco Bandai Games]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 16, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{Nihongo foot|''Drama CD: Tales of Symphonia (A Long Time Ago)''|ドラマCD テイルズ オブ シンフォニア 〜A long time ago〜|Dorama CD Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia 〜A long time ago〜|group=kanji}} 1, 2, and 3 are stories preceding the game. They were released between July 23, 2004 and September 24, 2004. {{Nihongo foot|''Drama CD: Tales of Symphonia Anthology 1 (Rodeo Ride Tour)''|ドラマCD テイルズ オブ シンフォニア アンソロジー1 〜ロデオライド・ツアー〜|Dorama CD Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Ansorojī 1 (Rodeoraido Tsuā)|group=kanji}} First Part and Second Part follow [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Sheena Fujibayashi|Sheena Fujibayashi]] and [[List of Tales of Symphonia characters#Zelos Wilder|Zelos Wilder]] as they tour the world a year after the events of the main game. The two CDs were released on May 25, 2005 and June 24, 2005. {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Comic Market 78''|テイルズリング・シンフォニア　Comic Market 78|group=kanji}} and {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Comic Market 79''|テイルズリング・シンフォニア　Comic Market 79|group=kanji}} are side stories with guest characters from ''[[Tales of Vesperia]]'' and ''[[Tales of Graces]]'', respectively. {{Nihongo foot|''Tales of Symphonia Original Soundtrack''|テイルズ オブ シンフォニア オリジナル・サウンドトラック|Teiruzu Obu Shinfonia Orijinaru Saundotorakku|group=kanji}} was published by [[DigiCube]] on October 1, 2003 and consists of 4 discs. It debuted at 98 on [[Oricon]]'s charts.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68HzJ8ii1?url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/518366/1/ |archivedate=June 9, 2012 |url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/518366/1/ |title=''Tales of Symphonia Original Soundtrack'' |publisher=[[Oricon]] |language=Japanese |accessdate=May 16, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} The soundtrack was re-released on October 27, 2004 by [[King Records (Japan)]] for the PS2 port of ''Tales of Symphonia''. === Animation === {{Infobox animanga/Header | image = | caption = | genre = }}
