{{Infobox hiking trail | name = | embed = | cellstyle = | title = The Great Trail, formerly known as Trans Canada Trail | photo = Image:Trans Canada Trail Pavilion.jpg | photo_size = | caption = Trans Canada Trail pavilion in [[Fredericton, New Brunswick]] | location = [[Canada]] | designation = | established = 1992 | connected = 2017 | completed = ?? | length = ({{Asof|2018}}) {{convert|24,134|km}} | trailheads = [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]]; [[Victoria, British Columbia]]; [[Tuktoyaktuk, Northwest Territories]] | use = [[Hiking]], [[biking]], [[equestrianism]], [[cross-country skiing]], [[snowshoeing]], [[canoeing]] | elev_gain_and_loss = | elev_change = <!-- Use elev_gain_and_loss if the gain and/or loss is known. Use this field when only the change is known. --> | highest = 2,185 meters | lowest = Sea level | grade = Variable | difficulty = Variable | season = All seasons | months = All seasons | sights = Numerous | hazards = Multiple | surface = Variable | ROW = Multiple | website = http://thegreattrail.ca }} '''The Great Trail''', formerly known as '''Trans Canada Trail''', is a cross-Canada system of greenways, waterways and roadways that stretches from the Atlantic to the Pacific to the Arctic oceans. The Trail extends over 24,000 kilometres (15,000 miles); it is now the longest recreational, multi-use trail network in the world. The idea for the Trail began in 1992, shortly after the Canada 125 celebrations. Since then it has been supported by donations from individuals, corporations, foundations and all levels of government. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://thegreattrail.ca/ |title=The Great Trail |publisher=Trans Canada Trail |accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="annualreport2017">{{cite web |url=http://thegreattrail.ca/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/TCT_AnnualReport2016-2017_FINAL_26-28edit_ENGLISH_smaller.pdf |title=Annual Report 2016–17 |publisher=Trans Canada Trail |page=6 |date=2017 |accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
'''Trans Canada Trail''' (TCT) is the name of the non-profit group that raises funds for the continued development of the Trail. However, the Trail is owned and operated at the local level.
On August 26, 2017, TCT celebrated the connection of the Trail with numerous events held throughout Canada. TCT has said it now plans to make the Trail more accessible, replace interim roadways with off-road greenways, add new spurs and loops to the Trail and fund emergency repairs when needed.
==Origin of trail idea== The creation of the Trail was born of Canada's 125th anniversary celebrations in 1992.<ref>Trans Canada Trail: The 18,000 kilometre dream, second edition, 2006</ref> It has its counterparts in such other [[greenway (landscape)|greenway]] routes as the 12 [[EuroVelo]] routes, the UK's [[National Cycle Network]], and the [[United States Numbered Bicycle Routes]] network.
==Funding== It has been funded largely by Canadian federal and provincial governments, with significant contributions from corporate and individual donors. The first province to have completed its designated section of the trail was [[Prince Edward Island]] (see [[Confederation Trail]]).
==Development and maintenance== The network of the Trans Canada Trail is made up of more than 400 community trails. Each trail section is developed, owned and managed locally by Trail groups, conservation authorities and by municipal, provincial and federal governments, for instance in parks such as [[Gatineau Park]] or along existing trails such as the [[Cataraqui Trail]] and [[Voyageur Hiking Trail]]. The Trans Canada Trail supports the construction and use of [[Greenway (landscape)|greenway]]s to replace roadways.
Moreover, considerable parts of the Trail are repurposed defunct rail lines donated to provincial governments by [[Canadian Pacific]] and [[Canadian National Railway]] railbeds rebuilt as [[walking trails]]. As such, much of the Trans Canada Trail development emulated the successful [[Rails-to-Trails]] initiative in the United States, whereby these transportation corridors are "rail banked" as recreational trails, allowing conversion back to rail should future need arise.
Thousands of Canadians, community partner organizations, corporations, local businesses and all levels of government are involved in developing and maintaining these trails. TCT does not own or operate any section of The Great Trail. As an ensemble, The Great Trail might be one of the largest volunteer projects ever undertaken in Canada.
==Routes and amenities== The main section runs along the southern areas of Canada connecting most of Canada's major cities and most populous areas. There is also a long northern arm which runs through [[Alberta]] to [[Edmonton, Alberta|Edmonton]] and then up through northern [[British Columbia]] to [[Yukon]]. [[File:Trans Canada Trail in British Columbia.jpg|thumb|This map of the province British Columbia shows the Trans Canada Trail, starting in North Saanich.]] The Trail is multi-use and depending on the section may allow [[hiking|hikers]], [[bicycle|bicyclists]], horseback riders, [[cross country skiing|cross country skiers]] and [[snowmobile]]rs. In theory, the Trail is equipped with regularly spaced pavilions that provide shelter as well as fresh water to travellers, but this varies widely from section to section, and particularly from province to province.
"[[Mile zero]]" of the Trail is located outside the [[Railway Coastal Museum]] in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]].
== Future developments ==
While the Trail is connected, TCT have said they will continue to fundraise for the future development and enhancement of the Trail. Among its objectives, TCT says it plans to replace interim roadways with off-road greenways, where possible, to make it safer and more accessible for all users, to add new Trail sections, and to provide emergency funding for Trail sections damaged by natural disasters, etc.
The Trail is not owned or operated by TCT, but the organization provides support to local partners and volunteer groups who maintain individual sections.
== Infrastructure and route details by province== {{Expand section|1= information about infrastructure in other provinces/territories |date=June 2014}} [[File:Train Cars at the Railway Coastal Museum in St. John's, NL.jpg|thumb|The eastern terminus of the Newfoundland T'Railway at the Railway Coastal Museum in St. John's, NL]]
===Newfoundland and Labrador=== As of May, 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eastcoasttrail.com/en/about-us/trans-canada-trail-partnership.aspx|title=Trans Canada Trail Partnership|last=Trans Canada Trail|first=|date=2017-05-25|website=|access-date=2018-02-26}}</ref>, "Kilometre 0" begins at [[Cape Spear]], the most easterly point in [[North America]]. Here it is known as the [[East Coast Trail]], a series of rugged coastal wilderness paths. The route follows the coastline north around St. John's Bay and Freshwater Bay, connecting with the [[Grand Concourse (St. John's)|Grand Concourse]] walkway network at [[Fort Amherst, St. John's|Fort Amherst]]. The route then follows a sidewalkway along Southside Road adjacent to [[St. John's Harbour]] until the former Trail Eastern Terminus located at the [[Railway Coastal Museum]]. From here It follows the former Newfoundland Railway route travelling south crossing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 2|Route 2]] into [[Kilbride, Newfoundland and Labrador|Kilbride]] then through [[Bowring Park (St. John's)|Bowring Park]]. Continuing north-west through [[Mount Pearl, Newfoundland and Labrador|Mount Pearl]] then [[Donovans, Newfoundland and Labrador|Donovans]] crossing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 1|Route 1]] into [[Paradise, Newfoundland and Labrador|Paradise]] passing [[Neils Pond (Newfoundland)|Neils Pond]] and [[Octagon Pond]]. The route then turns south-west in [[Conception Bay South]] and crosses Route 60 before it meets and follows the Conception Bay coastline. At Indian Pond, the [[Grand Concourse (St. John's)|Grand Concourse]] trail ends and the route is known as [[Newfoundland Trailway Park]], an 883 km linear park which consists of the former railbed and which allows motorized access.
The route continues as the Newfoundland T'Railway south-west passing through the east side of [[Holyrood Bay]]. The trail passes through [[Briens, Newfoundland and Labrador|Briens]] as it enters [[Holyrood, Newfoundland and Labrador|Hollyrood]]. The route again crosses Route 60 then the [[North Arm River (Newfoundland and Labrador)|North Arm River]] then travels north through [[Burnt Stump, Newfoundland and Labrador|Burnt Stump]]. The route travels south west passing [[Woodsford, Newfoundland and Labrador|Woodsford]] then passes through [[Brien's Gullies, Newfoundland and Labrador|Brien's Gullies]] before then crossing Route 1 again. The route then passes through [[Brigus Junction, Newfoundland and Labrador|Brigus Junction]], [[Mahers]], then [[Ocean Pond, Newfoundland and Labrador|Ocean Pond]] then a mostly treed area before entering [[Whitbourne, Newfoundland and Labrador|Whitbourne]] and crossing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 80|Route 80]]. Continuing the route crosses [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 100|Route 100]] then enters [[Placentia Junction, Newfoundland and Labrador|Placentia Junction]] before turning north passing over [[Coles Pond (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Coles Pond]]. Crossing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 120|Route 120]], The next major location is [[Tickle Harbour Station, Newfoundland and Labrador|Tickle Harbour Station]] where it again touches Route 1 and follows it crossing a few more times before entering [[Cobb's Pond, Newfoundland and Labrador|Cobb's Pond]] then [[Come By Chance, Newfoundland and Labrador|Come By Chance]]. The route continues as it enters [[Subdivision 1A, Newfoundland and Labrador#Goobies|Goobies]], then [[Northern Blight, Newfoundland and Labrador|Northern Blight]], then crosses Route 1 as it enters [[Clarenville, Newfoundland and Labrador|Clarenville]]. The route follows [[Shoal Harbour River (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Shoal Harbour River]] as it enters [[Thorburn Lake, Newfoundland and Labrador|Thorburn Lake]] then crosses [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 233|Route 233]] as it [[Port Blandford, Newfoundland and Labrador|Port Blandford]] then crosses Route 1 again as it enters [[Terra Nova, Newfoundland and Labrador|Terra Nova]].
The Trail changes to [[Gambo to Terra Nova Trail]] as it continues to Alexander Bay then route 1 then [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 320|Route 320]] as it enters [[Gambo, Newfoundland and Labrador|Gambo]].
Continuing north, the next leg of the trail is called [[Cobb Corridor Trail]] as it enters [[Butts, Newfoundland and Labrador|Butts]] then [[Benton, Newfoundland and Labrador|Benton]] then turning north-west as it enters [[Gander, Newfoundland and Labrador|Gander]]. As it continues, the route passes [[Glenwood, Newfoundland and Labrador|Glenwood]] then continues to [[Notre Dame Junction, Newfoundland and Labrador|Notre Dame Junction]] passing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 340|Route 340]] and finally [[Norris Arm, Newfoundland and Labrador|Norris Arm]].
The next section is [[Newfoundland Trailway Park]] continuing to [[Rattling Brook, Newfoundland and Labrador|Rattling Brook]], as it follows the [[Exploits River (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Exploits River]] through [[Junipers Brook, Newfoundland and Labrador|Junipers Brook]], [[Bishop's Falls, Newfoundland and Labrador|Bishops Falls]], Crossing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 350|Route 350]] and continuing through [[Grand Falls, Newfoundland and Labrador|Grand Falls]].
Now known as [[Exploits Valley and Beothuk Trail]] the trail moves along into [[Windsor, Newfoundland and Labrador|Windsor]] then [[Badger, Newfoundland and Labrador|Badger]] From here it is known as [[Newfoundland Trailway Park]] and travels through [[West Lake, Newfoundland and Labrador|West Lake]], [[Millertown Junction, Newfoundland and Labrador|Millertown Junction]]. the route passes through [[Quarry, Newfoundland and Labrador|Quarry]], [[Gaff Topsails, Newfoundland and Labrador|Gaff Topsails]], [[Kittys Brook, Newfoundland and Labrador|Kittys Brook]], [[Howley, Newfoundland and Labrador|Howley]] where it crosses the [[Main Brook, Newfoundland and Labrador|Main Brook]] and ending in [[Deer Lake, Newfoundland and Labrador|Deer Lake]].
The next stretch is called the [[Deer Lake to Corner Brook Trail]] and pretty much follows Route 1 through [[Pasadena, Newfoundland and Labrador|Pasadena]], [[Steady Brook, Newfoundland and Labrador|Steady Brook]] and [[Corner Brook, Newfoundland and Labrador|Corner Brook]] on the south side of the [[Upper Humber River (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Upper Humber River]] ending as it crosses [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 450|Route 450]].
Continuing south, the route is now known as [[Newfoundland Trailway Park]] passing through [[Mount Moriah, Newfoundland and Labrador|Mount Moriah]] then continuing on [[Harrys River, Newfoundland and Labrador|Harrys River]] into [[Gallants, Newfoundland and Labrador|Gallants]] then crossing [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 460|Route 460]] as it crosses [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 461|Route 461]] at [[Stephenville Crossing, Newfoundland and Labrador|Stephenville Crossing]] in [[St. George's Bay (Newfoundland and Labrador)|St. George's Bay]]. Passing through [[St. George's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. George's]], the route crosses [[Fischells Brook (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Fischells Brook]], then crosses [[Newfoundland and Labrador Route 404|Route 404]] in [[Cartyville, Newfoundland and Labrador|Cartyville]]. Passing through [[St. Fintan's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. Fintans]], the route continues to [[Codroy Pond, Newfoundland and Labrador|Codroy Pond]] then [[South Branch, Newfoundland and Labrador|South Branch]], [[Benoits Siding, Newfoundland and Labrador|Benoits Siding]], [[Doyles, Newfoundland and Labrador|Doyles]], [[Tompkins, Newfoundland and Labrador|Tompkins]], [[St. Andrews, Newfoundland and Labrador|St Andrews]], and ending in [[Cape Ray, Newfoundland and Labrador|Cape Ray]].
The last stretch of the trail in Newfoundland is known as the [[Wreckhouse Trail]]. This trail passes through [[Osmond, Newfoundland and Labrador|Osmond]], [[Grand Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador|Grand Bay]], and ends in [[Port aux Basques, Newfoundland and Labrador|Port aux Basques]] where you would take the [[Port Aux Basques to North Sydney Ferry]] to [[North Sydney, Nova Scotia]].
===Nova Scotia===
As the trail begins where it is known as '''Pottle Lake to North Sydney''' on the [[Cape Breton Island]] in the town of [[North Sydney, Nova Scotia|North Sydney]] separating itself from [[Nova Scotia Highway 105|Highway 105]] after the ferry ride from Newfoundland. As of June 2014, this portion of the route has not been completed however is planned to travel through the town and crossing [[Nova Scotia Highway 125|Highway 125]] following Old Branch Road on the North Side of [[Pottle Lake]].
From here, the trail changes to '''Old Branch Road - George River Division''' continues through [[Georges River, Nova Scotia|Georges River]] and continues south-east touching the north east corner of the [[Scotch Lake (Nova Scotia)|Scotch Lake]] then enters the community of [[Scotch Lake, Nova Scotia|Scotch Lake]] and follows the Scotch Lake Rd.
The route continues as '''Upper Leitches Creek to Scotch Lake''' briefly merging with [[Nova Scotia Route 223|Route 223]] on the Bras D'or Lakes Scenic Drive then follows the Upper Leitches Creek Rd as it enter [[Upper Leitches Creek]].
The route changes to the '''Scotch Lake - Grand Narrows''' trail as it continues now on Tower Rd as it passes the [[MacAulays Lakes]]. The route here will cross [[McLeod Brook (Nova Scotia)|McLeod Brook]] as it passes through the [[Bodale Hills (Nova Scotia)|Bodale Hills]]. The Route changes to '''Little Narrows''' as it enters the community of [[Rear Christmas Island, Nova Scotia|Rear Christmas Island]]. The route again merges onto Highway 223 in [[Christmas Island, Nova Scotia|Christmas Island]] and follows the Highway through [[Grand Narrows, Nova Scotia|Grand Narrows]], [[Iona, Nova Scotia|Iona]], [[Jamesville, Nova Scotia|Jamesville]], [[Jamesville West, Nova Scotia|Jamesville West]], and [[Ottawa Brook, Nova Scotia|Ottawa Brook]]. As the route passes [[Bras d'Or Lake|Bras D'or Lake]], it crosses at [[Little Narrows, Nova Scotia|Little Narrows]] using the [[Little Narrows Ferry]] and crosses the Trans-Canada at [[Nova Scotia Highway 105|Highway 105]] in [[Aberdeen, Nova Scotia|Aberdeen]], then continues north through [[Lewis Mountain (Nova Scotia)|Lewis Mountain]] where it becomes the '''Celtic Shores Coast Trail'''.
====Celtic Shores Coast Trail====
The Trans Canada Trail continues passing [[Nova Scotia Route 395|Route 395]] and passing through [[Scotsville, Nova Scotia|Scotsville]] to a fork north of [[Strathlorne, Nova Scotia|Strathlorne]].
'''North Trail'''
The North Path travels north and ends in [[Inverness, Nova Scotia|Inverness]].
'''South Trail'''
After passing through Strathlorne, the route passes [[Loch Ban (Nova Scotia)|Loch Ban]] then [[Black River, Inverness, Nova Scotia|Black River]] where the route changes names to Mabou Rivers Trail. From here it passes through [[Glendyer, Nova Scotia|Glendyer]] then crosses [[Nova Scotia Route 252|Route 252]] as it passes through [[Rankinville, Nova Scotia|Rankinville]] then crosses [[Nova Scotia Route 19|Route 19]] in [[Mabou, Nova Scotia|Mabou]].
===Prince Edward Island===
Prince Edward Island's portion of The Great Trail is known as the [[Confederation Trail]]. The main trail runs from Tignish at kilometre 0 to Elmira at kilometre 273. Spurs extend to Charlottetown, Georgetown, Montague, Murray River, Murray Harbour, Souris, Wood Islands, and to the Confederation Bridge in Borden-Carleton which links the Island with New Brunswick on the Canadian mainland.
===New Brunswick=== [[Shogomoc River Pedestrian Bridge]] is a 265-foot [[suspension bridge]] in [[Canterbury, New Brunswick]]. Part of The Great Trail and the [[Sentier NB Trail]] network, it was opened in October 2011 by a ribbon cutting ceremony with Valerie Pringle present as a TCT representative. Sentier NB Trail provided over $300,000 towards the project. It is known as the final non-motorized trail link between the town of [[Grand Bay–Westfield]] and the border of the province of Quebec.
===Quebec=== Much of the Trail's current route follows the ''Route Verte'' and has many cycling routes. Completed off-road hiking trails can be found in Gatineau Park and along a route linking the Papineau-Labelle Nature Reserve, Mont Tremblant Provincial Park, and the Mastigouche Nature Reserve. These form part of a planned hiking route that would eventually link Ottawa-Gatineau on the Ontario border with the Gaspe Peninsula and the New Brunswick border.
===Ontario=== As a legacy project of [[2015 Pan American Games]] and [[2015 Parapan American Games]], the [[Pan Am Path]] helps complete {{convert|250|km|mi}} gaps in Ontario's portion of the Trans Canada Trail.<ref>[http://news.ontario.ca/opo/en/2013/10/ontario-expanding-trails-in-time-for-the-peoples-games.html Pan Am and Parapan Am Trails]</ref> In 2013, a one-kilometre-long honorary segment of The Great Trail was opened on the grounds of [[Rideau Hall]] in Ottawa. The Lake Huron-North Channel Waterfront route reduces use of shoulders along the Trans-Canada Highway by about 50 kilometres.
===Prairie provinces===
The route through Manitoba is a mix of off-road hiking trails, road shoulders, and waterways.
Saskatchewan has managed to avoid major highways and paved roads and uses nothing more than rural gravel roads to link off-road hiking trails. The route through this province has been claimed as complete with the opening of the Wakamow Valley Suspension Bridge. However, parts of the land route include some waterways that require a canoe or small boat.
The off-road sections of the trail are very fragmentary in Alberta, where opposition to the trail by some special interest groups has been very strong. A major section in Alberta follows highway 2A between Edmonton and Calgary, a road that combines narrow shoulders with heavy traffic. The main role of the Alberta government so far has been to assist local trail associations in searching for better routes.
===British Columbia===
The main leg of the trail enters British Columbia from Alberta, following the [[Elk River (British Columbia)|Elk River]] passing through [[Sparwood, British Columbia|Sparwood]] and the [[Kootenays]] and Columbia mountains. From there, it delves southward and westward near the [[Kettle River (Columbia River)|Kettle river]]. The trail passes through the [[Okanagan Valley]] over the [[Kettle Valley Rail Trail]], including the very popular [[Myra-Bellevue Provincial Park|Myra Canyon]] portion. From here, it heads through [[Princeton, British Columbia|Princeton]] and continues west to [[Vancouver]]. Vancouver to [[Nanaimo, British Columbia|Nanaimo]] involves a trip on [[BC Ferries]]. From Nanaimo, the trail extends southward as a mix of off-road trails and secondary roadways on [[Vancouver Island]] to [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] where another ferry returns to Vancouver.
[[File:Trans Canada Trail - B.C.png|thumb|Trans Canada Trail. B.C. section. Data sourced from the Government of British Columbia data catalogue.]]
